2.1: Direction: In the given question a statement of assertion is given and a corresponding statement of reason is given just below it. Mark the correct statement as:

sec_questions: The least count of a ruler is-

The least count of a ruler is 1 mm.

In the science of measurement, the least count of a measuring instrument is the smallest and accurate value in the measured quantity that can be resolved on the instrument's scale.

Impulse \((I)=\) Force \(\times\) Time \(\quad\cdot\cdot\cdot\cdot\cdot\cdot\cdot(1)\)

Since, Force \((F)=\) Mass \(\times\) Acceleration \(=M \times\left[L T^{-2}\right]\)

\(\therefore\) The dimensional formula of force \(=\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \ldots\) (2)

On substituting equation (2) in equation (1) we get,

Impulse \(=\) Force \(\times\) Time

Or, \(I=\left[M^{1} L^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right] \times[T]=\left[M^{1} L^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right] \)

Therefore, the impulse is dimensionally represented as \(\left[{M}^{1} {L}^{1} {T}^{-1}\right]\).

Which two of the following five physical parameters have the same dimensions?

A) Energy Density

B) Refractive Index

C) Dielectric Constant

D) Young's Modulus

E)Magnetic Field

Dimensional formula of energy density \([\mathrm{u}]=\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\)

Dimensional formula of Young's modulus \([\mathrm{Y}]=\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\)

Dimensional formula of magnetic field \([\mathrm{B}]=\mathrm{MA}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\)

Refractive index and dielectric constant are dimensionless.

Thus energy density and Young's modulus have same dimensions.
What is the unit of Reynolds Number ?
Reynolds number has no unit. It is a unit-less, dimensionless quantity.
Which of the following is a dimensionless quantity ?

All the physical quantities given in the options except angle are dimensional quantities.

Angles measured in radians are considered to be dimensionless because the radian measure of angles is defined as the ratio of two lengths.
The SI unit of acceleration due to gravity is:
Whenever an object falls towards the earth, it gains an acceleration. This is called acceleration due to gravity. Its SI unit is similar to acceleration, i.e, \(\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\).

The resultant of two vectors of magnitudes 3 units and 4 units is 1 unit. What is the value of their dot product ?

They are in opposite directions as \(4-3=1\)

Hence dot product will be product of their magnitudes multiplied by \(\cos \theta\) which is \(-1\) in this case. This gives dot product \(=-4 \times 3=-12\)

If, \(x=a+b t+c t^{2}\) and \(x\) is in meters and \(t\) is in seconds, then the unit of ' \(a\) ' is:

Given \(x=a+b t+c t^{2}\)

From the principle of dimensional homogeneity, the left-hand side of the equation dimensionally equal to the right-hand side of the equation.

The dimension formula of distance \((\mathrm{x})=[\mathrm{L}]\)

\(\therefore[\mathrm{L}]=[\mathrm{a}]\)

\(\Rightarrow[a]=[L]\)

Therefore the unit of ' \(a\) ' is ' \(\mathrm{m}\) '.
Which is the strongest fundamental force in nature?
Nuclear force also called nuclear interaction, is the strongest of the four fundamental forces of nature.
Which force operates among the heavier elementary particles?

Strong nuclear force operates among the heavier elementary particles and the nucleons.

The nuclear force is a force that acts between the protons and neutrons of atoms. The nuclear force is the force that binds the protons and neutrons in a nucleus together. This force can exist between protons and protons, neutrons and protons or neutrons and neutrons. This force is what holds the nucleus together.

The SI unit of h is J.s or N.m.s and SI unit of \(c\) is \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\) and Si unit of G is N. \(\mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\)

For A: \(\sqrt{\frac{\left(\mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}{ }^{2}\right)(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s})}{(\mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{s})^{3 / 2}}}=\frac{\mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{3}}{\mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{s}^{5}}=\frac{\mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{3}}{\left(\mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\left(\mathrm{s}^{5}\right)}=\mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s}^{3}\)

For C: \(\frac{\sqrt{(\mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{s})\left(\mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\right)}}{(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s})^{\frac{5}{2}}}=\frac{N \mathrm{~s}^{3}}{\mathrm{~m} \cdot \mathrm{kg}}=\frac{\left(\mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\left(\mathrm{s}^{3}\right)}{\mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{kg}}=\mathrm{s}\)

Which of the following is a possible final step in applying the scientific method

Your experiment tests whether your prediction is accurate and thus your hypothesis is supported or not. It is important for your experiment to be a fair test.

You conduct a fair test by making sure that you change only one factor at a time while keeping all other conditions the same.

You should also repeat your experiments several times to make sure that the first results weren't just an accident.

The force between two short electric dipoles placed on the same axis at a distance R varies as?

Here it is given in the question that two short electric dipoles on the same axis are at a distance of R from each other. We are asked to find how the force acting in between them varies in the term of R.

We know the electric produced by an electric dipole in a n axial position is given by the equation,

\(E=\frac{2 K P}{R^{3}}\)

Where, \(K\) is the electrostatic constant.

The value of the electrostatic constant is given by, \(K=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\)

\(P\) is the electric dipole moment.

Now, potential energy of the dipole, \(U=-P E \cos \theta\)

Where, θ is the angle between the electric field and dipole, here it is placed in the same axis and thus the angle between the electric field and dipole will be zero.

\(\Rightarrow U=-P E \cos 0\)

\(\therefore U=-P E\)

Substituting the value of \(E\) in this equation, we get,

\(\therefore U=-P \times \frac{2 K P^{\prime}}{R^{3}}\)

We need to find the value of force acting between the two electric dipoles.

Force acting is given by the equation,

\(F=-\frac{d U}{d R}\)

Applying the value of the potential energy to this equation, we get,

\(\Rightarrow F=-\frac{d}{d R}\left(\frac{-2 K P P^{\prime}}{R^{3}}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow F=2 K P P^{\prime} \frac{d}{d R}\left(\frac{1}{R^{3}}\right)\)

\(\therefore F=-6 K P P^{\prime} \frac{1}{R^{4}}\)

There for the force between two short electric dipole placed on the same axis at a distance \(R\) is proportional to \(\frac{1}{R^{4}}\) or \(R^{-4}\).
If n drops, each of capacitance C, coalesce to form a single big drop, the capacitance of the big drop will be:

If \(\rho\) is the density of a small drop and \(r\) its radius, then the mass of each small drop is \(m=\frac{4 \pi}{3}{ }^{3} \rho\). If \(n\) such drops coalesce to form a big drop of radius \(R\), then the mass of the big drop is \(n \mathrm{~m}=\frac{4 \pi}{3} \mathrm{R}^{3} p\).

Now, by conservation of mass:

\(n\frac{4 \pi}{3}{ }^{3} \rho =\frac{4 \pi}{3} R^{3} \rho\)

Hence, \(R=n^{\frac{1}{3}}\) r

Now, the capacitance of a sphere is proportional to its radius.

Hence the capacitance of the big drop will be \(C^{\prime}=n^{\frac{1}{3}} C\).

A condenser of capacitance \(\mathrm{C}\) is fully charged by a \(200 \mathrm{~V}\) supply. It is then discharged through a small coil of resistance wire embedded in thermally insulated block of specific heat \(250 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{Kg}-\mathrm{K}\) and of mass \(100 \mathrm{~g}\). If the temperature of the book rises by \(0.4 \mathrm{~K}\), then the value of \(\mathrm{C}\) is:

The energy stored in the capacitor

\(\mathrm{U}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{CV}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{C} \times(200)^{2}=2 \mathrm{C} \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~J}\)

This energy is used to heat up the block. Let \(\Delta \theta\) be the rise in temperature, then heat energy

\(Q=\operatorname{ms} \Delta \theta=0.1 \times 250 \times 0.4=10 \mathrm{~J}\)

Now,

\(2 \mathrm{C} \times 10^{4}=10\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{C}=\frac{10}{2 \times 10^{4}}=5 \times 10^{-4}=500 \mu \mathrm{F}\)

Initially,

\(C=\frac{\varepsilon_{O} A}{d}\)

\(\Rightarrow C_{f}=\frac{C d}{d-t+\frac{t}{x}}\)

\(\Rightarrow C_{f}=\frac{C d}{d-t}\)

\(4.5 d-4.5 t=d\)

\(4.5 t=3.5 d\)

\(t=\frac{7 d}{9}\)

A dielectric slab of thickness d is inserted in a parallel plate capacitor whose negative plate is at x=0 and positive plate is at x=3d. The slab is equidistant from the pates. The capacitor is given some charge. As one goes from 0 to 3d :
the magnitude of the electric field remains the same
the direction of the electric field changes continuously
the electric potential increases at first, then decreases and again increases

Even after introduction of dielectric slab, direction of electric field will also be perpendicular to the plates and directed from positive plate to negative plate. The magnitude of filed will be charged.

Before introduced dielectric the field between the plates \(E=\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_{0}}\).

After introduced dielectric the field between the plates \(\mathrm{E}=\frac{\sigma}{\mathrm{K} \epsilon_{0}}\). where \(\mathrm{K}\) is dielectric constant.

As electric field lines flow from higher potential to lower so potential will decrease continuously from \(\mathrm{x}=0\) to \(\mathrm{x}=3 \mathrm{~d}\).

Two spheres \(A\) and \(B\) of radius ' \(a\) ' and 'b' respectively are at the same electric potential. The ratio of the-surface charge densities of \(A\) and \(B\) is:

Given,

\(\mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{B}}=\mathrm{B}\) and \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{B}}=\mathrm{V}\)

The electric potential on the surface of sphere \(A\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow V_{A}=\frac{k Q_{A}}{a}\)

The above equation can be written for \(\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{A}}\) as,

\(\Rightarrow Q_{A}=\frac{V a}{k}\)

The electric potential on the surface of sphere \(B\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow V_{B}=\frac{k Q_{B}}{b}\)

The above equation can be written for \(Q_{B}\) as,

\(\Rightarrow Q_{B}=\frac{V b}{k}\)

The surface area of the sphere is given as,

\(\Rightarrow A=4 \pi r^{2}\)

The surface charge density of sphere \(A\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \sigma_{A}=\frac{Q_{A}}{A_{A}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sigma_{A}=\frac{V a}{k 4 \pi a^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sigma_{A}=\frac{V}{k 4 \pi a} \quad \cdots(1)\)

The surface charge density of sphere B is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \sigma_{B} =\frac{Q_{B}}{A_{B}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sigma_{B} =\frac{V b}{k 4 \pi b^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sigma_{B} =\frac{V}{k 4 \pi b} \quad \cdots(2)\)

On dividing equation 1 and equation 2, we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\sigma_{A}}{\sigma_{B}}=\frac{b}{a}\)

A charge particle of charge \(25 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{C}\) is placed at a point. Find the magnitude of electric potential at a point which is at a distance of \(5 \mathrm{~m}\) from the charge particle.

Given,

Charge \((q)=25 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{C}\) and Distance \((r)=5 \mathrm{~m}\)

The electric potential \(\mathrm{V}\) at a point \(P\) due to point charge \(+q\) at a distance \(r\) is given by

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{1}{4 \Pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{q}{r}\)

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{9 \times 10^{9} \times 25 \times 10^{-10}}{5}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}=4.5 \mathrm{Volt}\)

The work done is against the electrostatic repulsive force and is stored as the potential energy.

A force acts for \(10 \mathrm{sec}\) on a body of mass \(100 \mathrm{~kg}\) which was at rest, after which it ceases to act. If the body travels \(160 \mathrm{~m}\) in the next \(8 \mathrm{sec}\), find the magnitude of the force.

The body travels \(160 \mathrm{~m}\) in \(8 \mathrm{sec}\), the velocity acquired is

\(v=\frac{\text { displacement }}{\text { time }}\)

\(v=\frac{160}{8}=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

This velocity is attained in \(10 \mathrm{sec}\).

So,

\(v=u+a t\)

\(20=0+a(10)\)

\(\Rightarrow a=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\therefore F=m a\)

\(=100 \times 2\)

\(=200 \mathrm{~N}\)

A force \(F\) is applied horizontally to a block \(A\) of mass \(m_{1}\) which is in contact with a block \(B\) of mass \(\mathrm{m}_{2}\), as shown in the figure. If the surfaces are frictionless, the force exerted by \(A\) on \(B\) is equal to:

Acceleration of the system, \(a=\frac{F}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\)

Now, the force exerted by \(A\) on \(B\) is responsible for the acceleration of block \(B\) and is given by \(F^{\prime}=m_{2} a=\frac{m_{2} F}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\).
A stone of mass \(m\) tied to a string of length \(l\) is rotating along a circular path with constant speed \(v\). What is the torque on the stone?

\(T=r \times F\)

Where, \(T\)-Tension, \(r\)-radial direction, and \(F\) - the force acting on the mass.

The radial direction would be from stone to center \((c)\) of the circular path. \(F\) is the force acting on mass \((m)\).

We all know that, if the body is moving within a circular motion, definitely there'll be a centrifugal force working along the center of the path.

Clearly, \(r\) and \(F\) working on the same axis or parallel to each other.

Finally, we can say that the net torques are zero.

A spring is compressed between two blocks of masses \(m_{1}\) and \(m_{2}\) placed on a horizontal frictionless surface as shown in the figure. When the blocks are released, they have initial velocity of \(v_{1}\) and \(v_{2}\) as shown. The blocks travel distances \(x_{1}\) and \(x_{2}\) respectively before coming to rest.

The ratio \(\left(\frac{x_{1}}{x_{2}}\right)\) is:

Initial momentum of the system is zero, i.e.

\(P_{i}=0\)

Given, the velocity acquire by masses \(m_{1}\) and \(m_{2}\) just after they are released be \(v_{1}\) and \(v_{2}\).

Using conservation of momentum,

\(P_{\mathrm{i}}=\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{f}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{O}=\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{v}_{2}-\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{x}_{2}-\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{x}_{1}=0 \quad\left[\because \mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{x}_{1}}{\mathrm{x}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{m}_{2}}{\mathrm{~m}_{1}}\)
What is the value of linear velocity, if angular velocity is \(3 \hat{i}-4 \hat{j}+\hat{k}\) and distance from the centre is \(5 \hat{i}-6 \hat{j}+6 \hat{k}\) ?

The linear velocity of a particle is given by

\(v=\omega r\) As shown in figure,

the direction of velocity \(\vec{v}\) is tangential to the circular path.

Both the magnitude and direction of \(\vec{v}\) can be accounted for by using the cross product of \(c d\) and \(\vec{r}\).

Hence, \(\vec{v}=\vec{\omega} \times \vec{r}\)

Given, \(\vec{\omega}=3 \hat{i}-4 \hat{j}+\hat{k}\)

and \(\vec{r}=5 \hat{i}-6 \hat{j}+6 \hat{k}\)

\(\therefore \vec{v}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ 3 & -4 & 1 \\ 5 & -6 & 6\end{array}\right|\)

\(=\hat{i}(-24+6)-\hat{j}(18-5)+\hat{k}(-18+20)\)

\(=-18 \hat{i}-13 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}\)

A ball of mass \(0.6 \mathrm{~kg}\) attached to a light inextensible string rotates in a vertical circle of radius \(0.75 \mathrm{~m}\) such that it has a speed of \(5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) when the string is horizontal. Tension in string when it is horizontal on other side is \(\left(g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)\)

Tension in the string when it makes angle \(\theta\) with the vertical,

\(T=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}+m g \cos \theta\)

When the string is horizontal, \(\theta=90^{\circ}\)

Here, \(m=0.6 \mathrm{~kg}, r=0.75 \mathrm{~m}, v=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Hence, \(T=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}+m g \times 0=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}\)

\(\therefore T=\frac{0.6 \times(5)^{2}}{0.75}=20 N\)

A cyclist starts from the centre \(\mathrm{O}\) of a circular park of radius \(1 \mathrm{~km}\), reaches the edge \(\mathrm{P}\) of the park, then cycles along the circumference and returns to the centre along QO as shown in the figure. If the round trip takes ten minutes, the net displacement and average speed of the cyclist (in metre and kilometre per hour) is

Since the initial position coincides with the final position. So, the net displacement of the cyclist = zero

Average speed of the cyclist \(=\frac{\text { Total distance travelled }}{\text { Total time taken }}\)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{OP}+\mathrm{PQ}+\mathrm{QO}}{10} \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~min} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}\)

\(=\frac{\pi+4}{20} \times 60 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}=21.4 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}\)
The maximum and minimum tension in the string whirling in a circle of radius 2.5 m with constant velocity are in the ratio 5 : 3 then its velocity is

In this problem it is assuemed that particle although moving in a vertical loop but its speed remain constant.

Tenstion at lowest point \(T_{\max }=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}+m g\)

Tension at highest point \(T_{\min }=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}-m g\)

\(\frac{T_{\max }}{T_{\min }}=\frac{\frac{m v^{2}}{r}+m g}{\frac{m v^{2}}{r}-m g}=\frac{5}{3}\)

by solving we get, \(v=\sqrt{4 g r}=\sqrt{4 \times 9.8 \times 2.5}=\sqrt{98} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

A cubical block of mass \(m\) rests on a rough horizontal surface, \(\mu\) is the coefficient of static friction between the block and the surface. A force mg acting on the cube at an angle \(\theta\) with vertical side of the cube pulls the block. If the block is to be pulled along the surface then the value \(\cot (\frac{\theta}{2})\) is

For balancing the forces:

\(\mathrm{F} \sin \theta=\mu(\mathrm{mg}-\mathrm{F} \cos \theta) ; \mathrm{F}=\mathrm{mg}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\sin \theta}{(1-\cos \theta)}=\mu \Rightarrow \cot (\frac{\theta} {2})=\mu\)

To move the body, \(\cot (\frac{\theta} {2})>\mu\)

The minimum force required to move a body up an inclined plane is three times the minimum force required to prevent it from sliding down the plane. If the coefficient of friction between the body and the inclined plane is \(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{3}}\) the angle of the inclined plane is:

To hold body stationary, force required: \(\mathrm{F}_{1}=m g \sin \theta-\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta\)

The force required to body move up is given by, \(\mathrm{F}_{2}=\mathrm{mg}(\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta)\)

\(\mathrm{F}_{2}=3 \times \mathrm{F}_{1} \Rightarrow \theta=30^{\circ}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{mg}(\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta)=3 \mathrm{mg}(\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta)\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \mathrm{mg} \sin \theta=4 \mathrm{mg} \mu \cos \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=2 \mu=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=30^{\circ}\)

A small block is shot into each of the four tracks as shown below. Each of the track rises to the same height. The speed with which the block enters the track is the same in all cases. At the highest point of the track, the normal reaction is maximum in case of:

Here, speed of the block at the highest points in all the four cases will be same. The normal reactions at these points will depend upon the centripetal acceleration experienced by the block.

Centripetal acceleration \(=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)

Radius of curvature in the first case will be minimum, so centripetal acceleration and hence reaction will be maximum in this case.

The coefficient of static friction, \(\mu_{\mathrm{s}}\), between block A of mass \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) and the table as shown in the figure is \(0.2\). What would be the maximum mass value of block B so that the two blocks do not move ? The string and the pulley are assumed to be smooth and massless.

\(\left(g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\)

The mass of the block \(\mathrm{A}\) is \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\), the coefficient of friction is \(0.2\).

As the blocks do not move therefore, the tension in the string must be equal to the force of friction on block A.

Applying Newton's second law for block A,

\(\mathrm{T}=\mu_{\mathrm{S}} \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}} g\)

\(=0.2 \times 2 \times 10\)

\(=4 \mathrm{~N}\)

Applying Newton's second law for block B,

\(\mathrm{T}=\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{B}} g\)

\(4=\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{B}} \times 10\)

\(\mathrm{~m}_{\mathrm{B}}=0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Thus, the maximum mass of the block B is \(0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\).
only to start a stationary object moving
to start a stationary object and to stop a moving object

force is required to start a stationary object and to stop a moving object due to inertia. Inertia is a property of matter by which it continues in its existing state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line, unless that state is changed by an external force. This is also called law of inertia or newton's first law of  motion
body acted on by zero net force moves with non zero acceleration
body acted on by no net force moves with increasing velocity and negative acceleration
body acted on by no net force moves with constant velocity (which may be zero) and zero acceleration
body acted on by net force moves with constant velocity (which may be zero)
If net force act on a body then acceleration of the body will also be zero.Hence velocity will not be changed i.e. it continues in its existing state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line.

final velocity of the object \(=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

therefore force,

\(s_{2}=4 s_{1}\)

A disc of mass \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) and radius \(0.2 \mathrm{~m}\) is rotating with angular velocity \(30 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}\). What is angular velocity, if a mass of \(0.25 \mathrm{~kg}\) is put on periphery of the disc?

If no external torque acts on a system of particles, then angular momentum of the system remains constant, that is:

\(\tau=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d L}{d t}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow L=I \omega=\) constant

\(\Rightarrow I_{1} \omega_{1}=I_{2} \omega_{2}\)

\(\omega_{1}=30 \text { rad } s^{-1}\)

So, we get after putting the given values in equation (i)

\(\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times(0.2)^{2} \times 30\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \times(2+2 \times 0.25)(0.2)^{2} \times \omega_{2}\)

or \(1.2=0.05 \omega_{2}\)

or \(1.2=0.05 \omega_{2}\)

or \(\omega_{2}=24 \mathrm{rads}^{-1}\)

Four spheres of diameter 2 a and mass M each are placed with their centres on the four corners of the square of side b. Calculate the moment of inertia of the system about one side of the square taken as its axis:

The configuration is shown in the figure. Let us calculate the moment of inertia of the system about the side CD.

I = MI of A about CD + MI of B about side CD + MI of C about side CD + MI of D about side CD

Now moment of inertia of sphere is \(\frac{2}{5} M a^{2}\)

\(I=\left(\frac{2}{5} M a^{2}+M b^{2}\right)+\left(\frac{2}{5} M a^{2}+M b^{2}\right)+\frac{2}{5} M a^{2}+\frac{2}{5} M b^{2}=\frac{8}{5} M a^{2}+2 M b^{2}=\frac{2}{5} M\left(4 a^{2}+5 b^{2}\right)\)
The ratio of the radii of gyration of a circular disc about a tangential axis in the plane of the disc and of a circular ring of the same radius about a tangential axis in the plane of the ring is:

If a body has mass \(\mathrm{M}\) and radius of gyration is \(\mathrm{K}\), then \(I=M K^{2}\).

Moment of inertia of a disc and circular ring about a tangential axis in their planes are respectively.

\(I_{d}=\frac{5}{4} M_{d} R^{2}\)

\(I_{r}=\frac{3}{2} M_{r} R^{2}\)

But \(I=M K^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow K=\sqrt{\frac{I}{M}}\)

\(\therefore \frac{K_{d}}{K_{r}}=\sqrt{\frac{I_{d}}{I_{r}} \times \frac{M_{r}}{M_{d}}}\)

\(\operatorname{Or} \frac{I_{d}}{I_{r}}=\sqrt{\frac{(\frac{5 }{ 4}) M_{d} R^{2}}{(\frac{3 }{ 2}) M_{r} R^{2}} \times \frac{M_{r}}{M_{d}}}=\sqrt{\frac{5}{6}}\)

\(\therefore I_{d}: I_{r}=\sqrt{5}: \sqrt{6}\)

A uniform rod of length L and M is pivoted at the centre. Its two ends are attached to two springs of equal spring constants k. The springs are fixed to rigid supports as shown in the figure, and the rod is free to oscillate in a horizontal plane. The rod is gently pushed through a small angle θ in one direction and released. The frequency of oscillation is:

Let us assume that there is no gravity acting on the system. Therefore, the forces acting on the rod will be the spring forces.

It is given that the rod is pivoted at point O and the two springs are attached at the end points of the rod. Then, the rod is rotated by a small angle θ.

Since the angle is small, the displacement of the endpoints of the rod can be considered as linear displacement. Suppose the end points of the rod displace by a length of x.

When the rod is rotated, the end points of the rod will make arcs of radius \(\frac{L}{2}\). The length of these arcs is \(x\). Then, \(x=\frac{L}{2} \theta\)

Since the angle is small, we can consider the cars as small straight line segments of length x.

So, we can say that the end points of the rod are displaced linearly for a length \(x=\frac{L}{2} \theta\).

If the endpoints of the rod get displaced by x, the springs will be compressed by length x. Therefore, both the springs will push the rod by applying equal horizontal forces of magnitudes F = kx each.

These two spring forces will create a torque on the rod and the rod will undergo a simple harmonic motion.

Torque generated on the rod is \(\tau=2 F r=2 k x \frac{L}{2}\).

We know that \(x=\frac{L}{2} \theta\).

\(\Rightarrow \tau=2 k\left(\frac{L}{2} \theta\right) \frac{L}{2}=k \frac{L^{2}}{2} \theta\)

But we also know that τ = Iα, where I is the moment of inertia of the rod about its point of rotation and α is the angular acceleration of the rod.

In this case, \(I=\frac{M L^{2}}{12}\)

\(\Rightarrow \tau=\frac{M L^{2}}{12} \alpha\)

Therefore,

\(\Rightarrow \tau=k \frac{L^{2}}{2} \theta=\frac{M L^{2}}{12} \alpha \)

\(\Rightarrow \alpha=\frac{6 k}{M} \theta\)

For a simple harmonic motion, α = ω2θ, where ω is the angular frequency of the rod.

This means that \(\omega^{2}=\frac{6 k}{M}\)

\(\Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\frac{6 k}{M}}\)

The frequency of the rod is given as \(f=\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}\)

Therefore, \(f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{6 k}{M}}\).

An electric motor exerts a constant torque \(10 \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{m}\) on a grind stone mounted on a shaft. MOI of the grind stone about the shaft is \(2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~m}^{2}\). If the system starts from rest find the work done in \(8 \mathrm{~s}\).

We know that the relation between torque \((\tau)\) and the angular acceleration (a) is,

\(a=\frac{\tau}{l}=\frac{10}{2}=5 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

Also by the rotational equation of motion,

(As starting from rest \(\omega_{0}=0\) ).

\(\omega=\omega_{0}+a t=5(8)=40 \operatorname{rad~s}^{-1}\)

From the Work-Energy theorem, work done(W) is equal to change in Kinetic \(\operatorname{energy}(\mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E})\),

\(W=\Delta K E=\frac{1}{2} \omega^{2}-0=\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times(40)^{2}=1600 \mathrm{~J}\)

A solid cylinder and a hollow cylinder, both of the same mass and same external diameter are released from the same height at the same time on an inclined plane. Both roll down without slipping. Which one will reach the bottom first?
Both together only when angle of inclination of the plane is 45°

For rolling without slipping (pure rolling), we have \(a=a \mathrm{R} \ldots\) (i)

From, \(\sum F=m a\)

\(m g \sin \theta-f=m a .....(ii)\)

(Here f is the friction force, a = linear acceleration α = angular acceleration)

As we know,

\(\tau=l a\) (about COM)

\(f \times R=l\left(\frac{a}{R}\right)[\) from eqn (i) \(]\)

\(f=\frac{l . a}{R^{2}} \ldots(iii)\)

From eq. (ii) and (iii),

\(m g \sin \theta-\frac{l a}{R^{2}}=m a\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{m g \sin \theta}{\left(\frac{1}{R^{2}}+m\right)}\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{m g R^{2} \sin \theta}{1+m R^{2}}\)

\([m, R\) and \(\theta\) are constant]

Thus, \(a \propto \frac{1}{l}\)

i.e the body whose I \((\mathrm{MOI})\) is less will reach the bottom first.

As we know, \(l_{\text{solid cylinder}}<l_{\text {hollow }}\)

So, solid cylinder will reach the bottom first.

Two spheres each of mass \(M\) and radius \(\frac{R}{2}\) are connected with a massless rod of length \(2 R\) as shown in the figure. What will be the moment of inertia of the system about an axis passing through the centre of one of the spheres and perpendicular to the rod:

Given, that the mass of the spheres is \(M\) and the radius is \(\frac{R}{2}\), also if they are separated by a distance \(2 R\). To find the moment of inertia of the system we need to use the parallel axis theorem of the moment of inertia. Which states that, if \(M\) mass of a body is rotated along the axis of the centre of mass of the body, then the new axis, which is parallel to the axis of rotation and at a distance say \(d\), then the moment of inertia along the new axis \(I_{n e w}\) is given as the sum of moment of inertia along the old axis and the product of the mass of the body with the distance between the two axis.

Or, \(I_{n e w}=I+M d^{2}\)

Let us first find the inertia of the individual system.

We know that the moment of inertia of sphere with centre \(P\) along \(A B\) is given by

\(I_{P}=\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{10} M R^{2}\)

Similarly, the moment of inertia of sphere with centre Q along AB is given by

\(I_{Q}=\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{10} M R^{2}\)

Using parallel axis theorem, we get,

\(I_{\text {new }}=I_{P}+I_{Q}+M d^{2}\)

Here \(d=2 R\)

The, \(I_{n e w}=\frac{1}{10} M R^{2}+\frac{1}{10} M R^{2}+M(2 R)^{2}\)

Or, \(I_{n e w}=\frac{1}{5} M R^{2}+4 M R^{2}\)

Or, \(I_{\text {new }}=\frac{1+20}{5} M R^{2}\)

Or, \(I_{\text {new }}=\frac{21}{5} M R^{2}\)

Statement 1: If there is no external torque on a body about its centre of mass, then the velocity of the centre of mass remains constant.

Statement 2: The Linear momentum of an isolated system remains constant.
Statement - 1 is correct (true), Statement - 2 is true and Statement - 2 is correct explanation for Statement - 1
Statement - 1 is true, statement - 2 is true but statement - 2 is not the correct explanation four statement -1

The velocity of centre of mass remains constant if no external force acts on the body.

External torque (τ = r × F) can be zero if F is finite but vectors r × F are parallel to each other. So, statement 1 is false. Also Linear momentum is always conserved.
Four cubes of side 'a' each of mass 40 gm, 20 gm, 10 gm, 20 gm are arranged in XY plane as shown in figure. The coordinates of the centre of mass of the combination with respect to origin are:

Here, \(\mathrm{m}_{4}=40 \mathrm{gm}, \mathrm{m}_{1}=20 \mathrm{gm}, \mathrm{m}_{2}=10 \mathrm{gm}\) and \(\mathrm{m}_{3}=20 \mathrm{gm}\)

Center of mass of each cube lies at its geometrical centre.

Also, \(\mathrm{x}_{1}=0.5 \mathrm{a}, \mathrm{x}_{2}=1.5 \mathrm{a}, \mathrm{x}_{3}=2.5 \mathrm{a}\) and \(\mathrm{x}_{4}=0.5 \mathrm{a}\)

Also, we get \(\mathrm{y}_{1}=\mathrm{y}_{2}=\mathrm{y}_{3}=0.5 \mathrm{a}\) and \(\mathrm{y}_{4}=1.5 \mathrm{a}\)

\(\mathrm{X}\)-coordinate of centre of mass \(\mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{x}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{x}_{2}+\mathrm{m}_{3} \mathrm{x}_{3}+\mathrm{m}_{4} \mathrm{x}_{4}}{\mathrm{~m}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2}+\mathrm{m}_{3}+\mathrm{m}_{4}}\)

\(\Longrightarrow \mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{(20)(0.5 \mathrm{a})+(10)(1.5 \mathrm{a})+(20)(2.5 \mathrm{a})+(40)(0.5 \mathrm{a})}{20+10+20+40}=\frac{19 \mathrm{a}}{18} \)

\(\mathrm{Y}\)-coordinate of centre of mass \(\mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{y}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{y}_{2}+\mathrm{m}_{3} \mathrm{y}_{3}+\mathrm{m}_{4} \mathrm{y}_{4}}{\mathrm{~m}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2}+\mathrm{m}_{3}+\mathrm{m}_{4}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{(20)(0.5 \mathrm{a})+(10)(0.5 \mathrm{a})+(20)(0.5 \mathrm{a})+(40)(1.5 \mathrm{a})}{20+10+20+40}=\frac{17 \mathrm{a}}{18} \)
The moment of inertia of a body does not depend on:
The distribution of the mass in the body
Position of axis of rotation of the body

Moment of inertia of a body depends on the mass of the body, distribution of mass in the body, position of axis of rotation of the body and also depends on the distance of body from the axis of rotation.
The centre of mass of the body:
May lie within, outside, on the surface of the body
Lies always on the surface of the body

Let’s discuss the centre of mass of a body and what all properties determine the centre of mass.

The centre of mass of a body is the point at which the whole mass of the body appears to be concentrated. Generally the centre of mass lies inside the body but the position may change. Centre of mass depends on the shape and its mass distribution for a continuous distributed object.

The center of mass need not lie within the body. This happens when the body does not have a geometrical symmetricity. When we consider the case of the center of mass of boomerang, it lies outside the body. Because of the shape and curves of the body of the boomerang, it has an asymmetrical distribution of mass.

For a body with constant density and an axis of symmetry, the center of mass lies on this axis. For example, a circular cylinder of constant density has its center of mass on the axis of the cylinder.
A boy of mass 50 kg is standing on a frictionless surface. He throws a ball of mass 2kg away from him with a speed of 10 m/s. Find the final speed of the centre of mass.

Initially the boy was at rest and there is no friction, so the net force on the ball-boy system is zero. Hence, their momentum change will be zero and final velocity of centre will also be zero.

Note that boy will move backwards with a speed of \(2 \times \frac{10}{50} = 0.4\) m/s.

A ball of mass 1 kg is thrown vertically upwards from a building with a speed of 10 m/s, and another ball of mass 3 kg is dropped from the same point towards the ground with the same speed. At what time will the centre of mass have the maximum height w.r.t the ground? Assume balls are left at t = 0.

When the balls are released in their respective directions, the ball going downwards is heavier and is covering more distance per unit time. This is because both the balls have the same initial speed and the heavier ball is gaining speed downwards while the other ball is losing speed as it moves upwards. Their mid-point will be below the point of release and centre of mass, will therefore, be even below that point, since heavier mass is moving downwards.
Three identical spheres each of radius R are placed such that their centres lie on a straight line. What is the location of their centre of mass from the centre of the first sphere?

Distance between first and last sphere = R + 2R + R = 4R

Since the spheres are identical and lie in a straight line, the centre of mass will lie exactly in the middle.

So, the centre of mass lies at a distance of 2R from the centre of the first sphere.
If a car is moving forward, what is the direction of the moment of the moment caused by the rotation of the tires?
It is heading inwards, i.e. the direction is towards inside of the car
It is heading outwards, i.e. the direction is towards outside of the car
It is heading forward, i.e. the direction is towards the forward direction of the motion of the car
It is heading backward, i.e. the direction is towards the back side of the motion of the car

When you curl your wrist in the direction in which the tires are moving then you will find that the thumb is pointing outwards. That is outwards the body of the car. This phenomenon is also observed in rainy seasons. When cars travel on the roads, the water is thrown outside from the tires, due to moment.
If the linear momentum is increased by 50%, then kinetic energy will increase by:

Kinetic energy of the body, \(K=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}\)

Since, the mass remains constant

\(\therefore K \propto p^{2} \)

\(\frac{K_{2}}{K_{1}}=\frac{p_{2}^{2}}{p_{1}^{2}}=\left[\frac{150}{100}\right]^{2}=\frac{9}{4} \)

\(100\left[\frac{K_{2}}{K_{1}}-1\right]=\left(\frac{9}{4}-1\right) \times 100=125 \%\)
A dancer on ice spins faster when she folds her arms. This is due to
increase in energy and increase in angular momentum
constant angular momentum and increase in kinetic energy
increase in energy and decrease in angular momentum

A dancer on ice spins faster when she folds her arms as the moment of inertia decreases and the angular velocity increases, thereby maintaining constant angular momentum and increase in kinetic energy.
There are two objects of masses 1 kg and 2 kg located at (1, 2) and (-1, 3) respectively. The coordinates of the centre of mass are:
Consider a sphere of uniformly distributed mass of 1 kg/m3 and radius 1 m. Its moment of intertia about one diameter is:

Here given a sphere is a uniformly distributed mass throughout its axis for as 1 kg m-3 and the radius is about r = 1 m, because it's continuously distributed mass we can say that its density is ρ = 1 kg m-3.

For finding the mass(m) we know that mass is the product of density (ρ) and Volume (V).

∴ m = ρ × V

\(\therefore \mathrm{m}=1 \times \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{m}=\frac{4}{3} \times 3.14 \times(1)^{3}=4.186 \mathrm{~kg}\)     .....(i)

→ For uniformly distributed sphere now finding a moment of inertia we know that

\(\therefore \mathrm{I}=\frac{2}{5} \mathrm{mr}^{2}=\frac{2}{5} \times 4.186 \times(1)^{3}[\because \mathrm{m}=4.186 \mathrm{~kg}\) from eq. (i) \(]\)

∴ I = 1.67 kg m2

So, the moment of inertia is about 1.67 kg m2 for the solid sphere.
As force is to torque, mass is to:

Angular Momentum (L):

The turning momentum of the particle about the axis of rotation is called the angular momentum of the particle. Mathematically angular momentum can be written as: 

L = Iω

Where I = Moment of inertia and ω = angular velocity

The mass is related here with the moment of inertia.

  • Force is related with torque in rotational motion
  • Similarly, mass is related to the moment of inertia in rotational motion.
  • Whereas, angular momentum (Iω) is similar to linear momentum (mv)
  • Also, the radius of gyration is the distance where we assume the mass is concentrated.
A shell at rest explodes. The center of mass of the fragments:

Linear momentum: A linear momentum includes mass as well as object's velocity so, when we calculate linear momentum we always take the product of mass of an object and its velocity. We define its S.I. unit by \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\). Numerically, we can write it as \(\vec{P}=m \vec{v}\). Momentum and velocity are vector quantities and \(m\) is a mass.

Center of mass: This is the mass which is focused on the center of a body. If we define this center properly, then we will mean that it is the average of the whole mass of the body which is centered at one point.

According to the question, the shell was at rest first and then it exploded. So, the explosion took no force from the outside. This means as the forces acting on it were inside of the shell so the momentum will be zero. As the linear momentum of the object (here shell) was zero then even after explosion the center of mass will remain zero. Therefore, after the action of explosion of shell into fragments will result into its center of mass at rest.

Consider a system of two particles having masses \(m_{1}\) and \(m_{2}\). If the particle of mass \(m_{1}\) is pushed towards the mass centre of particles through a distance '\(d\)', by what distance would be particle of mass \(m_{2}\) move so as to keep the mass centre of particles at the original position?

\(m_{1} r_{1}=m_{2} r_{2} \ldots(1)\)

\(m_{1}\left(r_{1}-d\right)=m_{2}\left(r_{2}-d^{\prime}\right) \ldots . .(2)\)

from (1) and (2) we get

\(d^{\prime}=\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}} d\)
When a explosive shell travelling in a parabolic path under the gravity explodes, the centre of mass of the fragments will continue to move:

When an explosive shell travelling in a parabolic path under the effect of gravity explodes, the center of mass of the fragments will move along the original parabolic path.

We know that explosive shell travelling in a parabolic path under gravity so,

Before explosion \(=\frac{\overrightarrow{F_{e x t}}}{M}=\frac{m g}{M}=g\)

After \(\exp\) losion \(=\frac{m_{1} g+m_{2} g+\ldots .}{m_{1}+m_{2}+\ldots}=g\)

The internal forces have no effect on the trajectory of the center of mass, and the forces due to explosion are the internal forces.

So the center of mass will follow the same parabolic path even after the explosion.

Two bodies of masses 5 kg and 10 kg are moving towards each other with equal velocities of 15 m/sec. Find the velocity of the centre of mass.

Given: m1 = 5 kg, m2 = 10 kg, v1 = 15 m/sec, and v2 = -15 m/sec

  • We know that if a system of particles have n particles and all are moving with some velocity, then the velocity of the centre of mass is given as,

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}+\ldots+m_{n} v_{n}}{m_{1}+m_{2}+\ldots+m_{n}}\)     .....(i)

By equation (i) the velocity of the centre of mass is given as,

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{(5 \times 15)+(10 \times-15)}{5+10}\)

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{(5-10) \times 15}{15}\)

\(\Rightarrow V=-5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}\)

Two particles of mass 10 kg and 30 kg are placed as if they are connected by a straight line. If the 10 kg mass is shifted towards the 30 kg mass by 2 cm, by what distance should the 30 kg mass move, such that their centre of mass is not changed?

Let the particle be separated by a distance x cm and let us consider a point (0, 0) with respect to which the centre of mass will be calculated.

The centre of mass for this arrangement will be \(C_{x}=\frac{10(0)+30(x)}{10+30}\)

If the 10 kg moves by a distance of 2 cm, let us assume that the 30 kg mass move by y cm towards 10 kg mass.

The new centre of mass will be \(C_{x}=\frac{10(2)+30(x-y)}{10+30}\)

Given that the centre of mass cannot change.

\(\Rightarrow \frac{10(0)+30(x)}{10+30}=\frac{10(2)+30(x-y)}{10+30}\)

\(\Rightarrow 30 \mathrm{x}=20+30(x-y)\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{y}=\frac{2 }{ 3} \mathrm{c m}\)

Therefore, 30 kg mass should move \(\frac{2}{3}\) cm towards 10 kg.
A solid sphere is rolling down an inclined plane. Then, the ratio of its translational kinetic energy to its rotational kinetic energy is:

Translational kinetic energy,

\(K_{T}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)

Rotational kinetic energy V1

\(K_{R}=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{2}{5} m R^{2} \times \frac{v^{2}}{R^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{1}{5} m v^{2}\)

\(\frac{K_{T}}{K_{R}}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}}{\frac{1}{5} m v^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{5}{2}=2.5\)
Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding center of mass?
The center of gravity is the point through which the force of gravity acts on an object or system.
Centre of Mass of a body is a point at which the whole of the mass of the body can be assumed as a point mass.
The center of Mass of a body will always be inside the body.
All of the above statements are correct regarding center of mass.

Centre of mass: Centre of Mass of a body is a point at which the whole of the mass of the body appeared to be concentrated.

Point mass: The body can act as a point mass at the point at which all the mass appeared to be concentrated i.e. center of mass.

Centre of gravity: The Centre of gravity of a body is a point at which the weight of the body can be assumed.

Option (A): Centre of gravity: The Centre of gravity of a body is a point at which the weight of the body can be assumed. 

  • It is the point where the force of gravity acts on the body.
  • So this is a correct statement.

Option (B): Centre of mass: Centre of Mass of a body is a point at which the whole of the mass of the body appeared to be concentrated.

  • At the center of mass, a body can be assumed as a point mass.
  • So, this is a correct statement.

Option (C): Centre of mass of a body need not be inside the body.

  • For example, The center of mass of a ring is located at its center, where there isn't any mass i.e. centre of mass is out of the body.
  • So, this statement is incorrect given in the question.

A circular disc of radius \(R\) is removed from a bigger circular disc of radius \(2 R\), such that the circumferences of the discs coincide. The centre of mass of the new disc is \(\frac{\alpha }{ R}\) from the centre of the bigger disc. The value of \(\alpha\) is:

In figure, O is the centre of circular disc of radius 2R and mass M.C1 is centre of disc of radius R, which is removed. If σ is mass per unit area of disc, then

\(M=\pi(2 R)^{2} \sigma\)

Mass of disc removed, \(M_{1}=\pi R^{2} \sigma=\frac{1}{4} M\)

Mass of remaining disc, \(M_{2}=M-M_{1}\)

\(=M-\frac{1}{4} M=\frac{3}{4} M\)

Let centre of mass of remining disc be at \(C_{2}\) where \(O C_{2}=x\)

As \(M_{1} \times O C_{1}=M_{2} \times O C_{2}\)

\(\therefore \frac{M}{4} R=\frac{3 M}{4} x\)

\(x=\frac{R}{3}=\alpha R \therefore \alpha=\frac{1}{3}\)

The angle turned by a body undergoing circular motion depends on time as \(\theta=\theta_{o}+\theta_{1} t+\theta_{2} t^{2}\). Then the angular acceleration of the body is:

Angle turned by the body

\(\theta=\theta_{0}+\theta_{1} t+\theta_{2} t^{2} \)

\(=\frac{d \theta}{d t} \)

\(=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\theta_{0}+\theta_{1} t+\theta_{2} t^{2}\right)\)

Angular velocity \(=\theta_{1}+2 \theta_{2} t\)

Angular acceleration \(\alpha=\frac{d \omega}{d t}\)

\(=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\theta_{1}+2 \theta_{2} t\right) \)

\(=2 \theta_{2}\)

The angular speed of a body changes from ω1 and ω2 without applying an external torque but due to change in its moment of inertia. The ratio of change in its moment of inertia. The ratio of radii of gyration in the two cases is:

Let the radius of gyration initially was K1, and angular velocity initially was ω1.

The initial moment of inertia I1 = mK12

After the change, the radius of gyration becomes K2, angular velocity becomes ω2.

The final moment of inertia I2 = mK22

Since no torque has been applied, no change in linear momentum.

Initial linear momentum = Final linear momentum

\(I \omega_{1}=I \omega_{2} \)

\(\left(m R_{1}^{2}\right) \cdot \omega_{1}=\left(m_{2}^{2}\right) \cdot \omega_{2} \)

\(K_{1}^{2} \cdot \omega_{1}=K_{2}^{2} \cdot \omega_{2} \)

\(\frac{K_{1}^{2}}{K_{2}^{2}}=\frac{\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}} \)

\(\frac{K_{1}}{K_{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}}}\)

So, \(\sqrt{\frac{\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}}}\) is the correct answer.
Moment of inertia does not depend upon:

The moment of inertia is defined as the quantity which decides the amount of torque needed for a specific angular acceleration in a rotational axis. It is also known as the angular mass or rotational inertia.

The moment of inertia of a body depends upon the following factors:

1) Density of the material

2) Shape and size of the body

3) Axis of the rotation

For the same mass and size of the solid body, it depends on how the mass is distributed relative to the axis (like the moment of inertia is always relative to a given axis). The farther the mass or a body is located from the axis, the bigger is the coefficient (so the larger moment of inertia for given mass and size of the body).

Here, let us say that the above body is a collection of small point masses. Let us suppose that the mass of the point mass is m and its distance from the axis is ‘r’. So, the moment of inertia of the mass m is given as,

\(I=m r^{2}\)

From the given options we can say that the moment of inertia of a body is independent of the angular velocity of the body. Because we know that the moment of inertia of a body is the product of the mass of the body and the square of the distance of the body from the axis. So, it depends only upon the mass and distance of the mass from the axis.
A solid cylinder of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\) rolls down an inclined plane of height \(h\). The angular velocity of the cylinder when it reaches the bottom of the plane will be:

[since there is no relative motion at point of contact, work done by friction \(W_{f}=0\) in pure rolling]

Applying mechanical energy conservation,

Loss in PE \(=\) Gain in \(K_{\text {Trans }}+\) Gain in \(K E_{\text {Rot }}\)

or \(M g h=\frac{1}{2} M v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \omega^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow M g h=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} \omega^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\right) \omega^{2}\)

\([\because v=\mathrm{R} \omega\) for pure rolling]

\(\Rightarrow M g h=\frac{3}{4} M R^{2} \omega^{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \omega^{2}=\frac{4 g h}{3 R^{2}} \)

\(\therefore \omega=\frac{2}{R} \sqrt{\frac{g h}{3}}\)

A stationary body of mass \(3 \mathrm{~kg}\) explodes into three equal pieces. Two of the pieces fly off at right angles to each other. One with a velocity of \(2 \hat{\mathrm{im}} / \mathrm{s}\) and the other with a velocity of \(3 \hat{j} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). If the explosion takes place in \(10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}\), the average force acting on the third piece in newtons is:

Mass of each fragment

\(\mathrm{m}=\frac{\mathrm{M}}{3}=\frac{3 \mathrm{~kg}}{3}=1 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Let the momentum of third piece be \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{3}}\) and that of other two be \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{1}}\) and \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{2}}\)

\(\therefore \overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{1}}=\mathrm{mv}_{1}=2 \hat{1}\)

and

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{2}}=\mathrm{mv}_{2}=3 \hat{\mathrm{j}}\)

Initial momentum of the bomb is zero i.e \(\vec{P}_{i}=0\)

Applying conservation of momentum:

\(0=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{1}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{2}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{3}}\)

\(0=2 \hat{1}+3 \hat{\mathrm{j}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{3}}=-(2 \hat{\mathrm{i}}+3 \mathrm{j}) \mathrm{kgms}^{-1}\)

Now average force acting on third piece \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{\overrightarrow{\mathrm{P}_{3}}}{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{-\left(22_{1}^{\hat{A}}+3 \hat{\mathrm{j}}\right)}{10^{-5}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}=-\left(2{ }_{1}^{A}+3 \mathrm{j}\right) \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N}\)

A given object takes \(n\) times as much time to slide down at \(45^{\circ}\) rough incline as it takes to slide down a perfectly smooth \(45^{\circ}\) incline. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the incline is given by:

For rough surface,

\(m g \sin \theta-\mu m g \cos \theta=m a\)

\(\rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{g}}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{\mu \mathrm{g}}{\sqrt{2}}=a\quad....(i)\)

or \(^{\prime} \mathrm{a}=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{\sqrt{2}}[1-\mu], \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{nt}\) [Acc. to question]

For smooth surface

\(\mathrm{mg} \sin \theta=m a^{\prime}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{g}}{\sqrt{2}}=\mathrm{a}^{\prime} \quad \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{t}\)

since both starts From O i.e. from rest and the distance (S) is same then

\(\mathrm{S}_{1}=\mathrm{S}_{2}\)

\(\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}=\frac{1}{2} a(n t)^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{g}}{\sqrt{2}} \mathrm{t}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{\sqrt{2}}(1-\mu) \mathrm{n}^{2} \mathrm{t}^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{n}^{2}[1-\mu]=1\)

\(\Rightarrow 1-\mu=\frac{1}{n^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mu=\left(1-\frac{1}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}\right)\)

A small block is shot into each of the four tracks as shown below. Each of the frictionless tracks rises to the same height. The speed with which the block enters the tracks is the same in all the cases. At the highest point of the track, normal reaction is the maximum in:

Here, speed of the block at the highest points in all the four cases will be same. The normal reactions at these points will depend upon the centripetal acceleration experienced by the block.

Centripetal acceleration \(=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)

Radius of curvature in the first case will be minimum, so centripetal acceleration and hence reaction will be maximum in this case.

Two blocks of equal mass m are released from the top of a smooth fixed wedge as shown in the figure. The acceleration of the center of mass of the two blocks is

Let us consider incline surfaces of wedge as x-axis and y-axis respectively. We can write accelerations of blocks A and B

\(\vec{a}_{A}=m g \sin 30^{\circ} \hat{i}\) and \(\vec{a}_{B}=m g \cos 30^{\circ} \hat{j}\)

The acceleration of center of mass of two blocks can be written as

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{A}}+m_{\mathrm{B}} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{B}}}{\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}}+m_{\mathrm{B}}}= \frac{m g \sin 30^{\circ} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\mathrm{mg} \sin 60^{\circ} \hat{\mathrm{j}}}{\mathrm{m}+\mathrm{m}}\)

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{\mathrm{g} \sin 30^{\circ} \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\mathrm{g} \sin 60^{\circ} \hat{\mathrm{j}}}{2}\)

\(\vec{a}_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{4} \hat{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3} \mathrm{~g}}{4} \hat{j}\)

\(\Rightarrow|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{cm}|=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{2}\)

The minimum force required to move a body up an inclined plane of inclination \(30^{\circ}\) is found to be thrice the minimum force required to prevent it from sliding down the plane. The coefficient of friction between the body and the plane is:

Force required to move body upward, \(\mathrm{F}_{1}=\mathrm{mg} \sin \theta+\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta\)

Force required to prevent sliding, \(F_{2}=m g \sin \theta-\mu \mathrm{mg} \cos \theta\)

\(m g \sin \theta+\mu m g \cos \theta=3(m g \sin \theta-\mu m g \cos \theta)\)

\(\mathrm{As}, \mathrm{F}_{1}=3 \mathrm{~F}_{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mu=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{3}}\)

A cubical block of mass \(m\) rests on a rough horizontal surface, \(\mu\) is the coefficient of static friction between the block and the surface. A force mg acting on the cube at an angle \(\theta\) with vertical side of the cube pulls the block. If the block is to be pulled along the surface then the value \(\cot (\frac{\theta}{2})\) is:

For balancing the forces: 

\(\mathrm{F} \sin \theta=\mu(\mathrm{mg}-\mathrm{F} \cos \theta)\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{mg}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\sin \theta}{(1-\cos \theta)}=\mu \Rightarrow \cot (\frac{\theta} {2})=\mu\)

To move the body, \(\cot (\frac{\theta}{2})>\mu\)

A block of mass \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) is resting on an inclined plane. The inclination of the plane to the horizontal direction is gradually increased. It is found that, when the angle of inclination is \(30^{\circ}\), the block just begins to slide down the plane. The coefficient of sliding friction \(\mu_{\mathrm{s}}\) between the block and the plane is:-

When forces are in equilibrium, \(f_{\mathrm{s}}=\mathrm{w} \sin \theta\) and \(\mathrm{N}=\mathrm{w} \cos \theta\)

\(\therefore \mu_{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\mathrm{N}}=\frac{\mathrm{w} \sin \theta}{\mathrm{w} \cos \theta}=\tan 30^{\circ}\)

The tension at the midpoint \(\mathrm{C}\) and \(\mathrm{D}\) of the lower and the upper wires will be respectively:

\(\left(M_{B}+m_{B C}\right) a=T_{C}-M_{A} g\)

Given: \(\mathrm{a}=0.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}, \mathrm{~m}_{\mathrm{BC}}=\frac{1}{2} \times 0.2=0.1 \mathrm{~kg}\), for wire \(\mathrm{BC}\).

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{C}}=(1.9+0.1)(0.2+9.8)=20 \mathrm{~N}\)

For tension at D: 

\(\left(M_{A}+M_{B}+m_{A B}\right) a=T_{D}-\left(M_{A}+M_{B}+m_{w}\right) g\)

Given: \(\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{AB}}=0.2 \mathrm{~kg}\) for wire \(\mathrm{AB}\).

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{D}}=(2.9+1.9+0.2)(0.2+9.8)=50 \mathrm{~N}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{C}}=20 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{D}}=50 \mathrm{~N}\)
The maximum and minimum tension in the string whirling in a circle of radius 2.5 m with constant velocity are in the ratio 5 : 3 then its velocity is (g = 9.8 m/s2):

Although the particle is travelling in a vertical loop, its speed is believed to be constant in this scenario.

Tension at lowest point, \(T_{\max }=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}+\mathrm{mg}\)

Tension at highest point, \(T_{\min }=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{r}-\mathrm{mg}\)

\(\therefore \frac{\mathrm{T}_{\max }}{\mathrm{T}_{\min }}=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}+\mathrm{mg}}{\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}-\mathrm{mg}}=\frac{5}{3}\)

On solving we get,

\(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{4 g r}=\sqrt{4 \times 9.8 \times 2.5}=\sqrt{98} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

A resultant force causes acceleration and a change in the velocity of the body for as long as it acts.The change in momentum is equal to the product of the average force and duration. Conversely, a small force applied for a long time produces the same change in momentum, the same impulse, as a larger force applied for a short time interval.

Impulse J is

J=Faverage(t2−t1)J=Faverage(t2−t1)

The impulse is the integral of the resultant force (F) with respect to time

J=∫t1t2F.dt

If second law is applied to a rigid body
the acceleration is that of any particle in the body
the acceleration is the average of all particles in the body
the acceleration is that of the centre of mass

a rigid body is characterized by the fact that the distances between any two particles that make up the body is constant in time. This means that instead of talking about the motion of each particle, we can talk about the motion of any one point in the body and of the body as a whole with reference to this one particle. The most convenient choice for this one point is the Centre of Mass

Newton's second law of motion gives the quantitative definition of force. The acceleration of an object as produced by a net force is directly proportional to the magnitude of the net force, in the same direction as the net force, and inversely proportional to the mass of the object

The momentum of a body is directly proportional to the applied force and takes place in the direction in which the force acts
The rate of change of momentum of a body is directly proportional to the applied force and takes place in the direction in which the force acts

Inertia is the resistance of any physical object to any change in its state of motion; this includes changes to its speed, direction, or state of rest. It is the tendency of objects to keep moving in a straight line at constant velocity. Inertia is a property of matter by which it continues in its existing state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line, unless that state is changed by an external force.

A block of mass \(2\) kg rests on a rough inclined plane making an angle of \(30^\circ\) with the horizontal. The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane is \(0.7\). The frictional force on the block is:

Given,

Mass \((m)=2\) kg

Coefficient of limiting friction \((\mu)= 0.7\)

Inclined plane making angle \((\theta)= 30^\circ\)

As we know,

The force applied on the body that is on the inclined plane is given as,

\(F = mg \sin \theta\)

\(\therefore F =2 \times 9.8 \times \sin 30^{\circ}\)

\(=2 \times 9.8 \times \frac{1}{2}\)

\(=9.8\) N

The limiting friction force between the block and the inclined plane is given as,

\(f =\mu mg \cos \theta\)

\(\therefore f =0.7 \times 2 \times 9.8 \cos 30^{\circ}\)

\(= 0.7 \times 2 \times 9.8 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)

\(=11.88\) N

Since the limiting friction force is greater than the force that tends to slide the body.

Thus, the body will be at rest and the force of friction on the block is \(9.8\) N.

While teaching in a class Mayank ask a question on the equilibrium of particle as shown in the figure and ask the student to find the weight of a body, if T2 = 100 N. Shreya gives the correct answer. So, what is the answer given by Shreya?

First, draw the free body diagram of the given figure and resolve it into a horizontal and vertical component.


As we know that the value of the horizontal component is always zero irrespective of the inclination of the body.

So, the Horizontal component will be,

\(T_{1} \cos 30^{\circ}=100 \cos 60^{\circ} \)

\(\therefore T_{1}=\frac{100 }{ \sqrt{3}} N\)

Vertical Component will be,

\(T_{1} \sin 30^{\circ}+100 \sin 60^{\circ}= W\)

By putting the value of \(T_{1}\) from above we get

\(\frac{100}{\sqrt{3}} \times \frac{1}{2}+100 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}= W \)

\( \therefore W =\frac{200 }{ \sqrt{3}} N\)

He then tied another string at 3 m below the roof with the previous one as shown in the figure. Find the tension T1 in the string? g =10 m/s2

Given, 

m = 10 Kg

g = 10 m/s2

First draw the free body diagram of the given figure,

Now resolve all forces into a horizontal and a vertical component.

​Horizontal Component \(= 100 \cos45^\circ =100\times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

\(= 50\sqrt{2} N\)

Vertical Component \(= 100\sin45^\circ=100\times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

\(= 50\sqrt{2} N\)

The relation between radius of curved road and banking angle is:

The phenomenon of raising the outer edge of the curved road compared to its inner edge is called banking of road.
As we know,
The velocity of the vehicle on a banked road can be expressed as,
\(v=\sqrt{rg\tan \theta}\)
\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=\frac{v^{2}}{rg}\)
\(\Rightarrow \theta \propto \frac{1 }{ r}\)
The angle of banking depends on the speed of the vehicle, the radius of the curved road and the acceleration due to gravity (g) at that place. The expression does not contain the term \(m\) representing mass, thus the angle of banking is independent of the mass (m) of the vehicle. Thus the angle of banking is the same for heavy and light vehicles. The angle of banking depends on the radius (r) of the curved road. The angle of banking is inversely proportional to the radius of curvature.
A circular road of 1000 m radius has a banking angle of 45°, the maximum safe speed of a car having a mass of 2000 kg will be (if the coefficient of friction between tyre and road is 0.5):

Given,

Radius, \(r=1000 m\)

Banking angle, \(\theta=45^{\circ}\) 

Coefficient of friction, \(\mu=0.5\)

Acceleration due to gravity, \(g=9.8 m/s^2\)

As we know,

Maximum safe velocity is calculated by,

\(v=\sqrt{\frac{r g(\tan \theta+\mu)}{1-\mu \tan \theta}} \)

\(\therefore v=\sqrt{\frac{1000 \times 9.8\left(\tan 45^{\circ}+0.5\right)}{1-0.5 \times \tan 45^{\circ}}} \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{1000 \times 9.8 (1+0.5)}{1-0.5 \times 1}}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{1000 \times 9.8 \times 1.5}{1-0.5}}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{1000 \times 9.8 \times 1.5}{0.5}}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{29400}\)

\(\therefore v =172 m / s\)

A car is moving with a constant speed of 10 ms-1 along a circular path of radius of 10 m in a horizontal plane. A plumb is suspended from the roof of the car by a light rigid rod.  The angle subtended by the rod from the path is:

Given, 

Radius \((r)=10 m\)

Velocity \((v)=10 m / s \)

\( g =10 m / s ^{2}\)

Free body diagram of the given condition,


So, \(F _{\text {net }}=0\)

\(T \sin \theta=\frac{m v^{2} }{ r} \)...(1) 

\(T \cos \theta=m g \)...(2) 

Dividing the equation (1) and (2), we get

\(\frac{T \sin \theta}{T \cos \theta}=\frac{v^{2}}{r g}\)

Substituting all the values in the above equation, we get

\(\frac{T \sin \theta}{T \cos \theta}=\frac{(10)^2}{10 \times 10} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T \sin \theta}{T \cos \theta}=\frac{100}{100} \)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=1\)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=\tan 45^\circ\)

\(\therefore \theta= 45^\circ\)

The angle subtended by the rod from the path is \(45^{\circ}\).
If a stone of mass m is rotated in a vertical circular path of radius \(1m\), the critical velocity will be: \(g=9.8 m/s ^{2}\)

The net force acting on a mass that is traveling in a vertical circle is composed of the force of gravity and the tension in the string.

\(\overrightarrow{F_{c}}=\overrightarrow{m g}+\overrightarrow{T} \)

\(\frac{\overrightarrow{m v^{2}}}{R}=\overrightarrow{m g}+\overrightarrow{T}\)

At the point, when the string losses its Tension and go slang, there should be enough gravitational force to make the body continue its motion in vertical plane. For this, the critical velocity should be maintained.

\(\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=m g \Rightarrow v ^{2}= Rg \)

\(\Rightarrow v =\sqrt{Rg}\)

Where \(R=\) radius of the circle in which the stone is moving but here it is the length of the string

Given,

\(R=1 m\), \(g=9.8 ms ^{-2}\)

\(\therefore v=\sqrt{1 \times 9.8}=3.13\)

So, the critical Velocity is \(3.13 m/s\).
The kinetic energy K of a particle moving along a circle of radius R depends on the distance covered is given as K = as2. The force acting on the particle is:

Given,

\(K = as ^{2}\)

Where \(K =\) kinetic energy, \(s =\) distance covered and \(a=\) acceleration.

Since the kinetic energy of the particle is changing, so we can say that the speed of the particle is also changing.

In a non-uniform circular motion, two forces will act on the particle \(F_{c}\) and \(F_{t}\).

Where \(F_{c}=\) centripetal force and \(F_{t}=\) tangential force.

The centripetal force acts toward the center and the tangential force acts tangentially.

So, the net force is given as,

\( F=\sqrt{F_{c}^{2}+F_{t}^{2}}\)...(1)

Centripetal force is given as,

\( F_{c}=\frac{m v^{2}}{R}\)...(2)

Where \(m=\) mass, \(R=\) radius and \(v=\) velocity

\(K = as ^{2} \)...(3) (Given)

We know that,

\( K=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)...(4)

By equation (3) and equation (4), we get

\( mv ^{2}=2 as ^{2} \)...(5)

\(\Rightarrow v=s \sqrt{\frac{2 a}{m}}\)

By equation (2) and equation (5), we get

\( F_{c}=\frac{2 a s^{2}}{R}\)...(6)

Tangential acceleration is given as,

\( a_{t}=\frac{d v}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow a_{t}=\frac{d v}{d s} \cdot \frac{d s}{d t}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{d s}{d t}\)

By equation (5),

\( a_{t}=v \sqrt{\frac{2 a}{m}} \)

\(\Rightarrow a_{t}=\frac{2 a s}{m}\)...(7)

The tangential force is given as,

\( F _{ t }= ma _{ t } \)

\(\Rightarrow F _{ t }=2 as\)...(8)

By equation (1), (6) and (8), we get

\( F=\sqrt{\left(\frac{2 a{s}^{2}}{R}\right)^{2}+(2 a s)^{2}}\)

\(\therefore F=2 a s\left[\frac{s^{2}}{R^{2}}+1\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\) or \( F=2 a s\left[1+\frac{s^{2}}{R^{2}}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\)
A book of mass 10 kg is lying at the front desk of a classroom. coefficient of static friction is 0.5. A force of 40 N is applied to the book. The book will:

Given,

Mass of the book \(( m )=10 kg\)

Coefficient of friction \(\left(\mu_{ s }\right)=0.5\)

External force applied \(( F )=\) \(50 N\)

Normal reaction force is given by,

\( N = mg \)

\(\therefore N =10 \times 9.8=98 N\)

Where \(g\) is the acceleration due to gravity.

Limiting force of friction is given by,

\( f _{ s }=\mu_{ s } N \)

\(\therefore( f_s )_{\max }=0.5 \times 98=49 N\)

As \(F<f _{ s }\), so the book will not move.
A body of mass 5 kg is placed on a rough horizontal surface. What is the maximum value of friction that can act on it? (Given μ = 0.3 and g = 10 m/s2)

Given,

Mass (m) = 5 kg

Coefficient of friction (μ) = 0.3

g = 10 m/s2

Free body diagram of the given condition,

In vertical direction forces are balanced.

∴ \(N = mg\)

The friction force is calculated by,

\(F = μ N =  μ mg\)

∴ \(F = 0.3 × 5 × 10 = 15\) N
The minimum external force needed to move a block kept on a rough surface is 250 N. Find the coefficient of friction between the surface and the block if the mass of the block is 40 kg. (g = 10 m/s2)

Given,

Applied force (F) = 250 N

Mass (m) = 40 kg

Normal (N) = mg = 40 × 10 = 400 N

Friction force (f) = μ N = 400 μ 

For moving the block, Applied (F) ≥ Friction force

250 ≥ 400 μ 

As the given force is minimum force, so

400 μ = 250

∴ Coefficient of friction (μ) = \(\frac{250}{400}\) = 0.625
An external force of 40 N is acting on a wooden block moving on a rough surface with a constant velocity of 2 m/s. Find the friction force on the block.

When the block is moving on a Rough surface Kinetic Frictional forces try to resist the movement.


Here, a block is moving with constant velocity, which means that no resultant force is acting on the block.

Thus, the frictional force is equal and opposite to the applied force and therefore 40 N force is acting on the block but in opposite direction to the external force.

Friction force = external force = 40 N

Three concurent forces F1, F2 and F3 are in equilibrium. The magnitude of the forces F1 and F2 is 3 N and 4 N respectively and both are acting perpendicular to each other. Find the magnitude of the third force.

Given,
\(F _{1}=3 N\)
\(F _{2}=4 N\)
As we know,
Three concurrent forces will be in equilibrium if the resultant of any two forces are equal and opposite to the third force.
Therefore,
\(\overrightarrow{F_{1}}+\overrightarrow{F_{2}}=-\overrightarrow{F_{3}}\)
When two forces \(F_{1}\) and \(F_{2}\) act perpendicular to each other and the resultant force is given as,
\( F=\sqrt{F_{1}^{2}+F_{2}^{2}}\)
\(\therefore  F=\sqrt{(3)^{2}+(4)^{2}} \)
\(\Rightarrow F=\sqrt{9+16} \)
\(\Rightarrow F=\sqrt{25} \)
\(\Rightarrow F =5 N\)
Therefore, the magnitude of the third force \(F _{3}\) will be \(5 N\).
If the momentum of a body is constant, then:
It may or may not be in translational equilibrium

As we know that the momentum of a body is given as,

P = m × v...(1)

Where m = mass, and v = velocity of the body

By equation (1) it is clear that if the momentum of a body is constant, then its velocity will also be constant and the acceleration will be zero.

An object is in translational equilibrium if the velocity of its translational motion is constant. To be in translational equilibrium, the net force acting on the object must be zero.

Therefore we can say that if the momentum of a body is constant, then it will be in translational equilibrium.
Mayank is doing an experiment in a lab he suspended 5 Kg mass by string making angles 60° and 30° with horizontal as shown in the figure. Find the tension T1 and T2. (Take g = 10 m/s2)

Given,

m = 5 Kg

g = 10 m/s2

First, draw the free body diagram of the given figure and resolve the horizontal and vertical component.


From the figure we get,

Horizontal component

\(T_{1} \cos 30^{\circ}=T_{2}\cos  60^{\circ} \)

\(\therefore T_{1}  \cos 30^{\circ}-T_{2} \cos 60^{\circ}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow T_{1} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-T_{2} \times \frac{1}{2}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{3}T_{1}}{2}-\frac{T_{2} }{2}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{3}T_{1}=T_{2}\)...(i)

Vertical component 

\(T_{1} \sin 30^{\circ}+T_{2}  \sin 60^{\circ}=50 N \)

\(\Rightarrow T_{1} \times \frac{1}{2} +T_{2} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=50\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T_{1}}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}T_{2} }{2}=50\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T_{1}+\sqrt{3}T_{2}}{2}=50\)

\(\Rightarrow T_{1}+\sqrt{3}T_{2} =100\)...(ii)

By solving equation (i) and (ii), we get

\( T_{1}+\sqrt{3} \times \sqrt{3}T_{1} =100\)

\(\Rightarrow T_{1}+ 3T_{1}=100 \)

\(\Rightarrow 4T_{1}=100 \)

\(\therefore T_{1}=25 N \) 

\(T_{2}=\sqrt{3}T_{1}=\sqrt{3} \times 25=25 \sqrt{3} N\)
A \(0.2 kg\) object at rest is subjected to a force \((0.3 \hat{i}-0.4 \hat{j}) N\). What is the velocity after \(6s\)?

Given,

Force \((F)=(0.3 \hat{i}-0.4 \hat{j}) N\)

Time \((t)=6 s\)

Mass \(( m )=0.2 kg\)

Initial velocity \((u)=0\)

Let the velocity of the object after \(6 s\) be \(v\).

As we know,

Force is given by,

\(F=m a\)...(1)

Where, \(m\) is the mass of the object, a is the acceleration.

Rearranging equation (1) we get,

\(a=\frac{F}{m}\)

Substituting the values in above equation we get,

\(a=\frac{(0.3 \hat{i}-0.4 \hat{j})}{0.2} \)

\(\Rightarrow a=\left(\frac{3}{2} \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}\right)\)

From equation of motion, we have

\(v=u+a t\)

Substituting the values in above equation we get,

\(v=0+\left(\frac{3}{2} \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\left(\frac{3}{2} \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}\right) \times 6 \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\left(\frac{18}{2} \hat{i}-12 \hat{j}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow v=(9 \hat{i}-12 \hat{j})\)

So, the velocity of an object after \(6 s\) is \((9 \hat{i}-12 \hat{j})\).
A gun fires a small bullet. The recoiling momentum of the gun is:
Equal and opposite to momentum of the bullet.
Equal and in same direction to momentum of the bullet.
More than momentum of bullet but in opposite to that of bullet
Less than momentum of bullet but in opposite to that of bullet

Since there is no external force in the system of the gun and the bullet, all forces are internal. So the momentum of the system will be conserved.

According to the law of conservation of momentum, the initial momentum of the system is zero (as there is no motion initial). So the final momentum of the system will also be zero.

This implies that the recoil momentum of the gun must be equal and opposite to that of the bullet (proved below).

\(P_{\text {initial }}=P_{\text {final }}\)

\(\Rightarrow 0=P_{\text {bullet }}+P_{\text {gun }}\)

\(\Rightarrow P_{\text {gun }}=-P_{\text {bullet }}\)

Here negative sign says the momentum of the gun is opposite to the momentum of the bullet, and the magnitude is the same.

So, the recoil momentum of the gun must be equal and opposite to that of the bullet.
Momentum of a system of particles is conserved if:
There is no external force acting on the system
There is a force provided to the system externally

According to the law of conservation of momentum, the total momentum of a system is conserved for an isolated system.

An isolated system means that there is no external interaction on the system. 

Thus, the momentum of a system of particles is conserved if there is no external force acting on the system.
A particle of mass 2 kg is moving with 20 m/s collides with a stationary particle of mass 3 kg. After the collision, both particles moves together. Find the loss of kinetic energy of the system.

Given,

Mass of the first particle \((m _{1})=2 kg\)

Mass of the second particle \((m _{2})=3 kg\)

Velocity of first particle \((u _{1})=20 m/s\)

Velocity of second particle \((u _{2})=0 m/s\)

Initial \(KE =\frac{1 }{ 2 }m _{1} u ^{2}{ }_{1}\)

\(=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times 2 \times (20)^{2}\)

\(=400 J\)

Let \(V\) is the final velocity of both the particle after collision.

\(P_{1}=m_{1} u_{1}+m_{2} u_{2}=2 \times 20+0=40 \)

\(P_{2}=m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}=(2+3) V=5 V \)

\(P_{1}=P_{2} \)

\(\therefore 5 V=40 \)

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{40 }{ 5}\)

\(\Rightarrow V=8 m / s\)

Final \(KE =\frac{1}{2}mV^2=\frac{1}{2}(m_1+m_2)V^2\)

\(=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times(2+3) \times 8^{2}\)

\(=160 J\)

Loss in \(KE =\) Initial \(KE -\) Final \(KE\)

\(=400-160\)

\(=240 J\)
A bomb of 12 kg divides in two parts whose ratio of masses is 1 : 3. If the kinetic energy of the smaller part is 216 J, then the momentum of the bigger part in kg-m/s will be:

After division, the mass of the bomb divides into two parts ratio of masses is 1 : 3.

So after division, the masses will be 3 kg and 9 kg and the kinetic energy of the smaller part is 216 J.

According to the law of conservation of momentum, the initial momentum of the system is zero (as there is no motion initial). So the final momentum of the system will also be zero. This implies that the momentum of the divided parts of the bomb must move in opposition to each other.

\(P_{\text {initial }}=P_{\text {final }} \)

\(\Rightarrow 0=P_{\text {big }}-P_{\text {small }} \)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}=P_{s}\)

The kinetic energy of the bigger part, \(K_{b}=\frac{P_{b}^{2}}{2 M_{b}}\)

The kinetic energy of the smaller part, \(K_{s}=\frac{P_{s}^{2}}{2 M_{s}}\)

Since, \(P _{ b }= P _{ s }\)

\(\therefore P _{ b }^{2}= P _{ s }^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}^{2}=K_{s}\left(2 M_{s}\right) \quad [\because P _{ s }^{2}=K_{s}(2 M_{s})]\)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}^{2}=216(2 \times 3) \)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}^{2}=216 \times 6 \)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}=\sqrt{1296}\) 

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}=36 \) kg-m/s

\(\therefore\) The momentum of the bigger part is \(36\) kg-m/s.
Two objects having their masses in ratio \(3: 5\) are acted upon by two forces each on one object. The forces are in the ratio of \(5: 3\). Find the ratio in their accelerations.
Suppose 2 bodies undergo collision. When do we say the momentum between them is conserved?
In the absence of an external force

The Law of conservation of momentum states that for two or more bodies in an isolated system, the total momentum remains constant before and after the collision unless an external force is applied.

For a collision occurring between object 1 and object 2 in an isolated system, the total momentum of the two objects before the collision is equal to the total momentum of the two objects after the collision. Momentum is conserved for both elastic and inelastic collision. Momentum remains conserved only when an external force is not present.
A 12 kg bomb at rest explodes into two pieces of 4 kg and 8 kg. If the momentum of 4 kg piece is 20 Na, the kinetic energy of the 8 kg piece is:

Given,

Total mass of the system (bomb) = 12 kg

Mass of first piece (m1) = 4 kg

Mass of the second piece (m2­) = 8 kg

The bomb was initially at rest.

So initial momentum of the system (P1) = 12 × 0 = 0

After the explosion, the momentum of the first piece = 20 Na

Final momentum of the system (P2) = momentum of the first piece + Momentum of the second piece

P2 = 20 + Momentum of second piece

Since there is no external force on the bomb during the explosion, so the momentum of the system before or after the explosion will remain the same.

According to law of conservation momentum,

P1 = P2

∴ 0 = 20 + Momentum of second piece

Momentum of second piece = - 20 = m2 × V

⇒ 8 × V = - 20

⇒ V = \(\frac{- 20}{8}\) = - 2.5 m/s

The negative sign shows the direction of the velocity.

Kinetic energy of second (8 kg) piece \((K E)=\frac{1}{2} m V^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 8 \times (2.5)^{2}\)

\(=4 \times 6.25\)

\( =25 J\)
A mass initially at rest exploded into two parts of 3 kg and 9 kg. If the speed of 3 kg mass is 18 m/s, find the speed of 9 kg mass.

Given that the masses will be 3 kg and 9 kg after the explosion.

Initially mass is at rest so Pinitial = 0

Now the explosion occurs due to internal forces, there is no external force involved, so momentum will be conserved.

According to the law of conservation of momentum, the initial momentum of the system is zero (as there is no motion initial). So the final momentum of the system will also be zero.

This implies that the momentum of the divided parts of the bomb must move in opposition to each other.

\(P_{\text {initial }}=P_{\text {final }}\)

\(\therefore 0=P_{b i g}+P_{\text {small }}\)

\(\Rightarrow 0=9 \times v+3 \times 18\)

\(\Rightarrow v=-6 m / s\)

Here negative sign means 9 kg mass will move opposite to the 3 kg mass.
An object of mass 5 kg is attached to the end of a rope. If the rope is pulled upward with an acceleration of 0.30 ms-2, what is the tension in the rope?

Given, 

Mass = 5kg

Acceleration of rope = 0.30 ms-2 

g = 9.8 ms-2

Free body diagram:

∵  Acceleration is upward with 0.3 ms-2

∴ T – mg = ma

⇒ T – (5 × 9.8) = 5 × 0.30

⇒ T = 50.5 N

So, the tension in the tope is 50.5 N.

A certain spacecraft is used to transport astronauts from International Space Station (ISS) to Earth. The spacecraft is designed to have three parts labelled P, Q and R each of mass 1200 kg, 3150 kg, and 2800 kg respectively. When the spacecraft is launched the exhaust system produces a force of 1430 N. Calculate the acceleration of the spacecraft as it leaves the ISS.

Let the Mass of spacecraft = Mass of (P + Q + R)

From Newton's third law of motion, when the exhaust system produces a force of 1430 N, an equal and opposite force is exerted back on the spacecraft. Let this force be F.

∴ F = 1430 N

As we know,

F = m × a 

∴ 1430 = Mass of spacecraft × a 

⇒ 1430 = (1200 + 3150 + 2800) × a

⇒ 1430 = 7150 × a

∴ a = 0.2 m/s2

So, the acceleration of the spacecraft is 0.2 m/s2.
Change in momentum is equal to the:

According to Newton's second law of motion, the force on the body is given as,

\( F=\frac{d P}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow dP = F \times dt \)...(1)

\(\therefore\) Change in momentum \(= F \times dt\)...(1)

Where \(F=\) force and \(d t=\) time

As we know, 

Momentum of a body is given as,

Momentum \(( P )=\) mass \(( m ) \times\) velocity \(( v ) \)...(2)

By equation (2) the change in momentum is given as,

Change in momentum \(=\) mass \(\times\) change in velocity...(3)

The impulse is given as,

\(I=F \times d t \)...(4)
