An object of mass \(7 kg\) is moving with a velocity given by \(v = at \hat{ i }+ bt ^{2} \hat{\jmath}\) where \(t\) is the time. Then the force acting on the object is:

Given,

Mass \(( m )=7 kg\),

Velocity \(( v )= at \hat{ i }+ bt ^{2} \hat{ j }\)

According to the Newton's second law of motion, the rate of change of momentum is directly proportional to the force applied by the moving body.

\(\frac{d p}{d t} \propto F\)

\(\therefore F=\frac{d p}{d t}=m \frac{d v}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=7 \times \frac{d(a t \hat{i}+b t^{2} \hat{j})}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=7(a \hat{i}+2 b t \hat{j}) \)

\(\Rightarrow F=7 a \hat{i}+14 b t \hat{j}\)
Ranveer pulled a table cloth from a table without dislodging the dishes. This is due to:

Newton’s first law of motion is also called the law of inertia. Inertia is the ability of a body by virtue of which it opposes a change.

According to Newton’s first law of motion, an object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.

When a body is at rest, it will remain at rest until we apply an external force to move it. This property is called inertia of rest.

When a body is in a uniform motion, it will remain in motion until we apply an external force to stop it. This property is called inertia of motion.

When Ranveer pulled a table cloth from a table, at that time the dishes were at rest. Due to the inertia of rest, the dishes remain at rest because the cloth is removed soon.
A water tank is filled with water to half its capacity. The tank is kept on a truck that is moving with a constant velocity. On sudden application of the brake, the water in the tank would:

​Inertia is the property of an object by virtue of which it opposes any event that attempts to put the object in motion or to change its velocity. Therefore, an object at rest would want to continue staying at rest and an object in motion would have a tendency to continue its motion. Greater the mass of the object more will be the tendency to resist the events. 

Newton's first law of motion states that an object at rest remains at rest, or if in motion, remains in motion at a constant velocity unless acted on by a net external force. This law is also known as the law of inertia.

As the truck is moving forward with a constant velocity, the tank along with the water is also moving under constant velocity. When a sudden brake is applied, it tends to oppose the forward motion of water in the tank. Due to the inertia of water, it would have a tendency to continue its forward motion. Therefore on sudden braking, it suddenly moves forward.
For a good refrigerant which of the following is an undesirable property when present in higher ranges?
High viscosity is obviously an undesirable property of good refrigerant as it increases the losses of energy converts the useful energy in to non-conservative frictional energy.

Heating of water under atmospheric pressure is iso baric process, since here the pressure is not varying. When a thermodynamic process occurs at constant pressure condition thus, those reactions are known to be Isobaric process.

A fixed mass of a gas is first heated isobarically to double the volume and then cooled isochorically to decrease the temperature back to the initial value. By what factor would the work done by the gas decrease, had the process been isothermal?

let initial volume, pressure and temperature of gas be \(\mathrm{P}_{0}, \mathrm{~V}_{0}\) and \(\mathrm{T}_{0}\) in first step gas undergoes in isobaric process so pressure will be constant during the process.

so Pressure \(=P_{0}\) and Volume \(=2 V_{0}\) and from \(P V=n R T\)

Temperature \(=2 \mathrm{~T}_{0}\)

In next step gas undergoes in isochoric process so volume will be constant during this process

so Volume \(=2 \mathrm{~V}_{0}\), Temperature \(=\mathrm{T}_{0}\) and from \(\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{nRT}\) 

Equation pressure will be \(=\frac{P_{0}}{2}\). Work done in isochoric process is zero.

Work done in isobaric and isochoric process is \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{nRT}_{0}\)

so if we see initial and final temperature values are same so lets consider it had been a isothermal process so \(\Delta \mathrm{W}=\mathrm{nRT}_{0} \ln \frac{\mathrm{V}_{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_{1}}=\mathrm{nRT} \mathrm{T}_{0} \ln 2\)

So work done decreases by a factor of ln2.
Which of the following does not possess the characteristics of an intensive property?

A property of a system, whose magnitude depends upon the amount of matter, is known as extensive property. Properties like mass, volume, internal energy, heat content, free energy, enthalpy, entropy, heat capacity, surface area, energy, etc. are dependent upon the mass of the system and are called extensive properties.

Intensive property: A property of a system, whose magnitude does not depend upon the amount of matter, is known as intensive property. Properties like temperature, pressure, surface tension, viscosity, specific heat, molar energy, molar entropy, density, refractive index, etc., are independent of the mass of the system and are called intensive properties.

Pressure versus temperature graph of an ideal gas is shown is the figure. Which of the following is correct?
During the process AB work done by the gas is positive
During the process CD work done by the gas is negative
During the process BC internal energy of the gas is increasing

Internal energy of an ideal gas is a function of temperature alone, and doesn't depend on any other parameters like volume, or pressure.

In process BC, the temperature increases linearly; hence the internal energy of the gas also increases.
The internal energy of an ideal gas depends upon:

Ideal gas is considered to be the hypothetical gas whose molecules occupy negligible space and have no interactions. An ideal gas is considered as a theoretical gas which is composed of many random moving particles and there are no interparticle interactions between them. An ideal gas obeys an ideal gas law. An ideal gas molecules either attract or repel to each other and they themselves take no volume.

The internal energy of the system is described as the energy contained within the system. It is the amount of energy required to create any given state, but does not contain the kinetic energy of the particles of the system in any given state. The internal energy changes in an ideal gas can be described solely by change in its kinetic energy. Kinetic energy is simply considered as the internal energy of the perfect gas and depends entirely on its pressure, volume, temperature. In an ideal gas, the intermolecular forces are assumed to be absent and all the collisions are perfectly elastic. Thus, the gas possesses only translational kinetic energy and hence the internal energy of the ideal gas depends only on the temperature.

Van Laar equation deals with the activity coefficients in _____________.

Van Laar equation deals with the activity coefficients in binary solutions.

\(\ln \gamma_{1}=\frac{A X_{2}^{2}}{\left(\frac{A X_{1}}{B}+X_{2}\right)^{2}}\)

The first law of thermodynamics is nothing but the law of conservation of ________.

The first law of thermodynamics is nothing but the law of conservation of energy.

According to first law \(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\) that is, heat supplied to a system is equal to the amount of work done by the system plus the increase in it's internal energy.

So, it's basically the same as the law of conservation of energy.
Which of the following property is not a thermodynamic property of the system?

A thermodynamic property is that, which is measurable and whose value describes the state of system. Out of the given quantities, heat doesn't describe the state of a system so it is not a thermodynamic property because a system doesn't contain heat but only can transfer heat.
All gases except __________ shows a cooling effect during throttling process at atmospheric temperature and pressure.

All the gases except \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{He}\) etc, have maximum inversion point greater than atmospheric (room) temperature cooling can take place by throttling if the initial conditions lie in a region where joule thomson coefficient is positive. But for \(\mathrm{H}_{2}\) the maximum inversion point is very low so usually heating takes place by throttling. But if we do the decrease the temperature of \(H_{2}\) from room temperature to below the maximum inversion point temperature by some primary cooling techniques than there are chances where cooling of \(H_{2}\) gas can be done by throttling.

A heat pump is a mechanical device that transfers heat from one environmental compartment to another, typically against a temperature gradient (i.e. from cool to hot).

Two identical capacitors, having plate separation d0, are connected parallel to each other across a point 'A' as shown in the figure. If the first plate of the first capacitor and the second plate of the second capacitor started moving with constant velocity u0 towards the left, then find the magnitude of current flowing in the loop.

The each plate of a capacitor has equal and opposite charge .

Potential across top capacitor is  \(\mathrm{V}_{1}=\mathrm{E}_{1}\left(\mathrm{~d}_{0}+\mathrm{x}\right)=\frac{(\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{2}-\mathrm{q})\left(\mathrm{d}_{0}+\mathrm{x}\right)}{\mathrm{A} \epsilon_{0}}\)

and potential across bottom capacitor is \(V_{2}=E_{2}\left(d_{0}-x\right)=\frac{(\frac{Q}{2}+q)\left(d_{0}-x\right)}{A e_{0}}\)

As the battery is removed, so \(V_{1}-V_{2}=0\)

or \(\frac{(\frac{Q}{2}-q)\left(d_{0}+x\right)}{A \epsilon_{0}}=\frac{(\frac{Q}{2}+q)\left(d_{0}-x\right)}{A \epsilon_{0}}\)

or \(\frac{\mathrm{Qd} \mathrm{d}_{0}}{2}-\mathrm{qd}_{0}+\frac{\mathrm{Qx}}{2}-\mathrm{qx}=\frac{\mathrm{Qd} \mathrm{d}_{0}}{2}+\mathrm{qd} \mathrm{d}_{0}-\frac{\mathrm{Qx}}{2}-\mathrm{qx}\)

or \(2 \mathrm{qd}_{0}=\mathrm{Qx} \Rightarrow \mathrm{q}=\frac{\mathrm{Qx}}{2 \mathrm{~d}_{0}}\)

Current \(\mathrm{i}=\frac{\mathrm{dq}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{\mathrm{Q}}{2 \mathrm{~d}_{0}} \frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\frac{\mathrm{Qv}_{0}}{2 \mathrm{~d}_{0}}\)

A parallel plate capacitor of capacitance 5μF and plate separation 6 cm is connected to a 1 V battery and charged. A dielectric of dielectric constant 4 and thickness 4 cm is introduced between the plates of the capacitor. The additional charge that flows into the capacitor from the battery is:

Charge on capacitor plates without the dielectric is

\(=\mathrm{CV}=\left(5 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~F}\right) \times 1 \mathrm{~V}=5 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{C}=5 \mu \mathrm{C}\)

The capacitance after the dielectric is introduced is

\(\mathrm{C}^{\prime}=\frac{\varepsilon_{0} \mathrm{~A}}{\mathrm{~d}-\left(\mathrm{t}-\frac{\mathrm{t}}{\mathrm{K}}\right)}=\frac{\frac{\varepsilon_{0} \mathrm{~A}}{\mathrm{d}}}{1-\left(\frac{\mathrm{t}-\frac{\mathrm{t}}{\mathrm{K}}}{\mathrm{d}}\right)}=\frac{\mathrm{C}}{1-\left(\frac{\mathrm{t}-\frac{\mathrm{t}}{\mathrm{K}}}{\mathrm{d}}\right)}=\frac{5 \mu \mathrm{F}}{1-\left(\frac{4 \mathrm{~cm}-\frac{4 \mathrm{~cm}}{4}}{6 \mathrm{~cm}}\right)}=\)

\(\frac{5 \mu \mathrm{F}}{1-\left(\frac{4-1}{6}\right)}=10 \mu \mathrm{F}\)

\(\therefore\) Charge on capacitor plate now will be

\(Q^{\prime}=\mathrm{C} ' \mathrm{~V}=10 \mu \mathrm{F} \times 1 \mathrm{~V}=10 \mu \mathrm{C}\)

Additional charge transferred \(=Q^{\prime}-Q=10 \mu \mathrm{C}-5 \mu \mathrm{C}=5 \mu \mathrm{C}\)

A body of capacity \(4 \mu \mathrm{F}\) is charged to \(80 \mathrm{~V}\) and an other body of capacity \(6 \mu \mathrm{F}\) is charged to \(30 \mathrm{~V}\). When they are connected the energy lost by \(4 \mu \mathrm{F}\) capacitor is:

Initial energy of body of capacitance \(4 \mu \mathrm{F}\) is \(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{i}}=\frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 10^{-6} \times 80^{2}=0.0128 \mathrm{~J}\)

Final potential on this body after connection is

\(\mathrm{V}=\frac{4 \times 80+6 \times 30}{4+6}=50 \mathrm{~V}\)

so final energy on it,

\(\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{f}}=1 / 2 \times 4 \times 10^{-6} \times 50^{2}=0.005 \mathrm{~J}\) Energy lost by this body \(=\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{i}}-\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{f}}=7.8 \mathrm{~mJ}\)

According to Coulomb's law

The energy stored in a parallel plate capacitor is \(\mathrm{E}\) and the potential difference between the plates is \(\mathrm{V}\), then the \(\mathrm{E}\) is related to \(\mathrm{V}\) as:

Where \(\mathrm{C}=\) capacitance of the capacitor, and \(\mathrm{V}=\) potential difference between the plates

\(\because \mathrm{U}=\mathrm{E}\)

A \(600 \mathrm{pF}\) capacitor is charged by \(100 \mathrm{~V}\) battery, then the electrostatic energy stored in the capacitor is:

Given,

\(C=600 \mathrm{pF}=600 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~F}\), and \(V=100\) volts

We know that the energy stored in the capacitor is given as,

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} C V^{2} \quad \cdots \text { (1) }\)

By equation 1 the energy stored in the capacitor is given as,

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} \times 600 \times 10^{-12} \times 100^{2}\)

The radius of the circular plates of a parallel plate capacitor is \(8 \mathrm{~cm}\) and the distance between the plates is 4 mm. When it is charged with a battery of 100 volts, the energy stored in the capacitor will be:

Given,

\(R=8 \mathrm{~cm}=8 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}, d=4 \mathrm{~mm}=4 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}\), and \(V=100\) volts

We know that the energy stored in a parallel plate capacitor is given as,

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} C V^{2} \quad-(1)\)

We know that the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor is given as,

\(\Rightarrow C=\frac{A \epsilon_{o}}{d} \quad \cdots(2)\)

Where \(\mathrm{A}=\) area of the plates, \(\mathrm{d}=\) distance between the plates, \(\mathrm{C}=\) capacitance of the capacitor, and \(\mathrm{V}=\) potential difference between the plates

By equation 1 and equation 2,

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{A \epsilon_{o}}{d} \times V^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\pi R^{2} \epsilon_{o}}{d} \times V^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\pi\left(8 \times 10^{-2}\right)^{2} \epsilon_{o}}{4 \times 10^{-3}} \times 100^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{8 \pi \epsilon_{o}}{10^{-3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{U}=8 \pi \epsilon_{0} \times 10^{3}\)

We know that,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{o}}=9 \times 10^{9} N-m^{2} / C^{2}\)

By equation 3 and equation 4,

\(\Rightarrow U=2 \times 4 \pi \epsilon_{0} \times 10^{3}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{2 \times 10^{3}}{9 \times 10^{9}}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{2}{9} \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~J}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=0.22 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~J}\)

The relative permeability of iron is of the order of:

Ferromagnetic Substances: The substances which are strongly magnetized when placed in an external magnetic field in the same direction to the applied field are called ferromagnetic substances.

Example: Iron, nickel, cobalt

Properties:

  • These are characterized by parallel alignment of magnetic dipoles
  • These substances are strongly attracted by a magnet
  • It develops strong magnetization in the direction of the applied magnetic field
  • By removing magnetizing filed, it does not lose its magnetization
  • When placed in a non-uniform magnetic field, it tends to move from weaker to stronger regions of the magnetic field
  • When placed in a uniform magnetic field, it aligns itself parallel to the direction of the magnetic field
  • Magnetic susceptibility is much greater than 1
  • Relative permeability is much greater than 1
  • Magnetic permeability is much larger compared to free space

The relative permeability of a substance X is slightly less than unity and that of substance Y is slightly more than unity, then:

Permeability is the measure of the ability of a material to support the formation of a magnetic field within itself. In other words, it is the degree of magnetization.

Relative permeability \((\mu)\) is the ratio of the permeability of a specific medium to the permeability of free space \(\left(\mu_{0}\right)\)

Diamagnetism is the property of an object which causes it to create a magnetic field in opposition of an externally applied magnetic field, thus causing a repulsive effect. Specifically, an external magnetic field alters the orbital velocity of electrons around their nuclei, thus changing the magnetic dipole moment in the direction opposing the external field. Diamagnets are materials with a magnetic permeability less than \(\mu_{0}\) (a relative permeability \(<1\) ) Paramagnetism is a form of magnetism which occurs only in the presence of an externally applied magnetic field. Paramagnetic materials are attracted to magnetic fields, hence have a relative magnetic permeability greater than one.

In a plane perpendicular to the magnetic meridian the dip needle will remain :

Earths magnetic South Pole is towards the earths North Pole, and magnetic North Pole is towards the geometrical South Pole. A magnetic needle is placed in the horizontal plane. It would align itself in the magnetic North-South (along the magnetic meridian).

There would be two vertical planes: One would pass through the magnetic meridian, and the other would be perpendicular to it. If the needle is placed in the vertical plane that passes through the magnetic meridian (at the equator) then the needle would show horizontal direction. If the needle is placed in horizontal plane at equator, then it would once again show horizontal direction. This is because there is only horizontal field there.If the needle is placed in the vertical plane (passing through magnetic meridian) at any point other than the equator and the poles, it would align in the direction of the resultant magnetic field.

Angle of dip would change if the needle is placed in geometric meridian. The vertical component would remain the same, but the horizontal component would change.

Hence, in a plane perpendicular to the magnetic meridian the dip needle will remain vertical.

\(\mu=\mu_{0}\left(1+\gamma_{m}\right)\)

For the angles of projection of a projectile as (\(45^{\circ}-\theta\)) and (\(40^{\circ}+\theta\)) the horizontal ranges described by the projectile are in the ratio:

Let u be the initial velocity of the projectile. Range of a projectile is given by:

Step 2: Ratio of \(R_{1} \& R_{2}\)

At \(\theta_{1}=45^{\circ}-\theta, \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{R}_{1}\)

\(\mathrm{R}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2} \sin 2\left(45^{\circ}-\theta\right)}{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2} \sin \left(90^{\circ}-2 \theta\right)}{\mathrm{g}}\)

At \(\theta_{2}=45^{\circ}+\theta, \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{R}_{2}\)

\(\mathrm{R}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2} \sin 2\left(45^{\circ}+\theta\right)}{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2} \sin \left(90^{\circ}+2 \theta\right)}{\mathrm{g}}\)

The ratio of \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) is given by

\(\frac{\mathrm{R}_{1}}{\mathrm{R}_{2}}=\frac{\sin \left(90^{\circ}-2 \theta\right)}{\sin \left(90^{\circ}+2 \theta\right)}=\frac{\cos 2 \theta}{\cos 2 \theta}=1\)

The friction of air causes a vertical retardation equal to the 10% of the acceleration due to gravity. The maximum height will be decreased by (take g = 10 ms-2):

Given,

Retardation \(=10 \%\)

If there is no friction then,

By the equation of the motion,

\(\mathrm{v}^{2}=\mathrm{u}^{2}+2 \mathrm{gh}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=0\)

\(\mathrm{h}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~g}}\)

Now,

When there is air resistance \(10 \%\) of the gravity.

\(g_{\text {eff }}=g+0.1 g=1.1 g\)

The maximum height will be,

\(\mathrm{h}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~g}_{\mathrm{ef}}}\)

Therefore, the difference is \(\mathrm{h}_{1}-\mathrm{h}\)

\(\mathrm{u}^{2} 2 \mathrm{~g}_{\mathrm{ef}}-\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~g}}\)

So,

Change in height is:

\(\frac{u^{2}}{2 g}-\frac{u^{2}}{2 g_{e f}}\)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~g}}-\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~g}}\left(1-\frac{11}{10}\right)\)

Thus the percentage change in height is:

\(=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~g}}\left(1-\frac{11}{10}\right)}{\frac{\mathrm{u}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~g}}} \times 100\)

\(=\frac{100}{11} \approx 9 \%\)
A projectile can have the same range \(R\) for two angles of projection. if \(t_{1} \& t_{2}\) be the times of flight in the two cases then what is the product of the two times of flight?

If \(R\) is the range of a projectile thrown at an angle of \(\theta\), then the range of a projectile thrown at an angle of \(90^{\circ}-\theta\) is also \(r\).

We know that,

\(t_{1}=\frac{2 u \sin \theta}{g}\) and

\(t_{2}=\frac{2 u \sin \left(90^{\circ}-\theta\right)}{g}=\frac{2 u \cos \theta}{g}\)

We also know that,

\(R=\frac{u^{2} \sin (2 \theta)}{g}\)

Where, \(u\) is the initial velocity of the projectile and \(g\) is the acceleration due to gravity.

Step 2: Calculate the product of the two times of flight

Multiplying \(t_{1}\) and \(t_{2}\),

\(t_{1} \cdot t_{2} =\frac{2 u \sin \theta}{g} \cdot \frac{2 u \cos \theta}{g}\)

\(=\frac{4 u^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta}{g^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{2\left[\frac{u^{2} \sin (2 \theta)}{g}\right]}{g} \)

\(\therefore t_{1} \cdot t_{2} =\frac{2 R}{g}\)

Therefore, the product of the two time of flights \(t_{1}\) and \(t_{2}\) is \(\frac{2 R}{g}\).

Velocity at point \(B=V_{B}=u-g(T-t)\)

\(=u-g\left(\frac{u}{g}-t\right)=g t\)

\(\Rightarrow {h}={V}_{{B}} {t}-\frac{1}{2} {gt}^{2}\)

\( \Rightarrow {h}={gt}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} {gt}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} {gt}^{2}\)
If \(\vec{A}\) and \(\vec{B}\) are non-zero vectors which obey the relation \(|\vec{A}-\vec{B}|=|\vec{A}+\vec{B}|\), then the angle between them is:

Let the two vectors be A and \(B\) then dot Product of two vectors:

\(\mathrm{A} \cdot \mathrm{B}=|\mathrm{A}||\mathrm{B}| \cos \theta\)

Let the two vectors be \(A\) and \(B\) then cross Product of two vectors:

\(\mathrm{A} \times \mathrm{B}=|\mathrm{A}||\mathrm{B}| \sin \theta\)

Where \(|A|=\) Magnitude of vectors \(A\) and \(|B|=\) Magnitude of vectors \(B\) and \(\theta\) is the angle between \(A\) and \(B\).

\(|\vec{A}+\vec{B}|=|\vec{A}-\vec{B}|\)

\(|\vec{A}|^{2}+|\vec{B}|^{2}+2|\vec{A}||\vec{B}| \cos \theta=|\vec{A}|^{2}+|\vec{B}|^{2}-2|\vec{A}||\vec{B}| \cos \theta\)

\(\therefore \cos \theta=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=90^{\circ}\)
If \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}=-\hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-3 \hat{k}\) and \(\vec{B}=4 \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}+6 \hat{k}\), then the angle made by \((\vec{A}+\vec{B})\) with \(x\)-axis is:

The angle made by the given vector will be \({4 5}^\circ\)

Given vector \(A=i+j\)

From a general form of vector written as vector \(V=x i+y j\), when the given vector \(A=i+j\) is compared,

We get,

\(x=1\)

and

\(y=1\)

And we know,

\(\tan \theta=\frac{y}{x}\)

Where \(\theta\) is the angle made by the vector with \(x\) axis.

\(\tan \theta=\frac{1}{1}\)

\(\tan \theta=1\)

\(\tan \theta=\tan 45^{\circ}\)

\(\theta=45^{\circ}\)

So, the angle \((\theta)\) made by the vector \(A=i+j\) with the x-axis is \(45^{\circ}\).

Set of elements (vectors) in a vector space is called a basis, or a set of basis vectors, if the vectors are linearly independent and every vector in the vector space is a linear combination of this set.In more general terms, a basis is a linearly independent spanning set.

Given a basis of a vector space, every element of vector space can be expressed uniquely as a linear combination of basis vectors, whose coefficients are referred to as vector coordinates or components.

A unit vector in a normed vector space is a vector (often a spatial vector) of length 1 . A unit vector is often denoted by a lowercase letter with a circumflex, or "hat": \(\hat{i} \hat{i}\) (pronounced "i-hat"). The term direction vector is used to describe a unit vector being used to represent spatial direction.

The plate separation in a parallel plate condenser is \(\mathrm{d}\) and plate area is \(\mathrm{A}\). If it is charged to \(\mathrm{V}\) volts and a battery is disconnected then work done in increasing the plate separation to \(2 \mathrm{~d}\) will be:

Workdone \(=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{~V}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{C}_{1} \mathrm{~V}^{2}\)

As dincreases, capacitance change

\(\mathrm{W}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{C}_{2}-\mathrm{C}_{1}\right) \mathrm{V}^{2}\)

Four metallic plates are arranged as shown in the figure. If d is the distance between each plate then capacitance of the given system between points A and B is: (given d<<A).

We know from the question that the distance between each plate is \(d\) and the area of the plate of capacitor is \(A\).

The capacitance of the given system between points \((A)\) and \((B)\) is,

\(C=C_{1}+C_{2}\).....(1)

We know that the expression of the capacitance of parallel plate capacitance is,

\(C=\frac{\varepsilon_{0} A}{d}\)

Here, \(\varepsilon_{0}\) is the absolute permittivity.

We know that the distance between each plate is and their area is also the same. So the capacitance of both capacitance will be the same.

\(C_{1}=C_{2}=\frac{\varepsilon_{0} A}{d}\)

Substitute the above expression in equation (1), we have,

\(C=\frac{\varepsilon_{0} A}{d}+\frac{\varepsilon_{0} A}{d}\)

\(=\frac{2 \varepsilon_{0} A}{d}\)

Two long parallel conductors are placed \(10 {~mm}\) apart from each other carrying a current of 150 Amperes. What will be the force per meter length of each one?

We know the force per unit length between the two conductors is,

\(\frac{F}{l}=\frac{\mu_{0} I_{1} I_{2}}{2 \pi d}\)

Here \(d=\) distance \(=10 \times 10^{-3}\) meter

\(\mu_{0}=4 \pi \times 10^{-7} {~F} / {m}\)

And currents \(I_{1}=I_{2}=150\) Ampere

\(\therefore \frac{F}{l}=\frac{4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \times 150 \times 150}{2 \pi \times 10 \times 10^{-3}}=0.45 {~N} / {m}\)

Therefore, the force per meter length of each one is \(0.45 {~N}\).
The electric potential due to an extremely short dipole at a distance r from it is proportional to :

Potential at point \(P=\frac{K V}{r_{1}}-\frac{K V}{r_{2}}\)

\(\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{KV}\left(\frac{\mathrm{r}_{2}-\mathrm{r}_{1}}{\mathrm{r}_{1} \mathrm{I}_{2}}\right)\)

we are taking extremely short dipole \(\mathrm{r}_{1} \cong \mathrm{r}_{2}=\mathrm{r}\)

\(\mathrm{r}_{2}-\mathrm{r}_{1} \cong \mathrm{d} \cos \theta\)

\(\mathrm{V}=\frac{\mathrm{KV} \mathrm{d} \cos \text { theta }}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}\)

\(\mathrm{~V}=\frac{\mathrm{KP} \cos \text { theta }}{\mathrm{r}^{2}} \mathrm{P}=\mathrm{V}\text { d, where } \mathrm{P} \text { is the dipole moment. }\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{V} \propto \frac{1}{\mathrm{r}^{2}}\)
A soap bubble of radius \(r\) is charged to a potential \(V\). If the radius is increased to \(n r,\) the potential on the bubble will become:

If the radius of a bubble is increased by a factor \(n\), its capacitance is also increased by a factor \(n\), i.e. \(C^{\prime}=n C\). Since the charge \(Q\) on the bubble remains unchaged, we have

\(Q=C V=C^{\prime} V^{\prime} \)

\(V^{\prime}=\frac{C V}{C^{\prime}}\)

\(=\frac{C V}{n C}\)

\(=\frac{V}{n}\)

Force of attraction between the plates of a parallel plate capacitor is :

The electric field between the two plates \(=\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_{0}}\)

Surface charge density, \(\sigma=\frac{\mathrm{q}}{\mathrm{A}}\)

Find force through electric field as

Two positive point charges are of 12C and 8C are 10cm apart from each other. The work done in bringing them 4cm closer is:

Given two charges \(q_{1}=12 \mu \mathrm{C}, \mathrm{q}_{2}=8 \mu \mathrm{C}\) are at distance ' \(\mathrm{d}_{1}\) ' \(=10 \mathrm{~cm}\)

We have to find the work done in bringing them \(\mathrm{d}_{2}=4 \mathrm{~cm}\) closer.

For this, we find the charge in the potential energy of the system and then take the difference.

Now \(\mathrm{d}_{1}=10 \mathrm{~cm}=10 \times 10^{-2}=10^{-1} \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\mathrm{d}_{2}=4 \mathrm{~cm}=4 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}\)

So, potential \(\left(\mathrm{V}_{1}\right)\) when \(\mathrm{q}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{q}_{2}\) are distance \(\mathrm{d}_{1}\) apart,

\(\mathrm{V}_{1}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{\mathrm{q}_{1} \mathrm{q}_{2}}{\mathrm{~d}_{1}}\)

Potential \(\left(\mathrm{V}_{2}\right)\) when \(\mathrm{q}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{q}_{2}\) are distance \(\mathrm{d}_{2}\) apart,

\(\mathrm{V}_{2}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{\mathrm{q}_{1} \mathrm{q}_{2}}{\mathrm{~d}_{2}}\)

Work done \(=V_{2}-V_{1}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} q_{1} q_{2}\left(\frac{1}{d_{2}}-\frac{1}{d_{1}}\right)\)

\(=9 \times 10^{9} \times 12 \times 8 \times 10^{-12}\left(\frac{1}{4 \times 10^{-2}}-\frac{1}{10 \times 10^{-2}}\right)\)

\(=864 \times 10^{-3}\left[\frac{6 \times 10^{2}}{40 \times 10^{-2}}\right]\)

\(=129.6 \times 10^{1}\)

\(=12.96 \approx 13\) Joules

If \(10^{9}\) electron move out of a body to another body every second, how much time is required to get a total charge of \(1 \mathrm{C}\) on the other body?

Given,

\(10^{9}\) electron takes \(1 \mathrm{sec}\)

So, 1 electron takes \(\rightarrow \frac{1}{10^{9}} \mathrm{sec}\)

And we know, \(1 \mathrm{C}=6.242 \times 10^{18}\) electron

\(\therefore 6.242 \times 10^{18}\) electrons takes \(\rightarrow \frac{6.242 \times 10^{18}}{10^{9}}\) \(=6.242 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{sec}\)

\(=\frac{6.242 \times 10^{9}}{60 \times 60 \times 24 \times 365} \mathrm{years}\)

\(=197.93\) years

\(\simeq 198\) years

If \(10^{9}\) electrons move out of a body to another body every second, then 198 years is required to get a total charge of \(1 \mathrm{C}\) on the other body.
is a property of particles such as atoms, ions, electrons etc

“Electric Charge is the property of subatomic particles that causes it to experience a force when placed in an electric and magnetic field.”

Electric charges are of two types: Positive and Negative, commonly carried by charge carriers protons and electrons.

Examples of the types of charges are subatomic particles or the particles of matter:

  • Protons are positively charged.
  • Electrons are negatively charged.
  • Neutrons have zero charge.

Two types

  • Positivecharge—deficiency of electrons i.e. if a body loses electrons it will be positive charged.
  • Negative charge—excess of electrons i.e. if a body gains electrons it will be negative charged.
Conservation of charges in tribo electric charging
implies half are positively charged and other half are neutral
implies one is positively charged and the other is negatively charged.

The triboelectric effect (also known as triboelectric charging) is a type of contact electrification in which certain materials become electrically charged after they come into frictional contact with a different material. Rubbing glass with fur, or a plastic comb through the hair, can build up triboelectricity.

When we charge something with static electricity, no electrons are made or destroyed. No new protons appear or disappear. Electrons are just moved from one place to another. The net, or total, electric charge stays the same. This is called the principle of conservation of charge.

If a glass rod is rubbed with silk, some electrons moves from glass rod to silk no new charge is generated or destroyed.
