If a small value of capacitance is connected in parallel with a large value, the combined capacitance will be:

Let \(C_{1}\) be the lower value capacitance and \(C_{2}\) be the higher value capacitance

If \(\mathrm{C}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{C}_{2}\) are connected in parallel then

Net capacitance \(\left(\mathrm{C}_{p}\right)=\mathrm{C}_{1}+\mathrm{C}_{2}\)

Net capacitance \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}>\mathrm{C}_{2}\)

Therefore, If a small value of capacitance is connected in parallel with a large value, the combined capacitance will be higher than the large value capacitor.
A capacitor that stores energy of \(0.5 \mathrm{~J}\), and has capacitance of \(1 \mu \mathrm{F}\), has potential difference of across it.
A spherical drop of capacitance \(1 \mu \mathrm{F}\) is broken into eight drops of equal radius. Then, the capacitance of each small drop is:

Let \(r=\) radius after splitting, \(R=\) Radius before splitting

The potential on a charged sphere is given by

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{K Q}{R}\)

The above of the equation can be rewritten as

\(\Rightarrow \frac{Q}{V}=\frac{R}{K}\)

We know \(C=\frac{Q}{V}\), then the above equation can be written as

\(\Rightarrow C=\frac{R}{K}\)

As it is given that, \(\mathrm{C}=1 \mu \mathrm{F}\), then

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R}{K}=1 \mu F\)

After splitting,

\(\Rightarrow 8 \times\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}\right)=\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\)

\Rightarrow r=\frac{R}{2}\)

The potential of the smallest drop is given by

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{r}{K}\)

Substituting the value of \(r\) in the above equation

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{R}{2 K}\)

The substituting the value of \(\frac{R}{K}=1 \mu F\) in the above equation \(\Rightarrow V=\frac{1}{2} \mu F\)

There is a simple pendulum hanging from the ceiling of a lift. When the lift is standstill, the time period of the pendulum is \(T\). If the resultant acceleration becomes \(\frac{g }{ 4}\), then the new time period of the pendulum is:

We know that:

Time period of a simple pendulum of length \(l\), is given by:

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}} \ldots(\mathrm{i})\)

Where, \(g\) is acceleration due to gravity.

When \(g^{\prime}=\frac{g}{4}\)

New, time period is

\(T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{\frac{g}{ 4}}} \ldots(\mathrm{ii})\)

Dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get

\(\frac{T^{\prime}}{T}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\frac{g}{ 4}}}=2\)

\(\Rightarrow T^{\prime}=2 T\)

Therefore, new time period becomes twice of the original value.

Two waves represented by \(\mathrm{y}_{1}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t})\) and \(\mathrm{y}_{2}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t}+\pi / 2)\) are superimposed at any point at a particular instant. The resultant amplitude is:

Given:

\(\mathrm{y}_{1}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t})\).....(1)

\(\mathrm{y}_{2}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t+\frac{\pi}{2}})\).....(2)

\(\mathrm{y}=a \sin((\omega t+ \phi)\).....(3)

On comparing (1) and (2) with (3).

\(\mathrm{a}_{1}=10, \mathrm{a}_{2}=10\) and \(\phi= \frac{\pi}{2}=90^{\circ}\)

The resultant amplitude A of two waves of amplitudes \(a_{1}\) and \(a_{2}\) at a phase difference of \(\phi\) is:

\(A=\left(a_{1}^{2}+\right.\) \(\left.\mathrm{a}_{2}^{2}+2 \mathrm{a}_{1} \mathrm{a}_{2} \cos \phi\right)^{\frac{1 }{ 2}}\).....(4)

Substituting all given value in (4).

\(A=\left(10^{2}+\right.\) \(\left.10^{2}+2 ×10 × 10 \cos 90^{\circ}\right)^{\frac{1 }{ 2}}\)

\(=10\sqrt{2}\)

\(=14.1\)

A piece of wood has dimensions \(a, b\) \(c\) Its relative density is \(d\). It is floating in water such that the side \(c\) is vertical. It is now pushed down gently and released. The time period is:

We know that:

Time period of SHM of small vertical oscillations in a liquid is given by:

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\), where \(l\) is the length of cube/cylinder dipped in the water.

So according to law of floatation,

weight of the cube \(=\) weight of the water displaced

\(a b c \times d \times g=b c l \times l \times g\)

\(\Rightarrow l=d a\)

\(\Rightarrow T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{d a}{g}}\)
A particle starts S.H.M. from the mean position. Its amplitude is \(A\) and time period is \(T\). At the time when its speed is half of the maximum speed, its displacement \(y\) is:

The relation between angular frequency and displacement is given as

\(\mathrm{v}=\omega \sqrt{\mathrm{A}^{2}-\mathrm{x}^{2}}\).....(1)

Suppose

\(\mathrm{x}=\mathrm{A} \sin \omega \mathrm{t}\)

On differentiating the above equation w.r.t. time we get

\(\frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\mathrm{A} \omega \cos \omega \mathrm{t}\)

The maximum value of velocity will be \(v_{\max}=A \omega\)

The displacement for the time when speed is half the maximum is given as

\(\mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{A} \omega}{2} \)

\(\mathrm{~A}^{2} \omega^{2}=4 \omega\left(\mathrm{A}^{2}-\mathrm{x}^{2}\right)\)

By substituting the value in \((1)\) we get the displacement as:

\(\mathrm{x}=\frac{\mathrm{A} \sqrt{3}}{2}\)

Two particles execute SHM of the same amplitude and frequency along the same straight line. If they pass one another when going in opposite directions, each time their displacement is half their amplitude, the phase difference between them is:

We know that:The equation for SHM is:

\(\mathrm{y}=\operatorname{Asin}(\omega+\phi)\)

As the displacement is half of the amplitudes so:\(\left(\mathrm{y}=\frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}\right)\)

or \(\frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}=\mathrm{A} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t}+\)\(\phi) \)

\((\omega t+\phi)=\frac{1}{2} \)

\(\therefore \omega \mathrm{t}+\phi=30^{\circ} \text { or } 150^{\circ}\)

Since the two particles are going in opposite directions, the phase of one is \(30^{\circ}\) and that of the other \(150^{\circ} .\)

So the phase difference between the two particles:

\(=150^{\circ}-30^{\circ}\)

\(=120^{\circ}\)

\(=\frac{2 \pi}{3}\)

A simple pendulum has a length \(l\) and the mass of the bob is \(m\). The bob is given a charge \(q\) coulomb. The pendulum is suspended between the vertical plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor. If \(E\) is the electric field strength between the plates, the time period of the pendulum is given by

Time period of simple pendulum in air

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\)

 

When it is suspended between vertical plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, then acceleration due to electric field,

\(a=\frac{q E}{m}\)

This acceleration is acting horizontally and acceleration due to gravity is acting vertically. So, effective acceleration

\(g^{\prime}=\sqrt{g^{2}+a^{2}}\)

\(=\sqrt{g^{2}+\left(\frac{q E}{m}\right)^{2}}\)

Thus, \(T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{\sqrt{g^{2}+\left(\frac{q E}{m}\right)^{2}}}}\)

The time period of a simple pendulum is \(T\). When the length is increased by \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\), its period is \(T_{1}\). When the length is decreased by \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\), its period is \(T_{2}\). Then, relation between \(\mathrm{T}, \mathrm{T}_{1}\) and \( \mathrm{~T}_{2}\) is:

We know that:

When the time period of a simple pendulum is \(T\).

\(T^{2}=4 \pi^{2}\left(\frac{l}{g}\right) \ldots(i)\)

When the length is increased by \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\)

\(T_{1}^{2}=4 \pi^{2}\left(\frac{l+10}{g}\right) \ldots(ii)\)

When the length is decreased by \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\)

\(T_{2}^{2}=4 \pi^{2}\left(\frac{l-10}{g}\right) \ldots(iii)\)

Adding Eqs. (ii) and (iii), we get

\(T_{1}^{2}+T_{2}^{2}=4 \pi^{2}\left[\frac{2 l}{g}\right] \)

\( 2\left(4 \pi^{2}\right)\left(\frac{l}{g}\right)=2 T^{2}\)

So the correct answer is \(2 T^{2}=T_{1}^{2}+T_{2}^{2}\)

A clock that keeps correct time at \(25^{\circ} C\) has a pendulum made of metal. The temperature falls to \(0^{\circ} C .\) If the coefficient of linear expansion of the metal is \(1.9 \times 10^{-5}\) per \(^{\circ} C\), then find the number of seconds the clock gains per day.

Given that a clock keeps correct time at \(25^{\circ} C\). So initial temperature \(\theta_{1}=25^{\circ} C\).

The pendulum is made of metal. We need to find the number of seconds gained per day by the clock when the temperature falls to \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

So final temperature \(\theta_{2}=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

So, \(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}=25-0=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

The relation connecting gain or loss in time and the change in temperature is given as:

\(\Delta t=\frac{1}{2} \times \alpha \times \Delta \theta \times t\).....(1)

Where \(\Delta t\) is the gain or loss in time.

\(\alpha\) is the coefficient of linear expansion.

\(\Delta \theta\) is the change in temperature and \(\mathrm{t}\) is the time.

\(\alpha\) is given as \(1.9 \times 10^{-5}\) per \({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

We need to calculate the gain of time per day.

Thus \(t=24 \times 60 \times 60 \mathrm{~s}\)

Change in temperature is \(\Delta \theta=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

Now substitute all the given values in the equation (1).

\(\Delta t=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \cdot 9 \times 10^{-5} \times 25 \times 24 \times 60 \times 60 \)

\(\therefore \Delta t=20.520\) seconds / day
A girl swings on cradle in a sitting position. If she stands what happens to the time period of girl and cradle?

A girl swings on the cradle in a sitting position. If she stands then the time period of girl and cradle will decrease.

The time period, \(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\) where \({l}\) is the length of simple pendulum. On standing the effective length of the pendulum measured from the point of suspension decreases. So, the time period of the cradle decreases.

A simple spring has length \(l\) and force constant \(k\). It is cut into two spring of length \(l_{1}\) and \( l_{2}\) such that \(l_{1=} n l_{2}[n\) is an integer\(]\) the force constant of the spring of length \(l_{2}\) is:

It is given that spring has a length of \(l\).

The force constant of the spring is \(k\).

Then the spring is cut into two springs of length \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\)

Relationship between \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) is given as

\(l_{1}=n l_{2}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{n}\) is an integer.

We need to find the force constant of the spring of length \(l_{1}\)

We know that the length of a spring and force constant are inversely related.

So, we can write it as

\(l \propto \frac{1}{k} \)

\(\Rightarrow l=\frac{c}{k}.....(1)\)

Where \(c\) is a constant of proportionality.

Let \(k_{1}\) be the force constant of spring with length \(l_{1}\) and \(k_{2}\) be the force constant of spring with length \(l_{2}\).

Then we can write

\( l_{1}=\frac{c}{k_{1}}.....(2)\)

And

\( l_{2}=\frac{c}{k_{2}}.....(3)\)

We know that the total length \(l\) is the sum of \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\).

\( l=l_{1}+l_{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow l=l_{1}+\frac{l_{1}}{n} \)

\(\because l_{1}=n l_{2}\)

Substituting the value of \(l\) and \(l_{1}\) from equation (1) and (2), we get

\(\frac{c}{k}=\frac{c}{k_{1}}+\frac{c}{n k_{1}}\)

Now let us solve for \(k_{1}\).

\( \frac{1}{k}=\frac{1}{k_{1}}+\frac{1}{n k_{1}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{k}=\frac{n+1}{n k_{1}} \)

\(\Rightarrow k_{1}=\frac{n+1}{n} k\)

This is the value of the spring constant of length \(l_{1}\).

A point particle of mass \(0.1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is executing SHM of amplitude \(0.1 \mathrm{~m}\). When the particle passes through the mean position, its \(\mathrm{KE}\) is \(8 \times 10^{-3} J\). The equation of motion of this particle, if its initial phase of oscillation is \(45^{\circ}\).

Given:

A point particle of mass \(0.1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is executing SHM of amplitude \(0.1 \mathrm{~m}\).

\(\mathrm{KE}\) = \(8 \times 10^{-3} J\)

Initial phase of oscillation = \(45^{\circ}=\frac{\pi}{4}\)

We know that:

\(\mathrm{KE}\) at mean position \(=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} a^{2}\)

According to the question:

 \(\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} a^{2}=8 \times 10^{-3}\).....(1)

Put all the given values in (1).

\(\omega=\left(\frac{2 \times 8 \times 10^{-3}}{m a^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2}\)

\(=\left[\frac{2 \times 8 \times 10^{-3}}{0.1 \times(0.1)^{2}}\right]^{1 / 2}\)

\(=4\)

Equation of SHM is,\(y=a \sin (\omega t+\theta)\)

\(=0.1 \sin \left(4 t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)
A body of mass \(0.01 \mathrm{~kg}\) executes SHM about \(x=0\), under the influence of force shown in the figure the period of the SHM is:

From the given graph, slope of F-x graph is k.

 \(k=\frac{F}{x}\)

\(=\frac{80}{0.2}\)

\(=400 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)

\(m=0.01\)

We know that time period \(T\) is given by:

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}\)

\(=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{0.01}{400}}\)

\(=\frac{\pi}{100}\)

\(=0.03142 \mathrm{~s}\)

The length of an elastic string is a metre when the longitudinal tension is \(4 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(\mathrm{b}\) metre when the longitudinal tension is \(5 \mathrm{~N}\). The length of the string in the metre when longitudinal tension is \(9 \mathrm{~N}\) is:

Let \(\mathrm{L}\) is the original length of the wire and \(\mathrm{k}\) is force constant of wire.

Final length \(=\) initial length \(+\) elongation

\(\mathrm{L}^{\prime}=\mathrm{L}+\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{k}}\)

For first condition \(\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{L}+\frac{4}{\mathrm{k}} \quad\).....(i)

For second condition \(\mathrm{b}=\mathrm{L}+\frac{5}{\mathrm{k}}\)......(ii)

By solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

\(\mathrm{L}=5 \mathrm{a}-4 \mathrm{~b} \text { and } \mathrm{k}=\frac{1}{\mathrm{~b}-\mathrm{a}}\)

Now, when the longitudinal tension is \(9 \mathrm{~N}\). length of the string.

\(=\mathrm{L}+\frac{9}{\mathrm{k}}=5 \mathrm{a}-4 \mathrm{b}+9(\mathrm{~b}-\mathrm{a}) \)

\(=5 \mathrm{~b}-4 \mathrm{a}\)
The variation of potential energy of harmonic oscillator is as shown in figure. The spring constant is:

We know that:

The Potential energy of the harmonic oscillator is given by \(\mathrm{PE}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{kx}^{2}\)

However, there can be initial potential energy, which is a constant.

Thus, the generalized potential energy of a harmonic oscillator is:

\(\mathrm{PE}=\mathrm{V}_{0}+\) \(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{kx}^{2}\).....(1)

From the given figure,

At \(\mathrm{x}=0, \mathrm{PE}=0.01 \mathrm{~J}=V_{0}\)

At \(\mathrm{x}=0.02 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{PE}=0.04 \mathrm{~J}\)

Substituting in the general form of Potential energy, we have \(\mathrm{V}_{0}=0.01 \mathrm{~J}\)

Put all the given values in (1).

Thus, \(0.01+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k}(0.02)^{2}=0.04 \)

\( \mathrm{k}=150 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}\)
If a simple pendulum is taken to a place where g decreases by \(2 \%\) then the time period:

We know that time period of simple pendulum is:

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\)

Taking log in both sides:

\(\log T=\log 2+\log \pi+\frac{1}{2} \log l-\frac{1}{2} \log g\)

Differentiating it we get

\(\frac{d T}{T}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d l}{l}-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d g}{g}=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d g}{g}(\therefore l\) is constant \()\)

\(\%\) change in time period

\(=\frac{d T}{T} \times 100=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d g}{g} \times 100 \)

\(=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{-2}{100}\right) \times 100\)

\(=1 \% \text { (increase) }\)

Displacement of a particle executing simple harmonic motion is represented by \(\mathrm{Y}=\) \(0.08 \sin \left(3 \pi \mathrm{t}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\) metre. Then calculate:

(a) Time period.

(b) Initial phase

(c) Displacement from mean position at \(\mathrm{t}=\frac{7}{36}\) sec.

Given:

Displacement equation is given as \(\mathrm{Y}=0.08 \sin \left(3 \pi \mathrm{t}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)

On comparing with \(\mathrm{Y}=\mathrm{A} \sin (\mathrm{\omega t}+\pi)\)

We get, \(\mathrm{\omega}=3 \pi\) and \(\phi=\frac{\pi}{4}\)

Time period \(\mathrm{T}=\frac{2 \pi}{\mathrm{\omega}}\)

\(=\frac{2 \pi}{3 \pi}\)

\(=\frac{2}{3} \mathrm{~s}\)

Initial phase \(\phi=\frac{\pi}{4}\)

\(\text { At } \mathrm{t}=\frac{7}{36} \mathrm{~s} \)

\( \mathrm{Y}=0.08 \sin \left(3 \pi \times \frac{7}{36}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)

\(=0.08 \sin (\frac{5 \pi }{ 6}) \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{Y}=0.08 \times 0.5\)

\(=0.04 \mathrm{~m}\)
Two waves of wavelength \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) and \(2.02 \mathrm{~m}\) respectively moving with the same velocity superimpose to produce 2 beats per sec. The velocity of the wave is:

When two waves having small differences in their frequency superpose each other there is a periodic variation in the intensity of the sound i.e., the amplitude of the sound rises and falls. The number of such variations heard per second is called the beat frequency.

The beat frequency is given by,

\(v_{B E A T}=v_{1}-v_{2} \ldots(1)\), where \(\mathrm{v}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{v}_{2}\) are the frequency of the two waves that are superposed.

In the question, the wavelengths of the two superposing waves are given to us. Let us write the wavelength in terms of their frequency using equation (1).

\(v_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{V}}{2 }\) and \(v_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{V}}{2.02 \mathrm{}}\) the velocity of both the waves i.e., \(\mathrm{V}\) is the same since they are moving together.

Now let us substitute the frequency of both the waves in equation 2 to determine the velocity of the wave.

\(v_{B E A T}=v_{1}-v_{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow v_{B E A T}=\frac{V}{2}-\frac{V}{2.02} \)

\(\Rightarrow 2=\operatorname{V}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2.02}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow 2=V(0.5-0.495049) \)

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{2}{4.95 \times 10^{-3}}\)

\(=0.404 \times 10^{3}\)

\(=404 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)
Intensity at any point due to interference of two waves will be maximum, when path difference at that point is:

We know the relation

\(I \propto\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+2 a_{1} a_{2} \cos \phi\right)\)

For intentisity to be maximum

\(\cos \phi=+1 \)

\(\text { or } \quad \phi=2 n \pi \)

\(\text { where } \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots \ldots . . \)

\(\therefore \text { Path difference } \)\((\Delta)=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi} \times \text { phase difference }( \phi)\)

\(\Delta=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi} \times \phi \)

Put all the given values in above equation:

\(\Delta=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi} \times 2 n \pi\)

\(\Delta=n \lambda\)

Two sine waves having unequal amplitudes and a phase difference of \(\frac{\pi}{2}\), are travelling along \(\mathrm{x}\) and \(\mathrm{y}\)-axis respectively. When they superimpose, the resultant wave will be:

The equation of the two superimposing waves can be give by:

\(\mathrm{y}_{1}=\mathrm{a}_{1} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t})\)

\(\mathrm{y}_{2}=\mathrm{a}_{2} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t}+ \frac{\pi}{ 2})=\mathrm{a}_{2} \cos (\omega \mathrm{t})\)

So, the equation of the resultant wave is:

\(\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{y}_{1}+\mathrm{y}_{2}\)

\(=\mathrm{a}_{1} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t})+\mathrm{a}_{2} \cos (\omega \mathrm{t})\).....(1)

Assuming \(\omega t=\phi, \mathrm{a}_{1}=\mathrm{a} \cos (\phi)\) and \(\mathrm{a}_{2}=\mathrm{a} \sin (\phi)\),

Put all values in (1).

\(\mathrm{a}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{2}^{2}=\mathrm{a}^{2}\left(\sin ^{2}(\phi)+\cos ^{2}(\phi)\right)=\mathrm{a}^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{a}=\sqrt{\mathrm{a}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{2}^{2}}\)

Three waves of equal frequency having amplitudes \(10 \mu \mathrm{m}, 4 \mu \mathrm{m}, 7 \mu \mathrm{m}\) arrive at a given point with successive phase difference of \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) radian. The amplitude of the resultant wave is:

The amplitude of the waves are:

\(\begin{aligned} a_{1} &=10 \mathrm{\mu m} \\ a_{2} &=4 \mathrm{\mu m} \\ a_{3} &=7 \mathrm{\mu m} \end{aligned}\)

The Phose differenve between \(1^{st}\) and \(2^{\text {nd }}\) wave is \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) and that between \(2^{\text {nd }}\) and \(3^{rd}\) wave is \(\frac{\pi}{2}\). Therefore , phose differente between \(1^{st}\) ond \(3^{r d}\) is \(\pi\). Combining \(1^{st}\) and \(3^{rd}\) their resultant amplitude is given by:

\(A_{1}^{2} =a_{1}^{2}+a_{3}^{2}+2 a_{1} a_{3} \cos \phi \)

\(\text { or } A_{1} =\sqrt{10^{2}+7^{2}+2 \times 10 \times 7 \cos \phi} \)

\(=\sqrt{100+49-140} \)

\(=\sqrt{9}\)

\(=3 \mathrm{\mu m}\)

Now Combining this with \(2^{\text {nd }}\) wave we have, the resultant amplitude:

\(A^{2} =A_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+2 A_{1} a_{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{ 2} \)

\( = \sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}+2 \times 3 \times 4 \cos 90^{\circ}}\)

\(=\sqrt{9+16} \)

\(=5 ~\mu m\)

It is found that when two waves of same intensity from two coherent sources superimpose at a certain point, then the resultant intensity is equal to the intensity of any one wave. This means that the phase difference between the two waves at that point is:
π2 rad
2π3 rad
π rad

The intensity of the resultant wave varies with amplitude of resultant wave as proportionally to square of amplitude. Intensity of resultant wave is defined as:

\(I=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta\) (where \(\left.\delta=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\right)\), \(\delta\) is the phase difference and \(\Delta x\) is the path difference between waves.

As given in the question the intensity of the waves are equal then \(I_{1}=I_{2}=I_{0}\). Substitute the value in the equation of intensity.

\(I=I_{0}+I_{0}+2 \sqrt{I_{0}^{2}} \cos \delta\)

\(\Rightarrow I=4 I_{0} \cos ^{2} \frac{\delta}{2}\)

Now it is given the resultant intensity is equal to the intensity of one wave only then \(I=I_{0}\), substituted in the above equation.

\(I_{0}=4 I_{0} \cos ^{2} \frac{\delta}{2}\)

\(\frac{1}{4}=\cos ^{2} \frac{\delta}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}=\cos \frac{\delta}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \cos \frac{\pi}{3}=\cos \frac{\delta}{2} \)

\(\therefore \delta=\frac{2 \pi}{3}\)

The phase difference between the waves is \(\frac{2 \pi}{3}\).
The apparent wavelength of light from a star moving away from the earth is \(0.02 \%\) more than the actual wavelength. What is the velocity of star?

Given:

\(C=3 \times 10^{8}  \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

\(\Delta \lambda=0.02 \%\)

We know that wavelength is expressed as \(\lambda\). So now the change in the wavelength is given as follows:

\(\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}=\frac{v}{C}\)

Here \(v\) is the velocity and \(C\) represents the speed of light. Hence we can express \(\mathrm{v}\) as:

\(v=\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} C\)

Now we have to put the values in the above expression, to get:

\(v=\frac{0.02}{100} \times 3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \)

\(v=60 \mathrm{kms}^{-1}\)

Closed O.P. and an open O.P. of same length produce 2 beats/sec. When they are set into vibrations together in fundamental mode. The length of open pipe is now halved and that of closed pipe is doubled. The number of beats produced will be:

For a closed organ pipe, the frequency of fundamental mode is \(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \mathrm{~L}_{\mathrm{c}}}\).

where \( v\) is velocity of sound in air and \(L_{c}\) is length of the closed pipe. For an open pipe, the frequency of fundamental mode is:

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2 \mathrm{~L}_{0}}\) Where \(\mathrm{L}_{0}\) is length of open pipe

\(\because \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{c}}=\mathrm{L}_{0}\) (given)

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}=2 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}} \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots .(1)\)

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}-\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=2 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots(2)\)

Solving (1) and (2) we get \(\mathrm{f}_{0}=4,\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=2\)

When length of open pipe is halved, its frequency of fundamental mode is:

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}_{0}}{2}\right)}=2 \mathrm{f}_{0}\)

\(=2 \times 4=8\)

When Length of closed pipe is doubled, its frequency

\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4\left(2 \mathrm{~L}_{\mathrm{c}}\right)}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{1}{2} \times 2 =1\)

Number of beats produced per second

\(=\mathrm{f}_{0}^{\prime}-\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}^{\prime}\)

\(=8-1\)

\(=7\)

Two sources \(A\) and \(B\) are sounding notes of freq. \(680 \mathrm{~Hz}\). A listener moves from \(A\) to \(B\) with a constant velocity \(u\). If the speed of sound is \(340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\), what must be the value of \(u\) so that he hears 10 beats \(/ \mathrm{s}\).

Given:

\(n=680\) m/s

Speed of sound (v) = \(340\) m/s

Listener go from \(\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B}\) with velocity (u) let the apparent frequency of sound from source A by listener:

\(\mathrm{n}^{\prime}=\mathrm{n} \frac{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\mathrm{v}+\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{s}}} \)

\(\mathrm{n}^{\prime}=680 \frac{340-\mathrm{u}}{340+0}\)

The apparent frequency of sound from source B by listener:

\(\mathrm{n} "=\mathrm{n} \frac{\mathrm{v}+\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{A}}}{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{S}}}\)

\(=680 \frac{340+\mathrm{u}}{340-0}\)

But listner hezear 10 beats prer second.

\(n^{''}-n^{'}=10\)

\(\Rightarrow 680 \frac{340+\mathrm{u}}{340}-680 \frac{340-\mathrm{u}}{340}=10\)

\(\Rightarrow 2340+\mathrm{u}-340+\mathrm{u}=10\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{u}=2.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)
Which band does the \(3 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~Hz}\) to \(3 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~Hz}\) frequency range fall into?

High-frequency band have \(3 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~Hz}\) to \(3 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~Hz}\) frequency range.

The only spectrum of electromagnetic waves that we can see is the visible spectrum. It consists of 7 major colours pertaining to different wavelengths of visible light. But there are many more frequencies and wavelengths at which these waves operate like the radio waves, X-rays and gamma rays. The electromagnetic spectrum defines an order of the frequencies of these waves.

The classes of electromagnetic waves, as mentioned in the question, range as:

  • High frequency band: \(3 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(30 \mathrm{MHz}\).
  • Super-high frequency band: \(3 \mathrm{GHz}\) to \(30 \mathrm{GHz}\)
  • Ultra-high frequency band: \(300 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(3 \mathrm{GHz}\)
  • Very high frequency band: \(30 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(300 \mathrm{MHz}\)
  • Here, \(1 \mathrm{MHz}=10^{6} \mathrm{Hz}\) and \( 1 \mathrm{GHz}=10^{9} \mathrm{~Hz}\)

The frequency range that we need to identify in our question is \(3 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(30 \mathrm{MHz}\). From the above distinction we can see that this lies in the high frequency band. This also lies in the major class of radio waves.
\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{s}}\) is the velocity of sound in air and \(\mathrm{C}\) is the R.M.S. velocity, then:

The velocity of sound in air is given by:

\(\mathrm{C_s}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma \mathrm{RT} }{ \mathrm{M}}}\).....(1)

where \(\gamma\) is the degree of freedom

\(\mathrm{T}=\text { temperature } \)

\(\mathrm{M}=\text { mass }\)

According to the kinetic theory of gases, The rms velocity of sound is given by:

\(\mathrm{C}=\sqrt{\frac{3 \mathrm{RT} }{ \mathrm{M}}}\).....(2)

Dividing equation (1) and (2) we get:

\(\frac{\mathrm{C_s} }{ \mathrm{C}}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{ 3} }\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{C_s}=\mathrm{C} \sqrt{ \frac{\gamma }{ 3}}\)
The loudness and pitch of a sound depends on:

The loudness and pitch of a sound depends on intensity and frequency.

Loudness depends upon intensity and pitch is depends upon frequency higher the amplitude of the sounder. The louder the sound is and the higher the frequency of the sound waves, the higher the pitch of the sound will be. Amplitude is the maximum displacement of vibration so, large-amplitude produces loud sound as large vibration produces a louder sound.
The ratio of densities of nitrogen and oxygen is \(14: 16\). The temperature at which the speed of sound in nitrogen will be same at that in oxygen at \(55^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is:

Given:

The ratio of densities of nitrogen and oxygen is \(14: 16\).

The temperature at which the speed of sound in nitrogen will be same at that in oxygen at \(55^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

\(T_{N}\) = Temperature of nitrogen

\(T_{o}\) = Temperature of oxygen

The velocity of the sound in nitrogen is given by:

\( \mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma \mathrm{RT}}{\mathrm{M}}} \)

\(\Rightarrow  \frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{N}}}{\mathrm{T}_{0}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{N}}}{\mathrm{M}_{0}} \)

\(\Rightarrow  \frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{N}}}{273+55}=\frac{14}{16}=\frac{7}{8}\)

Therefore, the temperature at which speed of nitrogen will be same as that of oxygen will be:

\(T_{N}=(273+55) \times \frac{7}{8}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{N}}=287 \mathrm{~K}=14^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

Velocity of sound waves in air is \(330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) for a particular sound wave in air, a path difference of \(40 \mathrm{~cm}\) is equivalent to phase difference of \(1.6 \pi\). The frequency of this wave will be:

Given:

Velocity of sound waves in air (V) = \(330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Path difference = \(40 \mathrm{~cm}\)

Phase difference = \(1.6 \pi\)

Velocity of sound waves \(=330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\Delta \phi=\mathrm{K} \Delta \mathrm{x} \).....(1)

\(\Delta \phi=\text { phase difference } \)

\(\mathrm{K}=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{x}=\) Path difference

Putting the values given in question in (1)

\(1.6 \pi=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\left(\frac{40}{100}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda=\frac{2 \pi}{1.6 \pi} \times \frac{40 \times 10}{100}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}\)

Now,

\(\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{f} \lambda\)

\(330=\mathrm{f}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \)

\(\mathrm{f}=660 \mathrm{~Hz}\)
Two waves of amplitude \(A_{1}\) and \(A_{2}\) respectively and equal frequency travels towards the same point. The amplitude of the resultant wave is:
\(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2}\)
\(\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\)
Between \(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\)
Can not say

Two waves of amplitude \(A_{1}\) and \(A_{2}\) respectively and equal frequency travels towards the same point. The amplitude of the resultant wave is always between \(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\).

If the two waves are in constructive phase, then the resultant amplitude will be equal to

\(\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2} \text { (maximum) }\)

If they are in destructive phase, then

\(\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\)

Therefore the resultant amplitude will be always between \(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2} \) and \( \mathrm{~A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\).

The resultant will depend on their phase difference.

In the figure shown below, all the contact surfaces are perfectly smooth. “M” and “m” indicate mass. When the object of mass “m” starts sliding down due to the force of gravity, then the centre of mass will _____.

Since all the contact surfaces are smooth, due to lack of friction, the net force in the horizontal direction is zero. So, the centre of mass will not change horizontally. However, the centre of mass will change vertically due to the action of external force – gravity.
For an object with the centre of mass at the origin, the x-coordinates of particles of the object _____.

For an object to have the x-coordinate of its centre of mass, there should be particles on both the negative and positive coordinates of the plane for the sum to be zero. However, for 1-dimensional particles that all lie on the y-axis symmetric about the x-axis, the x-coordinate is zero – which is neither positive nor negative, i.e., non-negative.
Numerous particles in a system are placed at a distance of “D” from the origin. The position of the centre of mass will definitely be _____.

Since all objects are placed at the same distance, they are either placed in a spherical configuration, circular-arc configuration or a linear configuration. In all of the cases, the centre of mass of the system will lie within the geometry of the shape. So, the centre of mass of the system is at a position lesser than or equal to D.
A wheel is rolling on a plane surface as shown. The centre of the wheel moves with a speed \(v_{0}\). Then the speed of the particle at P is:

The motion of the wheel is combined with rolling and translation.

The speed of the center of the wheel \(=v_{0}\)

Since the point \(\mathrm{P}\) is on the rim of the wheel, \({v}_{0}={R} \omega\)

Thus, the speed of the particle at \({P}, {v}={r} \omega\)

Where, \({v}\) is velocity, \({r}\) is radius, \(\omega\) is angular velocity

Using Pythagoras theorem, \(r=\sqrt{R^{2}+R^{2}}=\sqrt{2} R\) 

Therefore, speed at \({P}={r} \omega=\sqrt{2} {R} \omega=\sqrt{{2}} {v}_{0}\)
A particle is in circular motion in a vertical plane. If the direction of the velocity at the top most point is towards the east, then the direction of angular velocity is towards:

Since the circular motion is in the vertical plane, it is the plane of east-west and north-south will be the horizontal plane.

The direction of angular velocity is perpendicular to the plane of rotation. Thus, the angular velocity will be along the north-south direction.

Given that linear velocity is directed towards the east.

Thus, on using the right-hand thumb rule for vector product, the direction of angular velocity will be towards the north.
Consider a system on which there are external forces acting. If the vector sum of all these external forces is zero, then the centre of mass ____.

Since the vector addition of all external forces is zero, we know that the acceleration vector is zero for the resultant force vector as mass cannot be zero. Zero acceleration can imply zero or non-zero constant velocity. Thus, the centre of mass may move.
A flywheel of mass 6000 kg starts from rest and gets up to a speed of 20 rad/s in 2 minutes. The radius of gyration of the wheel is 100 cm. The average torque exerted on the flywheel is:

Given:

M = 6000 kg

\(ω_{0}\) = 0 rad/s, Angular speed (ω) after 2 min = 20 rad/s

time t = 2 min = 120 s

k = 100 cm = 1 m

ω = \(ω_{0}\) + α t

20 = 0 + α × 120

α = \(\frac{20}{120}\) 

= 0.1666 rad/s2 

We know that:

I = M × k2

Where, I is moment of inertia, M is mass, k is Radius of gyration.

I = 6000 ×12 = 6000 kg-m2

Now, T = I × α 

Where T is torque, I is moment of inertia, α is angular acceleration.

T = 6000 × 0.1666 

= 1000 Nm
If a solid disc was rotating along the x-y axis as shown below, in such case the direction of torque will be:

From the above-given explanation also from the given data, we can express the equation of torque as shown below:

Torque, \(\vec{\tau}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F}\)

And the direction of torque can be predicted using right-hand thumb rule, in which curled finger represents the direction of force and thumb represents the direction of torque as shown below,

So, from this, we can see that the direction of torque will be along the positive x-axis.

A couple of \(10^{5}\) Nm is applied to a fly wheel of mass \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) and radius of gyration \(50 \mathrm{~m}\). The angular acceleration of the wheel in \(\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) is:

Given that:

Torque, \(\mathrm{T}=10^{5}\) Nm

Mass, \(\mathrm{m}=10 \mathrm{~kg}\)

The radius of gyration, \(r=50 \mathrm{~m}\)

Moment of inertia,

\(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{mr}^{2}\)

\(=10 \times 50^{2}\)

\(=25000 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{2}\)

Torque, \(\mathrm{T}=\mathrm{I} \times\alpha\)

\(\) Angular acceleration, \(\alpha=\frac{T}{I}\)

\(=\frac{10^{5}}{25000}\)

\(=4~\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)
A door of 1.6 m wide requires a force of 1 N to be applied at the free end to open or close it. The force that is required at a point 0.4 m distant from the hinges for opening or closing the door is:

Given that initially Force \(\vec{F}=1 \mathrm{~N}\) and distance from the hinge \(\vec{\mathrm{r}}=1.6 \mathrm{~m}\)

Later \(\vec{r}=0.4 \mathrm{~m}\) and Required Force \(\vec{F}=\) ?

We know that the formula of torque \(\vec{T}\) is given by:

\(\vec{T}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F}\) (initial force)

\(=1.6 \times 1\)

\(=1.6 \mathrm{Nm}\)

Putting the above value in the formula of torque, we get:

\(1.6=0.4 \times \vec{F}\) (required Force)

\(\Rightarrow\vec{F}=4 N\)
120 N of force is required to open a nut using a spanner of length 10 cm. If another spanner of length 6 cm is used to open the same nut, what amount of force has to applied?

The opening of a nut using a spanner works on the principle of torque.

When a force is applied through a spanner, the fixed point lies where the nut is positioned. As a result, a turning effect is produced on the nut which helps in its opening or tightening.

The angle between force and moment arm is 90∘ when maximum torque is produced.

Given:

Length of the spanner = moment arm, r1 = 10 cm = 0.1 m

Force applied = 120 N

We Know that:

τ = r1 × F

Where, τ is torque, r1 is length of spanner and F is Force

= 0.1 × 120 = 12 N-m

To open the nut using another spanner, the same torque has to be produced.

Length of the second spanner, r2 = 6 cm = 0.06 m

τ = r2 × F

12 = 0.06 × F

⇒ F = 200 N
Moment of inertia, rotational kinetic energy, and angular momentum of a body is I, E, and L respectively then:

We know that:

\(K E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}\)

Angular momentum, \(L=I \times \omega\quad \ldots(1)\)

Roational kinetic energy, \(E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}\) 

Where I is Moment of inertia, and \(\omega\) is angular momentum

\(\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{I}} \quad \ldots(2)\)

Substituting (2) in (1) we get

\(\mathrm{L}=I \times \sqrt{\frac{2 E}{I}}\)

\(=\sqrt{(2 EI)}\)

A rod of length (L) \(15 {~m}\) is rotating about an axis passing through its one end and velocity at a point which is at \(\frac{L }{ 3}\) distance from the axis is \(15 {~m} / {s}\). Find the linear velocity of the free end of the rod.

Given that:

Length of the rod \({L}=15 \mathrm{~m}\)

Linear velocity at \(\frac{L }{ 3}\) is \((v)=15 {~m} / {s}\)

Let \(\omega\) is the angular velocity of the rod about the given axis of rotation.


We know that:

\(v=\omega \times L\)

At \(\frac{L} { 3}\),

\(v=\omega\times\frac{L} { 3}=15\)

So, \(\omega=\frac{45 } {L}  {rad} / {s}\)

Now for free end:

\({v}^{\prime}=\omega L\)

\(=(\frac{45 }{L}) \times {L}=45 {~m} / {s}\)
A string is wound round a hollow cylinder of mass 3 kg and radians 40 cm. The string is pulled with a force of 50 Newton. The angular acceleration of cylinder will be:

Given:

Force applied, \(\mathrm{F}=50 \mathrm{~N}\)

Mass, \(\mathrm{m}=3 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Radius, \(r=40 \mathrm{~cm}=0.4 \mathrm{~m}\)

Torque, \(T=F \times r=50 \mathrm{~N} \times 0.4 \mathrm{~m}=20 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}\)

Moment of inertia is given by:

\(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{mr}^{2}\)

\(=3 \mathrm{~kg} \times 0.4 \mathrm{~m} \times 0.4 \mathrm{~m}=0.48 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{2}\)

Angular acceleration is given by:

\(\alpha=\frac{\tau}{I}=\frac{20 \mathrm{Nm}}{0.48} \)

\(=41.66 \mathrm{rds}^{-2}\)
Find the radius of gyration of a disc of mass \({M}\) and radius \({R}\) rotating about an axis passing through the center of mass and perpendicular to the plane of the disc.

We know that:

In terms of the radius of gyration, the moment of inertia is \({I}={M} {K}^{2}\), so

\({M} {K}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} {MR}^{2}\) 

\(\Rightarrow {K}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} {R}^{2}\) 

\(\Rightarrow {K}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} {R}\),

\(\Rightarrow K=\frac{1}{1.414} {R}\)

\({K}=0.707 {R}\)

From a circular disc of radius \({R}\) and mass \(9 {M}\), a small disc of mass \({M}\) and radius \(\frac{R}{3}\) is removed concentrically. The moment of inertia of the remaining disc about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the disc and passing through its centre is:

The radius of full disc \(={R}\)

Mass of full disc \(=9 {M}\)

The radius of removed disc \(=\frac{R }{3}\)

Mass of removed disc \(=M\)

From the formula of moment of Inertia, we get,

\({I}_{1}=\frac{1} { 2}{ {M}_{1} {R}_{1}^{2}}=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times 9 {M} \times {R}^{2}=\frac{9 }{ 2} {MR}^{2}\) ( Full disc) 

\({I}_{2}=\frac{1 }{ 2}{ {M}_{2} {R}_{2}^{2}}=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times \mathrm{M} \times(\frac{R}{ 3})^{2}=\frac{{MR}^{2} }{ 18}\)

Therefore, the moment of inertia of the remaining portion of the disc about \({O}\) is.

\({I}={I}_{1}+{I}_{2}={MR}^{2}[\frac{9} { 2}+\frac{1 }{ 18}]=\frac{41}{ 9}{MR}^{2}\)

A thin disc and a thin ring, both have mass \({M}\) and radius \({R}\). Both rotate about axes through their centre of mass and are perpendicular to their surfaces at the same angular velocity. Which of the following is true?
The ring and the disc have the same kinetic energy
Kinetic energies of both the bodies are zero since they are not in linear motion

Moment of inertia of the ring about an axis passing through centre and perpendicular to its plane is given by:

\(I_{\text {ring }}=M R^{2}\)

Moment of inertia of the disc about an axis passing through centre and perpendicular to its plane is given by:

\(I_{d i s c}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\)

As we know that mathematically rotational kinetic energy can be written as:

\(K E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}\)

Where, \(\omega\) is angular velocity

According to question, that angular velocity of thin disc and a thin ring is same. Thus, Kinetic energy is depends on to moment of inertia. Therefore, a body having more moment of inertia will have more kinetic energy and vice versa.

So, from equation it is clear that, \(I_{\text {ring }}>I_{\text {disc }} ;\) so, \(K_{\text {ring }}>K_{\text {disc }}\)

\(\therefore\) The ring has higher kinetic energy.

An asteroid enters the atmosphere of the earth and breaks into two pieces. One of the pieces is larger than the other. Which of the following is true considering the centre of mass of both the pieces together?
The centre of mass shifts horizontally towards the larger piece
The centre of mass shifts horizontally towards the smaller piece
The centre of mass remains in the same trajectory as before breaking apart of the asteroid
Depends on the velocity of the asteroid

Since internal forces do not change the position of the centre of mass of a system as their net force is zero, the centre of mass remains in the same trajectory as before breaking apart of the asteroid. However, it is an influential factor for the trajectories of the two pieces after breaking apart.

Four identical thin rods each of mass \({M}\) and length \({l}\), form a square frame. Moment of inertia of this frame about an axis through the centre of the square and perpendicular to its plane is:

Given that:

Mass of each rod \(=M\)

Length of each \({rod}=l\)

Moment of inertia about an axis passing through the center of the rod, \(\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{C}}=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}\)

Moment of inertia of the rod about an axis through the center of the square and perpendicular to its plane:

Here, \(h=\frac{l }{ 2}\)

By using parallel axis theorem, Moment of Inertia I \(=I_{{C}}+{m}\left({h}^{2}\right)\)

\(=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+M\left(\frac{l}{2}\right)^{2}\)

\(=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+\frac{M l^{2}}{4}=\frac{M l^{2}}{3}\)

Moment of inertia due to all four rods \(=4 \times {I}\)

\(=4 \times \frac{M l^{2}}{3}\)

\(=(\frac{4 }{ 3}) {Ml}^{2}\)

The moment of inertia of a rod of mass \({M}\) and length \({l}\) about an axis passing through its centre and perpendicular to its length is \(0.084\) \({M} {l}^{2}\). Then the moment of inertia of the rod about an axis passing through one of its ends and parallel to the given axis will be:

Given that:

Moment of inertia about the axis through the centre of the road, \({I}_{{C}}=0.084 {M} {l}^{2}\)

The distance between the central axis and the axis passing through one of its ends parallelly, 

\(h=0.5l\)

Using the parallel axis theorem, Moment of Inertia \(I =I_{C}+M h^{2}=0.084 M l^{2}+M(0.51)^{2}\) 

\(=(0.084+0.25) {M} {l}^{2}\)

\(=0.334 {Ml}^{2}\)
The moment of inertia of a body is always minimum about an axis parallel to its:

From the parallel axis theorem, the moment of inertia about any other parallel axis passing through the axis of the center of mass (Centroidal axis):

Moment of inertia about \(P_{1}\) axis:

\(I=I_{c o m}+M x_{1}^{2}\)

And moment of inertia about \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\)

\(I=I_{{com}}+{M} {x}_{2}{ }^{2}\)

Where \(I\) is a total moment of inertia of the body, \({I}_{\text {com }}\) is the moment of inertia about the center of mass, \({M}\) is mass, \({x}_{2}\) is the perpendicular distance from an axis passing from center of mass.

So it is clear that the moment of inertia about any parallel axis from the Centroidal axis is more than the moment of inertia about the Centroidal axis.
A sphere of mass \(10 {~kg}\) and radius \(0.5 {~m}\) rotates about an axis passing through the tangent at a point on its surface. The moment of inertia of the sphere about the tangent is:

Given that:

Mass of the sphere, \({M}=10 {~kg}\)

The radius of the sphere, \(R=0.5 {~m}\)

Consider a point \({P}\) on the surface of the sphere and a tangent passing through it as shown. Let the moment of inertia about this tangent be I.

We know, the moment of inertia about the central axis of a sphere,

\(I_{C}=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}\)

Using the parallel axis theorem,

\(I=I_{C}+M h^{2}\)

From the figure, \({h}={R}\)

\(I=I_{C}+M R^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}+M R^{2}=\frac{7}{5} M R^{2}=\frac{7}{5} \times 10 \times(0.5)^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow I=3.5 {kgm}^{2}\)
If angular position of a rigid body changes with time as \(\theta=4 t^{3}-12 t-14\) then the angular velocity of the body at time \(t=1 {sec}\) is:

Given:

The expression for the angular position, \(\theta=4 t^{3}-12 t-14\)

\(\) Angular position, \(\theta=4 t^{3}-12 t-14\)

Now,

Instantaneous angular velocity is given as-

\(\omega=\frac{d \theta}{d t}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d \theta}{d t}=\frac{d\left(4 t^{3}-12 t-14\right)}{d t}=12 t^{2}-12\)

\(\therefore \omega=12 t^{2}-12\)

Now,

Angular velocity at \({t}=1 {sec}\), we have

\(\omega=12(1)^{2}-12=0\)

\(\therefore \omega=0\)

A thin circular ring of mass \({M}\) and radius \({R}\) is rotating about its axis with a constant angular velocity \(\omega\). Two objects each of mass ' \({m}\) ' are attached gently to the opposite ends of a diameter of the ring. The ring will now rotate with an angular velocity:

Given:

 \(M_{1}=M, M_{2}=2 m, R_{1}=R_{2}=R(l e t)\), initial velocity \(\left(\omega_{1}\right)=\omega\) and final velocity \(\left(\omega_{2}\right)=\omega^{\prime}\)

We have a thin circular ring of mass \(\mathrm{M}\) and radius \(\mathrm{r}\) and it is rotated at constant angular velocity \(\omega\)

The initial moment of inertia is of the circular ring is,

\(I_{1}=M_{1} R_{1}^{2}=M R^{2}\)..............(1)

The initial momentum of the circular ring is,

\(L=I_{1} \omega=M R^{2} \omega\)

When another ring of the same mass is put on the \(1^{\text {st }}\) rotating ring, then the final moment of inertia is,

\(I_{2}=M R^{2}+2 m R^{2}=(M+2 m) R^{2}\)

Final momentum of the circular ring is

\(L^{\prime}=I_{2} \omega^{\prime}=(M+2 m) R^{2} \omega^{\prime}\)

Since, there is no external torque acting on this system, this means that angular momentum of the system will be conserved.

Thus, by conservation of angular momentum,

\({L}={L}^{\prime}\)

\(\Rightarrow {MR}^{2} \omega=({M}+2 {~m}) {R}^{2} \omega^{\prime}\)

\(\Rightarrow \omega^{\prime}=\frac{M R^{2} \omega}{(M+2 m) R^{2}}=\frac{M \omega}{M+2 m}\)
Which of the following condition is/are true for rolling of disc without slipping on an incline plane of inclination \(\theta\).

Disc will begin to slip when:

\({f}=\mu \mathrm{N}\)

As there is no motion in a direction normal to the inclined plane:

\({N}={Mgcos} \theta\)

Applying Newton's Second Law to the linear motion of the center of mass, the net force on the cylinder rolling down the inclined plane is:

\(F=M a=M g \sin \theta-f \quad \dots\) (i)

It is only the force of friction \(f\) wich expert torque \(\tau\) on the cylinder and makes it rotate with angular acceleration.

It acts tangentially at the point of contact \(\mathrm{P}\) and has lever arm equal to \(R\).

putting the value of \({f}\) in equation (i), we get,

\({Ma}={Mg} \sin \theta-\frac{I \alpha}{R^{2}}=\mathrm{a}={g} \sin \theta-\frac{I \alpha}{M R^{2}}={a}+\frac{I \alpha}{M R^{2}}=\mathrm{g} \sin \theta\)

Moment of Inertia of the solid cylinder about its axis \(=\frac{{MR}^{2} }{ 2}\)

By putting value, I= \(\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\), we get,

\(\mathrm{a}=\frac{g \sin \theta}{1+\frac{I}{M R^{2}}}=\frac{2}{3} \mathrm{~g} \sin \theta\) \(\quad \ldots\) (ii)

Clearly, the linear acceleration of a solid cylinder rolling down an inclined plane is less than the acceleration due to gravity \((a<g)\)

The linear acceleration of the cylinder is constant for a given inclined plane and is independent of its mass \(M\), and Radius \(R\).

However, for a hollow cylinder.

\({I}={MR}^{2}\), the value of a would decrease to \(\frac{1 }{ 2}{~g} \sin \theta\)

From equation (i), the value of the force of friction is,

\(f=M g \sin \theta-\) Ma by putting the value of a from equation (ii), we get,

\(f={Mgsin} \theta-M \times\frac{ 2} { 3}(g \sin \theta)=\frac{1 }{ 3}({Mgsin} \theta)\)

if \(\mu_{{s}}\) is the coefficient of friction between the cylinder and the inclined plane, then

\(\mu_{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{f} {N}=\frac{\frac{1}{3} \mathrm{Mg} \sin \theta}{M g \cos \theta}=\frac{1} { 3} \tan \theta\)

Therefore, \(\mu_{{s}}>\frac{1} { 3}(\tan \theta)\) or \(\mu_{{s}}=\frac{1} { 3(\tan \theta)}\)

A solid sphere of radius \(R\) is rolling on a horizontal plank with velocity \(V^{'}\). The plank itself is moving with velocity \(V_{}\) on the ground. What is the relationship between \(V^{'}\) and \(V^{}\)?

When an object is rolling on a plane without slipping, the point of contact of the object with the plane does not move.

A rolling object's velocity \(V\) is directly related to its angular velocity \(\omega\).

Mathematically it is expressed as \({V}=\omega {R}\)

Where \(R=\) the object's radius and \(V=\) its linear velocity.


In pure rolling motion, the point of contact (bottom-most point) moves with velocity

\(V_{p}=\text { velocity of point } P=V\)

\(\Rightarrow V_{p}=\left(V^{\prime}-\omega R\right)=V\)

\(\Rightarrow V^{\prime}=V_{p}+\omega R\)

Where, \({V}^{\prime}=\) linear velocity of solid sphere

\({V}=\) velocity of planck
The linear momentum of the body is increased by \(30 \%\). Calculate the percentile change in the kinetic energy of the particle if the mass of the particle is constant.

Given:

The increase in linear momentum \(=30 \%\)

\({K}=\) Initial kinetic energy

\({K}_{1}\) = The new kinetic energy after the change in the momentum

\({P}_{1}=\) The new momentum after the increase, and \({P}=\) initial momentum

The percentage increase in the momentum can be represented as

\( {P}_{1}=1.30 {P}\)

The corresponding increase in the kinetic en energy is given by,

\( KE_{1}=\frac{P_{1}^{2}}{2 M}=\frac{(1.30 P)^{2}}{2 M}=\frac{1.69 P^{2}}{2 M}=1.69 \frac{P^{2}}{2 M}\)

\(\Rightarrow KE_{1}=1.69 K E\)

The change in Kinetic energy is given by

\( \Delta{KE}={KE}_{1}-{KE}=1.69 {KE}-{KE}=0.69 {KE}\)

The change can be expressed in percentile as

\(\Rightarrow\) Change in percentile \(=0.69 \times 100=69 \%\)
A body of mass \(1 {~kg}\) undergoes a change in velocity from \(2 {~m} / {s}\) to \(3 {~m} / {s}\) in 2 seconds, when a force is applied to it. The rate of change of linear momentum will be?

When the velocity of a body changes, the linear momentum also changes.

The rate of change of linear momentum is proportional to the applied force (Newton's second law of motion).

So, the rate of change of linear momentum is given as:

\(\frac{d p}{d t}=\frac{m\left(v_{2}-v_{1}\right)}{t}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d p}{d t}=\frac{1 \times(3-2)}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d p}{d t}=0.5 N\)
The moment of inertia of a thin rod of mass \({M}\) and length \({L}\) about an axis through one of its ends and perpendicular to length is:

The moment of inertia of the rod when the axis is perpendicular to it and passes through its center is

\(I_{c}=\frac{M L^{2}}{12}\)

The distance between the center of mass \({I}_{{c}}\) and one end of a rod \(({x})=\frac{L} { 2}\) Use parallel axis theorem:

The moment of inertia about one end is given by:

\({I}={I}_{{c}}+{M} {x}^{2}\)

\(=\frac{{ML}^{2}} { 12}+{M}(\frac{L} {2})^{2}\)

\(=\frac{{ML}^{{2 }}}{3}\)

A body of mass \(m\) is accelerated uniformly from rest to a speed \(v\) in a time \(T\). The instantaneous power delivered to the body as a function of time, is given by:

\(P_{\text {inst }}=F_{\text {inst }} \times v_{\text {inst }}\)

as it was given constant acceleration, force is also constant.

\(F_{\text {inst }}=F_{\text {const }}=m a \)

\(a=\frac{v}{T} \)

\(v_{\text {inst }}=(a \times t)=\frac{v}{T} \times t \)

\(P_{\text {inst }}=\left(m \times \frac{v}{T}\right) \times\left(\frac{v}{T} \times t\right) \)

\(P_{\text {inst }}=m \frac{v^{2}}{T^{2}} t\)
The power of a pump, which can pump \(200 \mathrm{~kg}\) of water to a height of \(50 \mathrm{~m}\) in \(10 \mathrm{~s}\), will be \(\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\)

The relationship between the force ' \(F\) ' and the position ' \(x\) ' of a body is as shown in the figure. What will be the work done in displacing the body from \(x=1 \mathrm{~m}\) to \(\mathrm{x}=5 \mathrm{~m}\) ?

\(W=\) area under \(F-x\) graph

From \(X=0\) to \(X=1\), force and displacement both are positive. Therefore work done is positive.

\(W_{0}=+\text { Area }=+5 J\)

From \(X=1\) to \(X=3\), force and displacement both are positive. Therefore work done is positive.

\(W_{1}=+\text { Area }=+15 J\)

From \(X=3\) to \(X=4\), force is negative but displacement is positive. Therefore work done is again positive.

\(\therefore W_{2}=-\text { Area }=-5 J\)

From \(X=4\) to \(X=5\), force and displacement both are positive. Therefore work done is again positive.

\(\therefore W_{3}=+\text { Area }=+5 J \)

\(W_{\text {Total }}=W_{0}+W_{1}+W_{2}+W_{3}=20 J\)
A stone of mass \(500 \mathrm{~g}\) is thrown vertically upwards with a velocity of \(15 m s^{-1}\). Calculate the potential energy at the greatest height.

Kinetic Energy, \(K . E=0.5 \times m \times v^{2}\)

\(\mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E}=0.5 \times 0.5 \times 15 \times 15=56.25 J\)

As it has \(56.25 J\) at the initial point as total energy, at some point X, Potential Energy(P.E.) is maximum.

Total energy = P.E. + K.E.

\(56.25=\text { P.E. }+\text { K.E. }\)

As energy is conserved total energy at point \(X\) also must be \(40 J\).

For P.E to be maximum K.E. must be zero.

So, P.E. \(=56.25 J\)

We can come to the conclusion that potential energy will have the maximum value at maximum height.
If under the action of a force \((4 i+j+3 k) N\), a particle moves from position \(r_{1}=3 i+2 j-6 k\) to positions \(r_{2}=14 i+13 j+9 k\), then the work done will be:

\(300 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done in sliding a \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) block, up an inclined plane to a height of 10 meters. Taking value of acceleration due to gravity ' \(g\) ' to be \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\), work done against friction is:

Let \(W_{f}\) be the work done against friction.

The total work done on a particle is equal to the change in its mechanical energy.

\(W=W_{f}+P E\)

\(=W_{f}+m g h \ldots(1)\)

Work done against the friction

From equation (1)

\(W_{f}=W-m g h\)

Substituting the values, we get

\(W_{f}=300 J-\left(2 \mathrm{~kg} \times 10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \times 10 \mathrm{~m}\right)\)

\(=100 J\)
The potential energy of a body is given by \(A-B x^{2}\). The magnitude of force acting on the particle is:

Force on the particle \(=-\frac{d U}{d x}\)

\(\Rightarrow F=2 B X\)

From the above equation: \(F \propto X\)

A force of \(60 N\) acts on a body which moves it through a distance of \(4 m\) on a horizontal surface. What is the work done, if the direction of the force is at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal surface?

An electric pump is used to fill an overhead tank of capacity \(9 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) kept at a height of \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) above the ground. If the pump takes 5 minutes to fill the tank by consuming \(10 \mathrm{~kW}\) power, then the efficiency of the pump must be (take \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) )

Mass of water raised \(=1000 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \times 9 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) \(=9000 \mathrm{~kg}\)

P. \(E=9000 \times 10 \times 10=900000 J\)

Power \(=\frac{P . \epsilon}{t}=3000\) watt

Efficiency \(=\frac{3 k W}{10 k w}=0.3=30 \%\)
A cricket ball is hit for a six leaving the bat at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal with kinetic energy \(K\). At the top, Kinetic energy of the ball is:

At the top position, the ball contains only horizontal

Velocity, hence \(v_{\text {top }}=v \cos 45^{\circ}\)

Initial velocity \(=v\)

\(K E=K=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)

Final \(K E=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v \cos 45^{\circ}\right)^{2}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}}{2}=\frac{K}{2}\)
A body of mass \(1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving in a vertical circular path of radius \(1 \mathrm{~m}\). The difference between the kinetic energies at its highest and lowest positions is:

Given,

\(r=1 m\)

\(m=1 \mathrm{~kg}\)

\(g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

In limiting case, for body to revolve in circle,

\(V_{\text {top }}=v_{1}=\sqrt{r g}\)

\(V_{\text {bott }}=v_{2}=\sqrt{5 r g}\)

The difference in kinetic energy,

\(\Delta E=(K . E)_{\text {bott }}-(K . E)_{\text {top }} \)

\(\Delta=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right)\)

\(\Delta=\frac{1}{2} m(5 r g-r g)=\frac{4 m r g}{2}\)

\(\Delta E=\frac{4 \times 1 \times 1 \times 10}{2}\)

\(\Delta E=20 J\)

A mass \(m\) is attached to the end of a rod of length \(I\). The mass goes around a vertical circular path with the other end hinged at the centre. What should be the minimum velocity of mass at the bottom of the circle, so that the mass completes the circle?

At top most point speed of the body may be zero because rod will support the body there.

Applying energy conservation at lowest point,

\(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=0+m g(2 l) \text { or } v=\sqrt{4 g l}\)

Hence, the correct option is (A).

An isolated particle of mass \(m\) is moving in a horizontal plane \((x-y)\), along the \(x\)-axis, at a certain height above the ground. It suddenly explodes into two fragments of masses \(\mathrm{m} / 4\) and \(3 \mathrm{~m} / 4\). An instant later, the smaller fragment is at \(y=+15 \mathrm{~cm}\). The larger fragment at this instant is at:

Before explosion particle was moving along \(x\)-axis i.e. it has no \(y\) component of velocity. Therefore the centre of mass will not move in \(y\)-direction or we can say \(y_{\mathrm{cm}}=0\)

Now \(y_{c m}=\frac{m_{1} y_{1}+m_{2} y_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\)

\(0=\frac{\left(\frac{m}{4}\right)(+15)+\left(\frac{3 m}{4}\right) y}{\left(\frac{m}{4}+\frac{3 m}{4}\right)} \)

\(\Rightarrow y=-5 c m\)

A bullet of mass \(10 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~kg}\) moving with a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) hits an ice block \(\left(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\) of \(990 \mathrm{~g}\) kept at rest on a frictionless floor and gets embedded in it. If ice takes \(50 \%\) of KE lost by the system, the amount of ice melted (in grams) approximately is: \((\mathrm{J}=4.2 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{cal})\) (Latent heat of ice \(=80 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{g}\) )

Kinetic energy of the bullet is \(=\frac{1}{2} \times m \times v^{2}=2 J\)

Now half of it is used by the ice to melt it, i.e. \(1 J=\frac{1}{4.2} c a l\)

Latent heat of the ice is \(L=80 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{gram}\).

Let \(M\) is the amount of ice melts.

\(M \times L=\frac{1}{4.2} \)

\(M=0.003 g m=3 \times 10^{-3}\)

And ice will only melt. The temperature will be same.

A particle is placed at the origin and a force \(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{Kx}\) is acting on it (where \(\mathrm{K}\) is positive constant). If \(U(0)=0\), the graph of \(U(x)\) versus \(x\) will be (where \(u\) is potential energy function)

\(\text { From, } F=-\frac{d U}{d x}\)

\(d U=-F d x \)

\(U=\int_{0}^{u(x)} d U=-\int_{0}^{x} F d x \)

\(=-\int_{0}^{c} k x d x \)

\(U=-\frac{k x}{2}\)

As, \(U(0)=0, \alpha x^{2}\) (where \(\alpha\) is a constant) and \(U\) are negative.
A body of mass \(m\), accelerates uniformly from rest to \(V_{1}\) in time \(t_{1}\). The instantaneous power after time \(t\) is:

Using first equation of motion, velocity after time \(t_{1}\) is given by:

\(V_{1}=a t_{1}\)

Similarly, velocity after time \(t\) is:

\(v=a t=\frac{V_{1} t}{t_{1}}\)

Power is given by: \(P=F v=\) mav

\(P=m\left(\frac{V_{1}}{t_{1}}\right) \times\left(\frac{V_{1} t}{t_{1}}\right) \)

\(=\frac{m V_{1}^{2} t}{t_{1}^{2}}\)

The potential energy of a conservative system is given by \(U=a y^{2}-b y\), where \(y\) represents the position of the particle, both a and \(b\) are constants. What is the force acting on the system?

As we know,

\(F=-\frac{d U}{d y} \)

\(F=-\frac{d\left(a y^{2}-b y\right)}{d y} \)

\(F=b-2 a y\)
If at the highest point of parabolic path kinetic energy is equal to potential energy, the angle of projection would be:

At highest point, velocity is only in horizontal direction which is \(v_{x}=v \cos \theta\)

So, \(K E=\frac{1}{2} m v_{x}^{2}\) (at highest point)

PE at highest point \(=m g h_{\max }\)

\(=m g \frac{v^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}{2 g}\)

\(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta=m g \frac{v^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}{2 g}\)

\(\tan \theta=1\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=45^{\circ}\)
Calculate the kinetic energy of a body of mass \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) moving with a velocity \(2 m s^{-1}\).

As we know,

The kinetic energy of a body,

\(K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \)

\(=\frac{1}{2}(10)(2)^{2}=20 J\)
A truck and a car moving with same kinetic energy are stopped by equal retarding force. Which of them will be stopped in shorter distance?

Kinetic energy lost by both before coming to rest is same. Also, the retarding force is same. From work energy theorem,

\(\Delta K E=F \times S\)

Since, \(\triangle K E\) and \(F\) are same, so \(S\) is same.
A ball tied to a string is swung in a vertical circle. Which of the following remains constant?

Earth's pull on the ball remains constant (W=mg).

Tension in the string changes along the vertical circular path.

Speed of the ball changes as sum of kinetic energy and potential energy remains constant during motion.

Speed changes, so, centripetal force changes.
If \(\mathrm{F}\) is a force and \(\mathrm{d}\) is the displacement in the direction of force then the work done by the force is given by:

Work done \(=\) force in the direction of displacement multiplied by displacement

\(W=\vec{F} \cdot \vec{d}\)
In which case is the work done zero?
Force and displacement are at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\)
Eorce and displacement are in the same direction
Force and displacement are perpendicular to each other
Force and displacement are at an angle of \(75^{\circ}\)

Work done \(=\) Force \(\times\) displacement i.e \(\mathrm{W}=\) F.x \(\cos \theta\) where \(\theta\) is the displacement angle

\(W=F . \operatorname{Cos} 90=o\) (Since \(\operatorname{Cos} 90\) degree is equal to zero)

So, when the force applied and displacement of the body are inclined at 90 degree's with each other work done is zero.

In International System of Units (SI) the newton is the unit for force. It is equal to the amount of net force required to accelerate a mass of one kilogram at a rate of \(1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}^{2}\) in direction of the applied force. It is named after Isaac Newton in recognition of his work on classical mechanics, specifically Newton's second law of motion.

The area under the force-displacement curve represents the work done.

It is the distance (s) of the object displaced by the application of the force (f). In this case force (f) is presented on the y-axis and displacement (s) on the x-axis.

The work done (w) is a scalar quantity.

Hence, the correct option is (D).
In the arrangement shown in the figure below, the strings are light and inextensible. The surface over which the blocks are placed is smooth. What is the acceleration of each block?

let tension in string attached to it be \(\mathrm{S}\) then \(14-\mathrm{S}=\mathrm{a}\)

A constant force acts on a body of mass \(\mathrm{m}_{1}\) which is at rest and produces a velocity 'v' over a displacement \(\mathrm{s}_{1}\). The same force acts on another body of mass \(\mathrm{m}_{2}\) at rest and produces the same velocity 'v' over a displacement \(\mathrm{s}_{2}\). The ratio of the displacements, \(\mathrm{s}_{1}: \mathrm{s}_{2}\) is:

The acceleration of the first body, \(a_{1}=\frac{F}{m_{1}}\)

The acceleration of the first body, \(a_{2}=\frac{F}{m_{2}}\)

We know that, \(v^{2}=2\)as

\(\Rightarrow 2 \times \frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{m}_{1}} \times \mathrm{s}_{1}=\mathrm{v}^{2}=2 \times \frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{m}_{2}} \times \mathrm{s}_{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \times \frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{m}_{1}} \times \mathrm{s}_{1}=2 \times \frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{m}_{1}} \times \mathrm{s}_{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{s_{1}}{s_{2}}=\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}}\)

A disc of radius r = 20 cm is rotating about its axis with an angular speed of 20 rad s–1. It is gently placed on a horizontal surface which is perfectly frictionless (as shown in the figure). What is the linear speed of point A on the disc?

A disc of radius \(=10 \mathrm{~cm}=0.1 \mathrm{~m}\)

Angular velocity \(=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}\)

Linear velocity on the rim \(=\omega r=20 \times 0.1=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Linear velocity at the middle of radius \(=\omega r / 2=20 \times(0.1) / 2=1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).
The v-t graph of a linear motion is shown in adjoining figure. What is the distance from origin after 8 seconds?

To find the disfance from the origin after 8 secs.

\(s=\frac{d v}{d t}\int d v=\int s d t \quad v=\int s d t\)

Area of \(v\)-t graph \(\Rightarrow\) Displacement

Qistance from origin \(=A_{1}-A_{2}\)

\(A_{1}=\frac{1}{2}(6)(4)\)

\(A_{2}=\frac{1}{2}(6)(2)\)

Dishance \(=\frac{1}{2}(6)(4)-\frac{1}{2}(6)(2)\)

\(=6 \mathrm{~m}\)

Two stones of masses \(m\) and \(2 m\) are whirled in horizontal circles, the heavier one in a radius \(\frac{r}{2}\) and the lighter one in radius \(r\). The tangential speed of lighter stone is \(n\) times that of the value of heavier stone when they experience same centripetal forces. The value of \(n\) is:

Let v be tangential speed of heavier stone.

Then, centripetal force experienced by lighter stone is 

\(\left(F_{c}\right)_{\text {lighter }}=\frac{m(n v)^{2}}{r}\)

and that of heavier stone is

\(\left(F_{c}\right)_{\text {heavier }}=\frac{2 m v^{2}}{(\frac{r}{2})}\)

But \(\left(F_{c}\right)_{\text {lighter }}=\left(F_{c}\right)_{\text {heavier }}\) (given)

\(\therefore \frac{m(n v)^{2}}{r}=\frac{2 m v^{2}}{(\frac{r}{2})}\)

\(n^{2}\left(\frac{m v^{2}}{r}\right)=4\left(\frac{m v^{2}}{r}\right)\)

\(n^{2}=4\) or \(n=2\)
A particle moves in a circle of radius 25 cm at the rate of two revolutions per second. The acceleration of particle is:
The pulleys and the strings shown in the figure are smooth and of negligible mass. For the system to remain in equilibrium, angle θ should be:

For block A, T-mg \(=m(0)\)

For block B, T-mg \(=\mathrm{m}(\mathrm{0})\)

(Since the both A and B blocks are similar and tension in the strings are mg. It has zero acceleration, as system is in equilibrium). 

So, \(2 \mathrm{~T} \cos \theta=\sqrt{2} \mathrm{mg}\)

\(2 \mathrm{mg} \operatorname{Cos} \theta=\sqrt{2} \mathrm{mg}\)

\(\theta=45^{\circ}\)
A body is dropped from height h. If the coefficient of restitution is e, then calculate the height achieved after one bounce.

When a body falls from height h, it strikes the ground with a velocity \(v=\sqrt{2 g h}\). Let it rebounced with a velocity v and rise to a height \(h_{1}\).

\(v=\sqrt{2 g h_{1} \Rightarrow e=\frac{v}{u}=\left(\sqrt{\frac{h_{1}}{h}}\right.}\)

Clearly, \(h_{1}=e^{2} h\)

A motor cyclist moving with a velocity of \(72 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\) on a flat road takes a turn on the road at a point where the radius of curvature of the road is 20 meters. \(=72 \times \frac{5}{18}=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Let the motorcyclist bends w.r.t vertical plane by angle \(\theta\)

To avoid skidding, \(\frac{\mathrm{v}^{2}}{\mathrm{gR}} \geq \tan \theta\)

\(\therefore \tan \theta \leq \frac{20^{2}}{10 \times 20}\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta \leq \tan ^{-1}(2)\)

Two masses \(\mathrm{M}\) and \(\frac{M}{2}\) are joined together by means of the light inextensible string passed over a frictionless pulley as shown in the figure.aWhen bigger mass is released the small one will ascend with an acceleration:

\(M\) is going down let acceleration be a

\((\frac{M}{r})\) is going up let acceleration be \(+a\) (magnitude of acceleration is same)

For \(\mathrm{M}_{3} \mathrm{~T}-\mathrm{Mg}=-\mathrm{Ma}\)  ...(1)

For \(\frac{M}{2}, T-(\frac{M}{2}) g=(\frac{M}{2})\)  ...(2)

Equation \((2)-(1)\)

\((\frac{-M}{2}) g+M g=(\frac{M}{2}) a+M a\)

\((\frac{Mg}{2})=(\frac{3}{2}) Ma\)

\(g=3 a\)

An ice cart of mass 60 kg rests on a horizontal snow patch with coefficient of static friction \(\frac{1}{3}\). Assuming that there is no vertical acceleration, find the magnitude of the minimum horizontal force required to move the ice cart. (g = 9.8ms-2):

Force applied against friction is

\(f_{k}=\mu_{k} R\)

\(=\mu_{k} m g\)

\(=\frac{1}{3} \times 60 \times 9.8\)

\(=196 \mathrm{~N}\)
A car of mass 800 kg moves on a circular track of radius 40 m. If the coefficient of friction is 0.5, then the maximum velocity with which the car can move is:

When a car goes round a curved road, it requires some centripetal force. While rounding the curve, the wheels of the car have a tendency to leave the curved path and regain the straight line path. Force of friction between the wheels and the mad opposes this tendency of the wheels. This force (of friction) therefore acts, towards the centre of the circular track and provides the necessary centripetal force.

\(\therefore \frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}} \leq \mu \mathrm{mg}\)

\(\mathrm{v}^{2} \leq \mu \mathrm{rg}\)

\(\mathrm{v} \leq \sqrt{\mu \mathrm{rg}}\)

Hence, the maximum velocity with which a vehicle can go round a level curve, without a skidding is \(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\mu \mathrm{rg}}\)

Here, \(r=40 \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\mu=0.5\)

\(\therefore v=\sqrt{0.5 \times 40 \times 9.8}\)

\(=14 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

A block of mass 2 kg is placed on the surface of a trolley of mass 20 kg, which is on a smooth surface. The coefficient of friction between the block and the surface of the trolley is 0.25. If a horizontal force of 2 N acts on the block, then the acceleration of the system (in ms-2) (g = 10 ms-2) is:

Maximum possible acceleration of \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) is \(\mathrm{a}=.25 \mathrm{~g}=2.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

Common acceleration of system \(\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{2}{22}=0.09 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

So they will move with acceleration of \(0.09 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)
If a car is to travel with a speed v along the frictionless, banked circular track of radius r, the required angle of banking so that the car does skid is:

Here θ is the angle of banking 

\(\mathrm{N} \cos \theta=\mathrm{mg}......(i)\)

\(\mathrm{N} \sin \theta=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}}.......(ii)\)

Dividing equation (ii) by (i), we get

\(\tan \theta=\frac{\mathrm{V}^{2}}{1 \mathrm{~g}}\)

A car is moving in a circular horizontal track of radius \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) with a constant speed of \(10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). A plumb bob is suspended from the roof of the car by a light rigid rod. The angle made by the rod with the vertical is:

Hence from the figure,

We know that,

\(\mathrm{T} \sin \theta=\frac{\mathrm{mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}} \quad[\) centripetal \(] \longrightarrow\) (i)

\(\mathrm{T} \cos \theta=\mathrm{mg} \quad \longrightarrow\) (ii) (force)

from (i) and (ii)

\(\frac{\mathrm{T} \sin \theta}{\mathrm{T} \cos \theta}=\frac{\mathrm{mv}}{\mathrm{r}} \times \frac{1}{\mathrm{mg}}\)

\(\tan \theta=\frac{\mathrm{V}^{2}}{1 \mathrm{~g}}\)

Given that, radius \(=10 \mathrm{~m}\)

velocity \(=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

\(\tan \theta=\frac{10^{2}}{10 \times 10}=1\)

\(\theta=45^{\circ}\)

A frictionless track ABCDE ends in a circular loop of radius R. A body slides down the track from point A which is at a height h = 5 cm. What is the maximum value of R for the body to successfully complete the loop?

From the conservation of energy,

\(\mathrm{mgh}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{gh}}\)

The condition for completing the loop is given as,

\(\sqrt{2 \mathrm{gh}}=\sqrt{5 \mathrm{gR}}\)

\(R=\frac{2 \times 5}{5}\)

= 2cm

Thus, the maximum value of R for the body to successfully complete the loop is 2 cm.

A elevator car whose floor to ceiling distance is \(2.7 \mathrm{~m}\) starts ascending with a constant acceleration of \(1.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}, 2 \mathrm{~s}\) after the start a bolt is begin to fall from the ceiling of the car. The free fall time of the bolt is \(\left(g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\):

Net acceleration on the elevator car is more than acceleration due to gravity.

Since elevator car is ascending upwards, from Newton's second law, the net force is acting upwards, hence resultant acceleration is

\(a_{r}=(8+a)\)

\(=(9.8+1.2)=11 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

Relative velocity of observer to elevator is

\(u_{\tau}=0\)

From the equation

\(s=u_{r} t+\frac{1}{2} a_{r} t^{2}\)

\(2.7=0+\frac{1}{2} \times 11 \times t^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow t^{2}=\frac{5.4}{11}\)

\(\Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{5.4}{11}} s\)

A body takes time \(t\) to reach the bottom of an inclined plane of angle \(\theta\) will the horizontal. if the plane made rough, time takes now is \(2 \mathrm{t}\). The coefficient of frcition of the rough surface is:

The free body diagram shows the various forces acting on the block. When plane is frictionless, then acceleration, \(a=g\) sin \(\theta\).

Let time taken is \(t_{1}\) Since body starts from rest, initial velocity \(u=0\)

\(\therefore s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t_{1}^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow s=\frac{1}{2} g \sin \theta t_{1}^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow t_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 s}{g \sin \theta}}\)

When plane is made rough, then acceleration \(a=g(\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta)\), where \(\mu\) is coefficient of friction.

\(\therefore t_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 s}{g(\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta)}}\)

Given, \(t_{2}=2 t_{1}\)

\(\therefore \sqrt{\frac{2 s}{g(\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta)}}\)

\(=2 \sqrt{\frac{2 s}{g \sin \theta}}\)

\(\therefore \frac{1}{\sin \theta-\mu \cos \theta}=\frac{4}{\sin \theta}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sin \theta=4 \sin \theta-4 \mu \cos \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \mu=\frac{3}{4} \tan \theta\)

A block is placed on an inclined plane. The angle of inclination (\(\theta)\) of the plane is such that the block slides down the plane at a constant speed. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the inclined plane is equal to:

When the block slides down the plane with a constant speed, then the inclination of plane is equal to the angle of response (\(\theta)\)

Co-efficient of friction \(=\tan\) of the angle response \(=\tan \theta\)
Second law in terms of momentum p and mass m is
Applied force is directly proportional to rate of change of momentum.
second law of motion  in terms of acceleration a⃗  and mass m of a body is
The second law states that the rate of change of momentum of a body is directly proportional to the force applied, and this change in momentum takes place in the direction of the applied force.
The vector sum of all the forces acting on a body is zero.

A  smooth inclined plane of length L having an inclination with the horizontal is inside a lift which is moving down with a retardation a. The time taken by a body to slide down the inclined plane from rest will be:

Here downward retardation means upward acceleration i.e \(\mathrm{g}^{\prime}=\mathrm{g}+\) a 

The acceleration of the body along incline \(\mathrm{a}^{\prime}=\mathrm{g}^{\prime} \sin \theta=(\mathrm{g}+\mathrm{a}) \sin \theta\) using \(S=u t+(\frac{1}{2}) a t^{2} \Rightarrow L=0+(1 / 2)(g+a) \sin \theta t^{2}\) 

or \(t=\sqrt{\frac{2 L}{g+a) \sin \theta}}\)
A block is sliding along inclined plane as shown in figure. If the acceleration of chamber is a, as shown in the figure. The time required to cover a distance L along incline is:

The net acceleration along the incline will be \(\mathrm{a}_{\text {effective }}=\mathrm{a} \cos \theta+\mathrm{g} \sin \theta\)

The time required will be \(L=0 \times t+\frac{1}{2} {\text {aeffective }} t^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{~L}}{a_{\text {effective }}}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{~L}}{\mathrm{a} \cos \theta+\mathrm{g} \sin \theta}}\)
A smooth rod of length l is kept inside a trolley at an angle θ as shown in the figure. What should be the acceleration a of the trolley so that the end remains in equilibrium with respect to it?

Equating the force,

\(\mathrm{N}=\mathrm{mg}\)

\(\mathrm{N}^{\prime}=\mathrm{ma}\)

taking moment about point A.

\(\mathrm{mg} \frac{1}{2} \cos \theta+m a \frac{1}{2} \sin \theta=N^{\prime} l \sin \theta\)

\(g \cos \theta+a \sin \theta=2 a \sin \theta\)

\(\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{g} \cot \theta\)
In an electromagnetic wave in free space the root mean square value of the electric field is \(E_{r m s}=6 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m}^{-1}\). The peak value of the magnetic field is:
Out of the following options which one can be used to produce a propagating electromagnetic wave?

An electric charge at rest will produce an electric field around it while a moving charge will produce an electric as well as magnetic field around it.

The electromagnetic waves are produced when there is a sudden change in the electric and magnetic field of a moving charge.

A stationary charge cannot produce the electromagnetic waves as its electric field stays constant while it is at rest. A charge moving at constant velocity also cannot produce electromagnetic waves as the constant motion means that there is no change in the electric and magnetic field of the moving charge.

The electromagnetic waves are produced only when an electric charge undergoes acceleration or deceleration. The change in the electric and the magnetic field of the charge on acceleration or deceleration is manifested in the form of electromagnetic waves.
Which among the following is the incorrect statement regarding displacement current?
The SI unit of displacement current is ampere.
Displacement current associated with the change in electric field through closed conducting loop.
Displacement current is due to flow of electrons in a current.

Displacement Current:

  • The idea of displacement current was firstly developed by famous physicist James Maxwell. 
  • The displacement current produces due to the change in electric flux (number of electric field lines through a cross-sectional area of a closed-loop) with respect to time.
  • The SI unit of displacement current is Ampere.  
  • The magnitude of displacement current is zero in the case of steady electric fields in conducting wire.
  • The idea of displacement current was introduced to the current for making ampere circuital law consistent.

Therefore, out of all the given statements, Only the statement of option (C) is incorrect.
In case of steady electric field in between region of the parallel plate capacitor. The magnitude of displacement current is:

In the case of a steady electric field, the electric field does not change with time. Therefore, the electric flux density through a closed-loop will be constant.

This results in zero change in electric flux with respect to time i.e.,

\( \frac{d \phi_{E}}{d t}=0\)

The displacement current will be:

\( i_{d}=\epsilon_{0} \frac{d \phi_{E}}{d t}=0\)
Calculate the displacement current between square plates in which electric field changes at the rate of \(5 \times 10^{12} {Vm}^{-1} {~s}^{-1}\). Side of plates is \(2.0 {~cm}\).

Given: 

Change in an electric field, \(\frac{d E}{d t}=5 \times 10^{12} {Vm}^{-1} s^{-1}\), 

Side of the plate (I) \(=2\) \({cm}=2 \times 10^{-2} {~m}\), 

and \(\epsilon_{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} C^{2} N^{-1} {~m}^{-2}\)

The area of the plate is:

Area of square \(=(\text{side})^2\)

\( A=2 \times 10^{-2} \times 2 \times 10^{-2}=4 \times 10^{-4} {~m}\)

We know that displacement current is given as:

\( I_{d}=\epsilon_{0} A \times \frac{d E}{d t}\)

\( I_{d}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 4 \times 10^{-4} \times 5 \times 10^{12}\)
