\( I_{d}=17.7 {~m}\)

What is the value of instantaneous displacement current in the free space between parallel plate capacitor of capacitance \(1 \mu F\) and the rate of changing potential difference maintain between plates is \(10^{6} {~V} / {s} ?\)

Given: 

Capacitance, (C) \(=1 \mu {F}\), 

Rate of change in voltage, \(\frac{d V}{d t}=10^{6} {~V} / {s}\)

The expression for displacement current \({i}_{{d},}\) in the case of capacitance is given as:

\( i_{d}=\frac{d q}{d t}\)\(\quad\).....(i)

As we also know that, the charge on the capacitor is:

\( {q}={CV}\)

Where q = charge on the capacitors

On substituting the value of q = CV in equation (i), we get,

\( i_{d}=C \frac{d V}{d t}\)\(\quad\).....(ii)

On substituting the given values in equation (ii), we get,

\( i_{d}=\left(10^{-6} \times 10^{6}\right) A\)

\( {i}_{{d}}=1 {~A}\)

Given: 

\(\phi_{E}=\left(10 t^{2}-20 t+5\right) V m\)

We know that:

The expression for displacement current is given by,

\( i_{d}=\epsilon_{0} \frac{d \phi_{E}}{d t}\)

\( i_{d}=\epsilon_{0} \frac{d\left(10 t^{2}-20 t+5\right)}{d t}\)

\( i_{d}=0\)

Electromagnetic waves are the transverse waves.

Transverse Waves: 

  • Those waves whose direction of propagation and direction of disturbance is always perpendicular, are known as transverse waves.
  • These waves produced in a medium that can sustain shearing strain.
  • Example: Electromagnetic Waves, Ripples on the surface of water, Vibrations in a guitar string.

Electromagnetic waves are generated by accelerated charge.

  • An accelerating charge produces a changing electric field which in turn produces a magnetic field. These alternatively changing magnetic and electric field give rise to electromagnetic waves.
  • Whereas, the static force generate only electric field and moving particle generates only magnetic field.
The ratio of amplitude of magnetic field to the amplitude of electric field for an electromagnetic wave propagating in vacuum is equal to:
Reciprocal of speed of light in vacuum
The ratio of magnetic permeability to the electric susceptibility of vacuum

A magnetic field is a vector quantity that describes the magnetic influence or an electric charge of another moving charge. A charge that is a magnetic field that is perpendicular to its own velocity and magnetic field.

Electric fields surround an electric charge and exert force on the charge of electric fields attracting or repelling it.

Electric field and magnetic field both are interrelated to each other and both are components of electromagnetic waves.

We know that,

\(\Rightarrow C=\frac{E_{0}}{B_{0}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{B_{0}}{E_{0}}=\frac{1}{C}\)

Therefore, the ratio of amplitude of magnetic field to the amplitude of electric field for an electromagnetic wave in a vacuum is equal to the reciprocal of speed of light.

does not give energy but exerts pressure.

What is the speed of electromagnetic waves in terms of dielectric constant and vacuum permeability?

Electromagnetic waves: It is a transverse wave defined as composed of oscillating electrical and magnetic fields perpendicular to each other.

The speed of electromagnetic waves is the same as of speed of light, i.e., \(c=3 \times 10^{8}\) \({m} / {s}\)

Mathematically, 

Speed of \(E M W=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{0} \mu_{0}} }=3 \times 10^{8} {~m} / {s}\)

Or, the relation between the speed of electromagnetic wave and dielectric constant and vacuum permeability is:

Speed of \(E M W=\frac{1}{\left(\epsilon_{0} \mu_{0}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}}\)

where,

\(\epsilon_{0}=8.854 \times 10^{-12} {~F} / {m}\) (vacuum permittivity or dielectric constant)

\(\mu_{0}=4 \pi \times 10^{-7} {H} / {m}\) \((\frac{\text{vacuum permeability}}{{\text{magnetic constant}}})\)
Which of the following statement is false for the properties of electromagnetic waves?
These waves do not require any material medium for propagation.
Both electric and magnetic field vectors attains the maxima and minima at the same place and same time.
The energy in electromagnetic wave is divided equally between electric and magnetic vectors.
Both electric and magnetic field vectors are parallel to each other and perpendicular to the direction of propagation of wave.

Electromagnetic waves or EM waves: The waves that are formed as a result of vibrations between an electric field and a magnetic field and they are perpendicular to each other and to the direction of the wave is called an electromagnetic wave.

Electromagnetic waves do not require any matter to propagate from one place to another as it consists of photons. They can move in a vacuum.

Properties of electromagnetic waves:

  • Not have any charge or we can say that they are neutral.
  • Propagate as a transverse wave.
  • They move with the velocity the same as that of light i.e., \(3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).
  • It contains energy and they also contain momentum.
  • They can travel in a vacuum also.

From above, it is clear that, electromagnetic waves do not require any matter to propagate from one place to another as it consists of photons. Therefore, statement in option (A) is correct.

In an electromagnetic wave, the electric field and magnetic field vary continuously with maxima and minima at the same place and same time. Therefore, statement in option (B) is correct.

The energy in an electromagnetic wave is divided equally between electric and magnetic fields. Therefore, statement in option (C) is correct. 

An electromagnetic wave is a perpendicular variation in both the electric field (E) and Magnetic field (B). Therefore, statement in option (D) is incorrect.
The propagation of electromagnetic waves is along the direction of:
Dot product of electric field and magnetic field.
Cross product of electric field and magnetic field.

Since both electric and magnetic fields are vectors, the direction of propagation of EM waves is obtained from the right-hand rule.

Let the electric field be denoted by \(\vec{E}\) and magnetic field be denoted by \(\vec{B}\).

According to the rule - If the fingers of the right hand are curled so that they follow a rotation from \(\vec{E}\) to \(\vec{B}\), then the thumb will point in the direction of the vector product i.e., the direction of EM waves.

Therefore, the direction of EM waves is found from the cross product of the electric field and magnetic field.
The phase difference between the electric field and the magnetic field in the electromagnetic wave is:

The phase difference between the electric field and the magnetic field in the electromagnetic wave is zero.

  • The electric field and the magnetic field components of an electromagnetic wave oscillate in such a way that they have their peak at the same time and also become zero at the same time.
  • Since there is no time difference between the peaks of the electric and the magnetic field, so the phase difference between the electric and the magnetic field of the electromagnetic wave is zero.

Infrared radiation was discovered in 1800 by William Herschel.

  • He did so with a simple experiment in which he dispersed sunlight through a prism and placed a thermometer at the location of each colour. 
  • He noticed that the thermometer temperature increased when he did this, which was not really unexpected since sunlight carries warmth.
  • However when he placed the thermometer past the red end of the spectrum – where there was no visible sunlight – the thermometer’s temperature still increased! 
  • Herschel had discovered infrared radiation – radiation beyond the red end of the visible spectrum. 
  • Wavelength: 700 nanometers to 1 millimeter.
Among the following which electromagnetic waves have the wavelength range of 700 nm to 400 nm?

Light waves have the the wavelength range of 700 nm to 400 nm.

  • Light or visible light is electromagnetic radiation within the portion of the electromagnetic spectrum that can be perceived by the human eye. 
  • Visible light is usually defined as having wavelengths in the range of \(400-700\) nanometers \(({nm})\), or \(4.00 \times 10^{-7}\) to \(7.00 \times 10^{-7} {~m}\), between the infrared (with longer wavelengths) and the ultraviolet (with shorter wavelengths). 
  • This wavelength means a frequency range of roughly \(430-750\) terahertz \(({THz})\).

Radio waves, infrared rays, visible light, ultraviolet rays, X-rays, and gamma rays are all types of electromagnetic radiation.

  • Radio waves have the longest wavelength, and gamma rays have the shortest wavelength.
  • After radio waves, infrared waves has the longest wavelength among the others.

Spectrum of X-rays is continuous and linear. 

  • In an X-ray tube, when high-speed electrons strike the target they penetrate to the target.
  • The electrons lose their kinetic energy and come to rest inside the metal.
  • The electron before finally being stopped makes several collisions with the atom in the target. At each collision, one of the following two types of X-rays get formed
  • Continuous X-rays
  • Characteristic X-rays
  • ​Due to continuous X-rays, the spectrum will be continuous.
  • ​Due to characteristic X-rays, the spectrum will be linear.

So, the spectrum of X-rays is continuous and linear.
Which of the following remains same for all electromagnetic waves?

Electromagnetic spectrum is the arrangement of electromagnetic radiations according to their frequency or wavelength.

f = cλ 

As we go from gamma rays to radio waves, the frequency decreases, and the wavelength increases.

Therefore, the velocity (c = 3 × 108 m/s) is constant.

An electron is accelerated from rest to potential V. The final velocity of the electron is

When a charged particle is accelerated by an electric field (uniform or non-uniform), by work energy theorem, ΔKE=W, we have

\(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}=q V \quad(\because W=q V)\)

For electron,

\(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}=\mathrm{eV}\)

or \(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\left(u^{2}+\frac{2 \mathrm{eV}}{m}\right)}\)

If electron is initially at rest, u=0

\(v=\sqrt{\left(\frac{2 \mathrm{eV}}{\mathrm{m}}\right)}\)

Note: If field is uniform, \(\mathrm{E}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{d}}\right)\)

\(\therefore v=\sqrt{\left(\frac{2 e E d}{m}\right)}\)

Mass equivalent to an energy of 931 MeV is

Here, we are given the energy in the MeV unit and we are being asked to find its mass equivalent. So, we will first convert the energy in joules and then use the equation that relates mass to the energy.

- eV stands for electron volts and it is related with SI unit joule as follows. We know that charge on one electron

is \(1.6 \times 10^{-19} C\). So,

\(1 \mathrm{eV}=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{~J}\)

And M in MeV stands for mega and we can say that 1000eV = 1MeV. So, we can say that

\(931 \mathrm{MeV}=931 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 10^{6} J=1489.6 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~J}\)

Now, we have the energy in the joule unit which is the SI unit. So, now we can use the mass-energy relation equation.

- Scientist Albert Einstein gave the relation between the mass and the energy. The formula is:

\(E=m c^{2}\)

Where \(E=\) Energy

\(\mathrm{m}=\) mass and \(\mathrm{c}=\) velocity of the light in vacuum \(=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

- We know the energy and velocity of light in vacuum. So, we can find the mass equivalent to that energy. So, putting available values in the equation (1), we get

\(1489.6 \times 10^{-13}=m \times\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}\)

So, we can write that

\(m=\frac{1489.6 \times 10^{-13}}{9 \times 10^{16}}=165.51 \times 10^{-29} \mathrm{~kg}=1.6 \times 10^{-27 \mathrm{~kg}}\)

Thus, we can conclude that mass equivalent to the energy of \(931 \mathrm{MeV}\) is \(1.6 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\).

For ionising an excited hydrogen atom, the magnitude of energy required (in eV) will be

The ionization energy (IE) of an atom describes the minimum amount of energy required to remove an electron (to infinity) from the atom.

For the electron in ground state i.e. n = 1, the ionization energy is

\(\mathrm{IE}_{1}=\mathrm{E}_{\infty}-\mathrm{E}_{1}\)

\(\mathrm{IE}_{1}=0-(-13.6) \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots(\) since, ground state energy is \-13.6 \mathrm{eV}\)

\(\mathrm{IE}_{1}=13.6 \mathrm{eV}\)

For the electron in first excited state i.e. \(n=2\), the ionization energy is

\(\mathrm{IE}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{IE}}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}\)

\(\mathrm{IE}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{IE}_{1}}{2^{2}}\)

\(\mathrm{IE}_{2}=\frac{13.6}{4}=3.4 \mathrm{eV}\)

For the electron in second excited state i.e. \(\mathrm{n}=3\), the ionization energy is

\(\mathrm{IE}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{IE}_{1}}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}\)

\(I E_{2}=\frac{I E_{1}}{3^{2}}\)

\(\mathrm{IE}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{IE}_{1}}{3^{2}}\)

\(\mathrm{IE}_{2}=\frac{13.6}{9}=1.51 \mathrm{eV}\) and so on.

Hence, the ionisation energy for excited hydrogen atom will be \(3.4 \mathrm{eV}\) or less than it.

Ernest Rutherford who was a former research student of JJ Thomson supervised the experiment carried by two of his students Hans Geiger and Ernst Marsden. Rutherford felt that there existed a nucleus at the centre of the atom having positive charge and thus proposed the Rutherford model.
What is the unit of mass when measured on the atomic scale?
The unified atomic mass unit (u) is defined as one twelfth of the mass of an unbound neutral atom of carbon-12 in its nuclear and electronic ground state and at rest.
Atomic mass unit (u) is defined as ________ of the mass of the carbon (12C) atom.

For standardization, a specific atomic nucleus (carbon-12) had to be chosen because the average mass of a nucleon depends on the count of the nucleons in the atomic nucleus due to mass defect. This is also why the mass of a proton or neutron by itself is more than (and not equal to) 1 u.
A proton, an electron, and an antineutrino

Relation between atomic number (Z), neutron number (N) and mass number (A) is
mass number (A) = total number of nucleons = number of protons + number of nutrons = atomic number (Z) + neutron number (N)
The nuclei of isotopes of a given element contain the same number of
Isotopes are variants of a particular chemical element which differ in neutron number. All isotopes of a given element have the same number of protons in each atom.
All nuclides with same mass number A are called

These are the elements having same atomic number but different mass number. They have the same atomic number because the number of protons inside their nuclei remains the same. The difference in their mass number is due to the difference in their number of neutrons.
Nuclides with same neutron number N but different atomic numbers Z are called
Two nuclides are isotones if they have the same neutron number N, but different proton number Z. For example, boron-12 and carbon-13 nuclei both contain 7 neutrons, and so are isotones.

Always equal to the total mass of its individual protons and neutrons
Always greater than total mass of its individual protons and neutrons
Always less than total mass of its individual protons and neutrons

This is referred to as a mass defect. The mass defect of a nucleus is the difference between the mass of a nucleus and the sum of the masses of the nucleons that make it up, and it indicates the mass equivalent of the nucleus' binding energy.

A particle is moving eastwards with a velocity of 5 m/sec. If in 10s the velocity changes by 5 m/s northwards, what is the average acceleration in this time?

Let the north side is positive \(y\)-axis \((\hat{j})\) and the east side is positive \(x\)-axis \((\hat{i})\)

So, initial velocity \(v_{i}=5 \hat{i},\) final velocity \(v_{f}=5 \hat{j}, time~t =10\) s

We know that average acceleration \(\vec{a}\) is given as:

\(\vec{a}=\frac{\overrightarrow{\Delta v}}{\Delta t}\)

Where, \(\Delta v\) is change in velocity and \(\Delta t\) is change in time.

\(=\frac{\overrightarrow{v_{f}}-\overrightarrow{v_{i}}}{\Delta t}\)

\(=\frac{5 \hat{j}-5 \hat{i}}{10}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}(\hat{j}-\hat{i})\)

\(=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\) m/s\(^{2}\)

From its components, it is evident that the direction is north-west making 135 degrees with respect to the east.
A lady goes to a shop which is 2 km from her house. On reaching the shop she finds it locked and returns back home. Her final displacement would be:

Displacement is a vector quantity and can be obtained from the difference of position coordinates of the initial and final positions.

The lady starts the journey from her home (initial point) and reaches back to her home (final point) upon seeing the shop closed. Here, the initial and final point at the end of the journey is the same. So, the displacement is zero.
If the object is at rest, then the slope of position-time graph:

The rate of change of displacement of a body is called the velocity of that body.

Velocity is a vector quantity that has both magnitudes as well as direction.

The slope of the position-time graph gives velocity.

​Velocity (v) \(= \frac{dx}{dt}\)

Where, x is displacement or position and t is time.

The shortest path length between two points is called displacement.


Slope (m) = tanθ

Where, θ is the angle made by the curve with X-axis.

Given that the object is at rest. So the velocity of the object is zero.

Since, the slope of the position-time graph gives velocity and hence the slope will be zero.
If the velocity of an object is directly proportional to the time, then the object has:

The rate of change in velocity is called acceleration. The slope of a velocity-time graph gives the acceleration.

Given that:

v ∝ t

v = kt

Where, v is velocity, t is time, k is a constant.

Acceleration (a) = \(\frac{dv}{dt}\) = k = constant

Anything (that is velocity, acceleration, or speed) which is constant is called uniform (uniform velocity, uniform acceleration, or uniform speed).

Given:

\(v_{i}=54\) km/h \(=54 \times \left(\frac{5}{18}\right)=15\) m/s

\(v_{ f }=72\) km/h \(=72 \times\left(\frac{5}{18}\right)=20\) m/s

\(\Delta t = 5\) s

Where, \(v_{i}=\) Initial Velocity, \(v_{ f }=\) Final velocity, \(\Delta t =\) time

We know that:

Acceleration \(\vec{a}=\frac{\overrightarrow{\Delta v}}{\Delta t}=\frac{\overrightarrow{v_{f}}-\overrightarrow{v_{i}}}{\Delta t}\)

A balloon is rising with a velocity of 10 m/s. When it is at a height of 40 m above the earth, a packet is dropped from it. By what time it will take to reach the ground?

A balloon is rising with a velocity of \(10\) m/s. So when a packet is released its initial velocity will be the same as the ballon i.e., \(15\) m/s. So,

\(u =10\) ms\(^{-1}, s =-40\) m, \(a =- g =-10\) ms\(^{-2}\)

We know that:

\(s = ut +\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) at ^{2}\)

Where, \(u\) is initial velocity, \(a\) is constant acceleration, \(t\) is time and \(s\) is displacement.

\(-40=10 \times t +\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)(-10) t ^{2}\)

Solving equation \(t=-2\) (not possible) thus, we will take 4.

A 2 kg block and a 4 kg block are dropped from the same roof simultaneously. The ratio of time taken by them to reach the ground will be:

Let \(U_{1}=U_{2}=0\) m/s, \(h _{1}= h _{2}= h , a = g , S _{1}= S _{2}= h\)

The equations of motion of the two bodies is given by:

\(h=\frac{1}{2} g t_{1}^{2}\)

\(h=\frac{1}{2} g t_{2}^{2}\)

Where, \(h=\) height, \(g=\) acceleration due to gravity, \(t=\) time

Since, the time taken by both, the bodies are equal to reach the above equation can be rewritten for \(t\) as,

\(t_{1}=t_{2}=t=\sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}}\)

According to the equation of motion, \(V=U+g t\), the two bodies equation of motion can be written as,

\(V_{1}= gt\)

\(V _{2}= gt\)

Where, V is the final velocity and U is the initial velocity.

The ratio of \(V_{1}\) to \(V_{2}\) is given by,

\(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}=\frac{g t}{g t}=\frac{1}{1}\)

A particle moves on the circumference of a circle of radius r. Starting from one point particle reaches its diametric end in time t. The magnitude of the average velocity of the particle is:

According to the question it reaches its diametric end so if the particle starts from point A then it will reach to point B.

Displacement \(=2 r\)

A particle starting from rest and moving under constant force displaces by \(S_{1}\) in time t. It shall displace further by distance \(S _{2}\) in time from \(t\) to \(2 t\), then what is true?

Given: Initial velocity \(u =0\) m/s

We know that when the force is constant, the acceleration is also constant. The second equation of motion is given as,

\(S=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}\)

For time \(t\),

Displacement \(S = S _{1}\)

\(S_{1}=(0 \times t)+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}\)

Where, u is initial velocity and a is acceleration.

\(S_{1}=\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \quad \ldots\) (1)

For total time \(2 t\),

Displacement \(S=S _{1}+ S _{2}\)

\(S_{1}+S_{2}=(0 \times 2 t)+\frac{1}{2} a(2 t)^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow S_{1}+S_{2}=4 \frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \quad \ldots\) (2)

By equating equation (1) and equation (2), we get

\(S_{1}+S_{2}=4 S_{1}\)

\(\Rightarrow S_{2}=3 S_{1}\)

Aceleration vs velocity graph. Here, the graph shows a constant velocity for increased acceleration. However, acceleration the rate of change of velocity, and here there is no change in velocity. Thus, this is not a possible real motion.
Which one of the following statements is correct about magnitude of displacement?
It can be less than or equal to the distance travelled.
It is never equal to the distance travelled.
It is greater than the distance travelled.

The magnitude of displacement is equal to the minimum possible distance between two positions. So, distance ≥ Displacement.

For a moving particle, distance can never be negative or zero while displacement can be (Zero displacement means that body after motion has come back to initial position). i.e., Distance > 0 but Displacement > = or < 0.

For motion between two points displacement is single-valued while distance depends on the actual path and so can have many values.

For a moving particle, distance can never decrease with time while displacement can.

A decrease in displacement with time means the body is moving towards the initial position.
In a uniform motion, the speed time graph is:
A straight line parallel to the time axis.

If a body covers equal distance in equal intervals of time in a given direction then it is said to be moving with uniform motion.

In a uniform motion, an object moves with constant speed. So, its speed will remain the same during the whole motion. So, in a uniform motion, the speed time graph is a straight line parallel to the time axis.

A man went to a trip. When he started from his house, the odometer of his car reads 1500 km and the reading was 1860 km when he reached back home. If he took 1 hour for the journey, then what is the average velocity?

The man started his trip from his house and after completing the trip he reached back home. So, the initial and the final position of the man is the same, therefore, the displacement of the man is \(0\) m.

The velocity is given as,

\(v=\frac{d x}{dt}\)

Where, dx is displacement and dt is time.

\(d x=0\) m

\(d t=1\) hour \(=3600\) s

\(v=\frac{0}{3600}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=0\) m/s
Displacement time graph for a body cannot be _________.

For the displacement time graph:

The slope of the graph gives velocity (v).

\(v=\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}=\tan \theta\)

Option (A): A graph parallel to displacement axis gives slope \(=\infty\) as \(\theta=90^{\circ}\)

So, velocity for this will be infinite. \(\left(v=\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}=\tan 90=\infty\right)\)

But, it is impossible to gain infinite velocity.

So, this graph is not possible.

Option (B): A graph parallel to time axis gives slope \(=0\) as \(\theta=0^{\circ}\)

So, velocity for this will be zero. \(\left(v=\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}=\tan \theta\right)\)

So, this graph is also possible.

Option (C) and Option (D): A curve graph with negative or positive slope, gives velocity negative or positive respectively.

At a particular time, this will give some slope value (some value of velocity).

So, this graph is possible.
A boy travels a distance of 16 m from X to Y and then moves a distance of 12 m at right angles to XY. What are the distance travelled and the displacement?

Given: XY = 16 m and YZ = 12 m

The distance travelled by the boy is:

\(X Y+Y Z=16+12=28\) m

The shortest distance between point \(Z\) and \(X\) is:

\(X Z=\sqrt{X Y^{2}+Y Z^{2}}\)

\(=\sqrt{16^{2}+12^{2}}\)

\(=\sqrt{400}\)

\(=20\) m
If the displacement (s) of a body is directly proportional to square of time (t), then its acceleration:

It is given that \(s \propto t^{2}\)

\(s=k t^{2}\)

Where, s is displacement and t is time.

Differentiate the above equation with respect to time, then,

\(\frac{d(s)}{d t}=v=\frac{d\left(k t^{2}\right)}{d t}=2 k t\)

Therefore, velocity will be constant. Thus, option (A) is incorrect. Differentiate the above equation again with respect to time, then,

\(\frac{d(v)}{d t}=a=\frac{d(2 k t)}{d t}=2 k\)

Where, d(v) is speed and a is acceleration.

Therefore, acceleration will be constant.
A particle moves towards east for 2 sec with velocity 15 m/s and move towards north for 8 sec with velocity 5 m/s. Then average velocity of the particle is:

Given: Velocity of particle in east direction \(v _{ E }=15\) m/s, Time in east direction \(t _{ E }=2\) sec, Velocity of particle in north direction \(v _{ N }=5\) m/s, and Time in north direction \(t _{ N }=8\) sec.

Displacement in the east direction,

\(x_{E}=v_{E} \times t_{E}\)

\(\Rightarrow x_{E}=15 \times 2=30\) m

Displacement in the north direction,

\(x_{N}=v_{N} \times t_{N}\)

\(\Rightarrow x_{N}=5 \times 8=40\) m

Since, east and north direction are at \(90^{\circ}\) to each other, so the resultant displacement,

\(x=\sqrt{x_{E}^{2}+x_{N}^{2}+2 x_{E} x_{N} \cos \theta}\)

\(\Rightarrow x=\sqrt{30^{2}+40^{2}+2 \times 30 \times 40 \cos 90}\)

\(\Rightarrow x=50\) m

Total time is taken,

\(t=t_{E}+t_{N}\)

\(\Rightarrow t=2+8=10\) sec

Average velocity,

\(v=\frac{x}{t}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{50}{10}=5\) m/s

Acceleration of the body is non-zero and has magnitude is given as:

\(a=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)

Where, \(a\) is centripetal acceleration, \(v\) is speed and \(r\) is the radius.

From the above, it is clear that in a uniform circular motion the speed of the particle remains constant, therefore if a particle is moving along a circle with a uniform speed \(v\), then its speed will be the \(v\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\).

A boy standing on a \(20\) m tall building throws a stone horizontally with a speed of \(15\) m/s. With what speed will the stone hit the ground (in m/s)? (use \(g =10\) m/s\( ^{2})\)

Given: Horizontal velocity \(\left( u _{ x }\right)=15\) m/s and height \(=20\) m

The time \(t\) for stone to reach the ground,

\(t=\sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}}\)

Where, \(h=\) the position of the boy,

\(t=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 20}{10}}=2\) sec

Let \(v _{y}\) be the vertical (downward) component of velocity of the stone when it hits the ground, then

\(v_{y}^{2}=u_{y}^{2}+2 g h\)

\(\Rightarrow v_{y}^{2}=2 \times 10 \times 20=400\) m\(^{2}\)/s\(^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow v_{y}=20\) m/s

The final speed of the stone,

\(v=\sqrt{u_{x}^{2}+v_{y}^{2}}\)

\(=\sqrt{(20)^{2}+(15)^{2}}\)

\(=\sqrt{625}\)

\(=25\) m/s

Consider the following statements.

1. The Cross product of two vectors is known as the vector product.

2. The Cross product of two vectors is known as the scalar product.

Which of the following statements is correct?

The vector product or cross product of two vectors is defined as a vector having a magnitude equal to the product of the magnitudes of two vectors with the sine of the angle between them, and direction perpendicular to the plane containing the two vectors in accordance with right-hand screw rule.

The symbol for the cross product is given by cross sign (×).

From above it is clear that the cross product of two vectors is known as the vector product. Therefore, statement 1 is correct.

From above it is clear that the cross product of two vectors is known as the scalar product. Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.
The \(X\) and \(Y\) components of a force \(F\) acting at \(30^{\circ}\) to \(x\)-axis are respectively:

Given: \(\theta=30^{\circ}\) is angle with \(x\)-axis, and vector is Force \(F\)

If a vector \(A\) is given in \(XY\) plane, making an angle of \(\theta\) with \(x\) axis then:

its component in \(y\)-axis \(=A \sin \theta\)

its component in \(x\)-axis \(=A \cos \theta\)

its component in \(y\) axis \(=F \sin \theta=F \sin 30=\frac{F}{2}\)

its component in \(x\) axis \(=F \cos \theta=F \cos 30=\frac{\sqrt{3} F}{2}\)
A vector which coincides with initial and terminal points is called ________.

Zero vector/Null vector: The vector having magnitude equal to zero is called a null vector. It is generally represented by O. In zero vector the initial and terminal points coincide with each other. A point is generally taken as a null vector.

\(\overset{\longrightarrow}{\mid A \mid}=0\)

Free vector: If a vector's initial point is not defined then it is said to be a free vector.

Unit vector: A vector that has a unit magnitude (length) is called a unit vector.

Equal vectors: When the magnitude and direction of two vectors are same, the vector is said to be equal vector.
If a fielder can throw a ball to a maximum horizontal distance of 120 m, then how high (in m) can he throw if he throws vertically with the same velocity? (use g = 10 m/s\(^{2}\))

Given: \(R =120\) m

As we know that \(\sin \theta\) is maximum at \(90^{\circ}\). Therefore horizontal range will maximum at \(45^{\circ}\).

\(R=\frac{u^{2} \sin 2 \times 45^{\circ}}{g}=\frac{u^{2} \sin 90^{\circ}}{g}=\frac{u^{2}}{g}\)

Where, R is the maximum horizontal distance, u is the initial velocity, g is acceleration due to gravity.

\(\Rightarrow u^{2}=120 \times 10=1200\) m\(^{2}\)/s\(^{2}\)

The ball will achieve the maximum height when it is thrown vertically upward.

For such motion, the final velocity 'v' is zero at the maximum height '\(H\)'.

Use kinematics equation to find the maximum height,

\(v ^{2}= u ^{2}-2 gH\)

\(\Rightarrow- u ^{2}=-2 gH\)

\(\Rightarrow H=\frac{u^{2}}{2 g}=\frac{1200}{2 \times 10}=60\) m
Ship A is moving North West at speed of \(18 \sqrt{2}\) m/s and ship B is moving East at a speed of 9 m/s. What is the magnitude of the relative velocity of ship B with respect to ship A.

Given: \(V _{ A }=18 \sqrt{2}\) m/s in North West direction, \(V _{ B }=9\) m/s in East direction.

So, from the parallelogram addition of vectors:


The vector resolution of two velocities in \(x\)-and \(y\)-direction.

\(V_{ A }=18 \sqrt{2} \operatorname{cos} 45^{\circ}(- i )+18 \sqrt{2} \operatorname{sin} 45^{\circ} j =-18 \sqrt{2} \times \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) i +18 \sqrt{2} \times\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)j\)

\(V _{ A }=-18 i +18 j\)

Similarily, \(V_{B}=9 i\)

\(\vec{V}_{\frac{B}{A}}=\vec{v}_{B}-\overrightarrow{V_{A}}=9 i -(-18 i +18 j )=27 i -18j\)

\(\vec{V}_{\frac{B}{A}}=\sqrt{\left(27^{2}+18^{2}\right)}=9 \sqrt{13}\) m/s
At the topmost position of trajectory, what we can say about acceleration of particle along y-axis?
For a projectile acceleration due to gravity remains constant throughout its trajectory.

When the object is thrown from the ground, the acceleration due to gravity is constant on the object throughout its flight.

      So, the acceleration of the projectile is equal to the acceleration due to gravity, 9.81 m/s, from just after its thrown, through its highest point, and until just before it hits the ground.


      So, from the given condition we know that acceleration remains constant throughout its trajectory. So, option (D) is correct.

      Which means for a projectile acceleration due to gravity remains constant throughout its trajectory.

      Thus, option (A), (B) & (C) cannot be correct.
The \(x\) -component of a force of \(50N\) is \(30N\), then what will be the \(y\)-component of the same applied force?

Concept:​

Resolution of vectors into components: We have a vector \((F)\) where the magnitude of the vector is \(F\) and the angle with horizontal is \(\theta\).

The vector has two components: \(1\). Vertical component and \(2\). Horizontal component

Vertical component \(\left(F_{y}\right)=F \sin \theta\)

Horizontal component \(\left(F_{x}\right)=F \cos \theta\)

Here \(F=\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}}\)

Calculation:

Here \(F_{x}\) and \(F_{y}\) are along \(X\) - and \(Y\) - direction.

Let the applied force \(F=50\)

And the \(x\)-component of the applied force \(F_{x}=30\)

The \(y\)-component of the applied force \(F_{y}=\)?

We know that the vector sum of the force

\(F=\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}}\)

\(50 N=\sqrt{30^{2}+F^{2}}\)

Now squaring both sides

\(2500=900+F^{2}\)

\(F_{y}=\sqrt{2500-900}=\sqrt{1600}\)

\(F_{y}=40 N\)

A \(1 \mathrm{~kg}\) ball moving at \(12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) collides head-on with a \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) ball moving in the opposite direction at \(24 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). What is the velocity of each ball after the impact if the coefficient of restitution is?

Given,

Coefficient of restitution \(e=\frac{2}{3}\)

Velocity of mass \(1 \mathrm{~kg}\) after the collision is given by

\(\mathrm{V}_{1}=\frac{\left(\mathrm{m}_{1}-\mathrm{em}_{2}\right) \mathrm{u}_{1}+(1+\mathrm{e}) \mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{u}_{2}}{\mathrm{~m}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2}}\)

\(\text { Or } \mathrm{V}_{1}=\frac{\left(1-\frac{2}{3} \times 2\right) \times 12+\left(1+\frac{2}{3}\right) \times 2 \times(-24)}{1+2} \)

\(=-28 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

The velocity of mass \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) after the collision is given by

\(\mathrm{V}_{2}=\frac{\left(\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}_{1}\right) \mathrm{u}_{2}+(1+\mathrm{e}) \mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{u}_{1}}{\mathrm{~m}_{1}+\mathrm{m}_{2}}\)

Or \(\mathrm{V}_{2}=\frac{\left(2-\frac{2}{3} \times 1\right) \times(-24)+\left(1+\frac{2}{3}\right) \times 1 \times(12)}{1+2}\)

\(=-4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

A crane is used to lift \(10000 \mathrm{~kg}\) of coal from a mine \(100 \mathrm{~m}\) deep. If the time taken to lift coal by the crane is 1 hour, then what is the power of the driving mechanism of the crane?

(Efficiency of the crane is \(80 \%, \mathrm{~g}=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} 2\) )

Given that the mass \((\mathrm{m})\) of the crane \(=10000 \mathrm{~kg}\) and displacement(s)=

\(100 \mathrm{~m}\)

Thus, we have Work done \(=\mathrm{F} \times \mathrm{s}\)

\(=98 \times 10^{5} \text { joule }\)

We also know that power is work done in the given time or power

\(=\frac{W}{t}\)

\(=\frac{98 \times 10^{5}}{3600}=2.722 \times 10^{3} \text { watt }\)

Now, Efficiency \(=\frac{\text { Power used to lift load }}{\text { Total power }} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}=\frac{2.722 \times 10^{3}}{80} \times 100=3403\) watts

Thus, we have power of the crane \((\mathrm{P})\) to be 3403 watts.

A particle of mass \(m\) has half the kinetic energy of another particle of mass \(\frac{m}{2}\). If the speed of the heavier particle is increased by \(2 \mathrm{~ms}-1\), its new kinetic energy equals the original kinetic energy of the lighter particle. The ratio of the original speeds of the lighter and heavier particles is:

For the particle (1),

given mass \(m_{1}=m\), let speed be \(v\)

Kinetic energy \(=K_{1}=\left(\frac{1}{2} m_{1} v^{2}\right)\)

For the particle (2),

Given mass \(m_{2}=\frac{m}{2}\), let speed be \(v^{\prime}\)

Kinetic energy \(=K E_{2}=\left(\frac{1}{2}, 2 v^{\prime 2}\right)\)

Since the particle of mass \(m\) has half the kinetic energy of another particle of mass \(\frac{m}{2}\) we get

\(K \cdot E_{1}=\frac{K \cdot E_{2}}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m_{1} v^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} m_{2} v^{\prime 2}\)

Given that \(\left(m_{1}=m\right)\) and \(\left(m_{2}=\frac{m}{2}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{m}{2} v^{\prime 2} \)

\(v^{2}=\frac{v^{2}}{4}\)

So the ratio of speed of the lighter particle and that of heavier particle is given by,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{v^{\prime}}{v}=\frac{2}{1} \)

\(\Rightarrow v^{\prime}: v=2: 1\)

The figure above shows a smooth curved track terminating in a smooth horizontal part. A spring of spring constant \(400 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}\) is attached at one end to the wedge fixed rigidly with the horizontal part. A \(40 \mathrm{~g}\) mass is released from a position of rest at a height of \(4.9 \mathrm{~m}\) on the curved track. What is the maximum compression of the spring? (Take \(\left.g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\)

At the instant of maximum compression, the speed of the \(40 \mathrm{~g}\) mass reduces to zero. Taking the gravitational potential energy to be zero at the horizontal part, the conservation of energy shows, \(m g h=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}\)

Where \(\mathrm{m}=0.04 \mathrm{~kg}, \mathrm{~h}=4.9 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{k}=400 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}\) and \(\mathrm{x}\) is the maximum

compression.

Thus, \(x=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{mgh}}{\mathrm{k}}}\)

\(=\frac{\sqrt{2 \times(0.04 \mathrm{~kg}) \times\left(9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right) \times(4.9 \mathrm{~m})}}{(400 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m})} \)

\(=9.8 \mathrm{~m}\)

A uniform chain of length \(L\) and mass \(M\) is lying on a smooth table and \(\frac{1}{3}\) of its length is hanging vertically down over the edge of the table. If \(g\) is acceleration due to gravity, the work required to pull the hanging part on the table is:

Consider, the weight of hanging part \(\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}}{3}\right)\) of chain \(=\frac{\mathrm{Mg}}{3}\)

This weight acts at the center of gravity of the hanging part, which is at a distance of \(\left(\frac{L}{6}\right)\) from the table.

Work done \(=\) force \(\times\) distance

So,

\(\mathrm{W}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{Mg}}{3}\right) \times\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}}{6}\right)\)

\(\mathrm{W}=\frac{\mathrm{MgL}}{18}\)

A shell is fired from a canon with velocity \(\mathrm{vm} / \mathrm{s}\) at an angle \(\theta\) with the horizontal direction. At the highest point in its path it explodes into pieces of equal mass. One of the pieces retraces its path to the canon and the speed in \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\) of the other piece immediately after the explosion is:

Shell is fired with velocity \(v\) at an angle \(\theta\) with the horizontal.

So its velocity at the highest point = horizontal component of velocity \(=v \cos \theta\)

So momentum of shell before explosion \(=m v \cos \theta\)

When it breaks into two equal pieces and one piece retrace its path to the canon, let the other part move with velocity \(\mathrm{V}\).

So momentum of two pieces after explosion

\(=\frac{m}{2}(-v \cos \theta)+\frac{m}{2} V\)

By the law of conservation of momentum

\(m v \cos \theta=\frac{-m}{2} v \cos \theta+\frac{m}{2} V \)

\(\Rightarrow V=3 v \cos \theta\)

A pendulum consists of a wooden bob of mass \(m\) and length \(\mathbf{I}\). A bullet of mass \(\mathrm{m}_{1}\) is fired towards the pendulum with a speed \(v_{1}\). If the bullet emerges out of the bob with a speed \(\frac{v_{1}}{3}\), and the bob just completes motion along a vertical circle, then \(v_{1}\) is:

Given,

Mass of bob \(=m\),

Initial velocity of bob \(=0\)

Mass of bullet \(=m_{1}\)

Velocity of the bullet just before collision \(=V_{1}\)

Velocity of bullet just after collision \(=\frac{V_{1}}{3}\)

Let, velocity of \(m\) just after collision is \(v\).

Then, from the conservation of momentum we have,

\(m_{1} V_{1}=m v+m_{1} \frac{V_{1}}{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{2 m_{1} \mathbf{v}_{1}}{3 m}\)

Now, for just completing the circle in vertical circular motion, the velocity of \(m\)

\(v=\sqrt{5 g l}\)

Substituting the value of \(v\), we have

\(\frac{2 m_{1} V_{1}}{3 m}=\sqrt{5 g l} \)

\(\therefore V_{1}=\frac{3 m}{2 m_{1}} \sqrt{5 g l}\)

A bullet of mass \(\mathrm{m}\) moving with a horizontal velocity \(\mathrm{v}_{1}\) strikes a stationary block of mass \(M\) suspended by a string of length \(L\). The bullet gets embedded in the block. What is the maximum angle made by the string after the impact?

From the geometry of the above figure it is clear that the height \(\mathrm{h}\) reached can be expressed in terms of length of the string and the angle made.

When the bullet gets embedded in the block, then

\(h=L-L \cos \theta\)

Applying law of conservation of momentum, we have

Mass of bullet times its velocity before collision = sum of masses of bullet and block times velocity of block,

\(m v=(m+M) V \quad \ldots . .(2)\)

Where \(V\) is the velocity of the block and bullet after the impact.

Also, from the law of conservation of energy, we have

\(\frac{1}{2}(m+M) v^{2}=(m+M) g h \)

\(\therefore V^{2}=2 g(L-L \cos \theta)\)

From equation (2), we get

v=\frac{m v}{m+M}

So,

\(1-\cos \theta=\frac{V^{2}}{2 g L}\)

\(\cos \theta=\left[1-\frac{m^{2} U^{2}}{2 g L(m+M)^{2}}\right]\)

Or \(\theta=\cos ^{-1}\left[1-\frac{m^{2} v^{2}}{2 g L(m+M)^{2}}\right]\)
A body falling from a height of \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) rebounds from a hard floor. If it loses \(20 \%\) of its energy during the impact, then it will rise up to:

Initial potential energy \(=\mathrm{mgh}\) where \(h=10 \mathrm{~m}\)

It loses \(20 \%\) of its energy \(=0.2 \mathrm{mgh}\)

Its kinetic energy after rebound \(=0.8 \mathrm{mgh}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2} \ldots\) (1)

Now the ball will rise to a new height ' \(h\) ' and :

\(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}=\mathrm{mgh}^{\prime} \ldots . . \text { (2) }\)

From (1) and (2)

\(0.8 \mathrm{mgh}=\mathrm{mgh}\)

\(\mathrm{h}^{\prime}=0.8 \mathrm{~h} \)

\(=0.8 \times 10=8 \mathrm{~m}\)

What is the velocity of the bob of a simple pendulum at its mean position, if it is able to rise to a vertical height of \(20 \mathrm{~cm}\) ? \(\left(\mathrm{g}=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\)

Given that,

Height \(\mathrm{h}=20 \mathrm{~cm}\)

Now,

Kinetic energy at mean position = potential energy at maximum height

\(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}=\mathrm{mgh}\)

\(\mathrm{v}^{2}=2 \mathrm{gh}\)

\(v=\sqrt{2 g h}\)

\(v=\sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 0.2}\)

\(=\sqrt{3.92}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=1.97 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)
If the speed of a vehicle increases by \(2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\), its \(\mathrm{KE}\) is doubled. The original speed of the vehicle was:

Let original speed of the vehicle is \(\mathrm{v}\),

\(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m}(\mathrm{v}+2)^{2}=2\left(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}\right) \)

\(\mathrm{v}+2=\sqrt{2} \mathrm{v}\)

\(\Rightarrow(\sqrt{2}-1) \mathrm{v}=2 \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{2}-1}\)
A body of mass \(400 \mathrm{~g}\) is rotating in a circular path of radius \(\mathrm{r}\) with constant velocity. What is the work done in one complete revolution?

Work done \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{FS} \cos \theta\)

Where \(\theta\) is the angle between \(\mathbf{F}\) and \(\mathrm{S}\).

If \(\theta=90^{\circ} \Longrightarrow \mathrm{W}=0\)

Thus the work done by a force will be zero if the object moves in a direction perpendicular to the direction of applied force.

Displacement of the body revolving in a circular path is along the tangent whereas centripetal force acts radially inwards i.e they are perpendicular to each other.

So, work done in this case by the centripetal force is zero.
If the momentum of a body is increased by \(60 \%\), then its KE increases by:

We know kinetic energy \(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{K}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}\) and momentum of an object \((\mathrm{P}=\mathbf{m v}\)

Now multiplying and dividing \(\mathbf{E}_{\mathrm{K}}\) by mass we get

\(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{K}}=\frac{1}{2 \mathrm{~m}} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \mathrm{v}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{p}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~m}} \ldots \text { (1) }\)

Now when the momentum is increased by \(60 \% \mathrm{P}_{\text {new }}=1.6 \mathrm{P}\)

\(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{rav}}}=\frac{1}{2 \mathrm{~m}} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \mathbf{v}^{2}=\frac{1.6 \mathrm{p}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~m}}\)

Solving 1 and 2 we get,

\(\frac{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{K}}}{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{Knew}}}=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{p}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~m}}}{\frac{1.6 \mathrm{P}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{~m}}}\)

\(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{Knew}}=2.56 \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{K}}\)

Thus percentage increase in its kinetic energy \(=156 \%\)

Two carts of masses \(200 \mathrm{~kg}\) and \(300 \mathrm{~kg}\) respectively standing on horizontal straight rails are pushed apart by an explosions of the device kept in connecting mechanism of carts. The coefficient of friction between carts and rails are identical. If the \(200 \mathrm{~kg}\) cart travels a distance \(36 \mathrm{~cm}\) and stops, what is the distance covered by cart weighing \(300 \mathrm{~kg}\) :

Apply conservation of momentum,

\(200 v_{1}=300 v_{2} \)

\(\frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=\frac{300}{200}=\frac{3}{2}\)

If \(E_{1}\) and \(E_{2}\) are the kinetic energies after explosion and \(W_{1}\) and \(W_{2}\) are the work done in stopping the carts by friction of force \((=\mu \mathrm{mg})\).

We have \(\frac{\frac{5}{2} m v_{1}^{1}}{\frac{1}{2} m v_{2}^{2}}=\frac{W_{1}}{W_{2}}=\frac{F_{1} d}{F_{2} d}\)

Or \(\frac{\frac{1}{2} \times 200 \times v_{1}^{2}}{\frac{1}{2} \times 300 \times v_{2}^{2}}=\frac{\mu \times 200 \times g \times 36}{\mu \times 300 \times g \times x}\)

\(\operatorname{Or} \frac{v_{1}^{2}}{v_{2}^{2}}=\frac{36}{x}\)

Or \(\frac{9}{4}=\frac{36}{x}\)

Or \(x=16 \mathrm{~m}\)

A solid ball of density half that of water falls freely under gravity from height of \(19.6 \mathrm{~m}\) and then enters water. Up to what depth will the ball go? \((\mathrm{g}=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} 2)\)

From the law of conservation of mechanical energy, the velocity at the surface of the water

\(v=\sqrt{2 g h}=\sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 19.6}=19.6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Net retardation inside the water,

\(a=\frac{\text { Upthrust - weight }}{\text { mass }} \)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{V(2 \rho) g-V(\rho) g_{1}}{V(\rho)}=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[\text { upward }]\)

[ \(\rho\) is the density of the ball and \(2 \rho\) is the density of water]

So, using \(v^{2}-u^{2}=2\) as

\(\Rightarrow O^{2}-19.6^{2}=2 \times(-9.8) \times \mathrm{s}\)

Since, at maximum depth ball will be at instantaneous rest,

\(\Rightarrow s=19.6 m\)

The PE between 2 atoms in a molecule is given by \(u(x)=\frac{a}{x^{12}}-\frac{b}{x^{6}}\) where a and \(b\) are positive constants and \(x\) is the distance between the atoms. The atoms are in stable equilibrium when:

The potential energy between two atoms in a molecule is given by

\(\mathrm{U}(\mathrm{x})=\frac{\mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{k}^{12}}-\frac{\mathrm{b}}{\mathrm{x}^{6}}\)

The atom is in stable equilibrium. When condition for stable equilibrium

\(\mathrm{F}=-\frac{\mathrm{dU}}{\mathrm{dx}}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow-\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{dx}}\left[\frac{\mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{x}^{12}}-\frac{\mathrm{b}}{\mathrm{x}^{6}}\right]=0\)

Or \(-12 \mathrm{ax}^{-13}+6 \mathrm{bx}^{-7}=0\)

Or, \(\frac{+12 \mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{x}^{13}}=\frac{6 \mathrm{~b}}{\mathrm{x}^{7}}\)

Or, \(\frac{2 a}{b}=x^{6}\)

\(x=6 \sqrt{\frac{2 a}{b}}\)
If a bag of mass \(M\) hangs by a long thread and a bullet of mass \(m\) comes horizontally with velocity \(v\) and gets caught in the bag, then for combined (bag + bullet) system:

Kinetic energy is \(\frac{m^{2} v^{2}}{2(M+m)}\)

Initial momentum \(=\mathbf{m v}\)

Final momentum \(=(m+M) V\)

By conservation of momentum \(m v=(m+M) V\)

\(\therefore\) Velocity of (bag + bullet) system \(V=\frac{m v}{M+m}\)

\(\therefore\) Kinetic energy \(=\frac{1}{2}(m+M) V^{2}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}(m+M)\left(\frac{m v}{M+m}\right)^{2}\)

\(=\frac{1 m^{2} v^{2}}{2(M+m)}\)
A cord is used to lower vertically a block of mass \(m\) to a distance \(d\) at a constant downward acceleration of \(\frac{g}{5}\). The work done by the cord on the block is:

Let T tension in the sting

\(\mathrm{gm}-\mathrm{T}=\frac{\mathrm{gm}}{5} \)

\(\mathrm{~T}=\mathrm{gm}-\frac{\mathrm{gm}}{5} \)

\(=\frac{4 \mathrm{gm}}{5}\)

Work done by tension,

\(=-\mathrm{T} \times \mathrm{d}\)

\(=-\frac{4 \mathrm{gm}}{5} \times \mathrm{d} \)

\(=-\frac{4 \mathrm{gmd}}{5}\)
A particle moves under the effect of a force \(F=c x\) from \(x=0\) to \(x_{1}\). The work done in the process is:

Given,

\(F=cx\)

As we know,

\(W=\int F \cdot d x\)

\(W=\int_{0}^{x_{1}} c x \cdot d x \)

\(F=\left[c \frac{x^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}^{x_{1}}\)

\(F=\)\(\frac{1}{2} {cx}_{1}^{2}\)

The work done in pulling up a block of wood weighing \(2 \mathrm{kN}\) for a length of \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) on a smooth plane inclined at an angle of \(15^{\circ}\) with the horizontal is . \(\left(\sin 15^{\circ}=0.2588\right)\)
The scalar product of two vectors \(A\) and \(B\) is:

The scalar product of two vectors \(A\) and \(B\) is a scalar.

The scalar product of two vectors \(A\) and \(B\) of magnitude \(|A|\) and \(|B|\) is given as \(|\mathrm{A}||\mathrm{B}| \cos \theta\), where \(\theta\) represents the angle between the vectors a and \(B\) taken in the direction of the vectors.
The scalar product of two vectors \(A\) and \(B\) in terms of the magnitudes and angle \(\theta\) is:

The scalar product of two vectors can be constructed by taking the component of one vector in the direction of the other and multiplying it times the magnitude of the other vector. This can be expressed in the form.

\(\vec{A} \cdot \bar{B}=|A||B| \cos \theta\)
The scalar product of two vectors \(A\) and \(B\) in terms of the projections of the vectors on the \(x, y\) and \(z\) axis is:

\(A=A_{x} i+A_{y} j+A_{z} k\)

\(B=B_{x} i+B_{y} j+B_{z} k\)

\(A \cdot B=\left(A_{x} j+A_{y} j+A z k\right) \cdot\left(B_{x} j+B_{y} j+B_{z} k\right)\)

\(A B=A_{x} B_{x}+A_{y} B_{y}+A_{z} B_{z}\)

The scalar product is commutative and distributive.

(a) Commutative:

\(\mathrm{A} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{B}}=\mathrm{B} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}\)

\(\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B}=\vec{B} \cdot \vec{A}\)

\(|\mathrm{A}||\mathrm{B}| \cos \theta=|\mathrm{B} \| \mathrm{A}| \cos \theta \quad|A||B| \cos \theta=|B||A| \cos \theta\)

(b) Distributive:

\(\vec{A} \cdot(\vec{B}+\vec{C})=\)\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{A} .} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{B}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}. \overrightarrow{\mathrm{C}}\)
The change in kinetic energy of a particle is equal to the ___________.
Work done on it by the aerodynamic force
Work done on it by the net force
Work done on it by some force

The change in kinetic energy of a particle is equal to the work done on it by the net force.

If a body of mass \(m\) moves with velocity \(u\) under the addition of force \(F\). Its velocity becomes \(v\) after being displaced by \(s\).

then,

\(v^{2}=u^{2}+2 \mathrm{as}\)

\(v^{2}-u^{2}=2 \mathrm{as} \)

\(\mathrm{mv}^{2}-m u^{2}=2 \mathrm{mas}\)

\(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}=\mathrm{Fs} \)

\(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{f}}-\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{i}}=\mathrm{W}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{K}=\mathrm{W}\)
A straight section PQ of a circuit lies along the x–axis from x = – to x = and carries a current I. The magnetic field due to the section PQ at point x = + a will be:
Proportional to
Magnetic field in the line of conductor is zero. As conductor is placed along \(\mathrm{x}\) axis and \(\vec{B}\) is measured at \(x=a, \vec{B}\) will be zero.

A proton is moving perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field of \(2.5\) tesla with \(2 \mathrm{MeV}\) kinetic energy. The force on proton is _________  N. (Mass of proton \(=\) \(1.6 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\). Charge of proton \(=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

Force on moving charge in the magnetic field

\(\mathrm{F}=q \mathrm{qB} \sin \theta\)

but \(\theta=90\)

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{qvB}\)

Hence velocity \(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{\mathrm{~m}}}\) (E is kinetic energy of proton)]

\(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 2 \times 10^{6} \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{1.6 \times 10^{-27}}}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=2 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

putting the values we get

\(F=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 2 \times 10^{7} \times 2.5\)

\(=8 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~N}\)
A power line lies along the East-West direction and carries a current of 10 A. The force per unit length due to the earth's magnetic field of 10–4 T is:

Given,

current \(=10\) ampere

The magnetic field of \(10^{-4}\) tesla

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{B} \times \mathrm{I} \times \mathrm{L} \times \sin \mathrm{A}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{B}\) is the magnetic field, \(\mathrm{I}\) is the current, \(\mathrm{L}\) is the length of wire and \(\mathrm{A}\) is the angle between the magnetic field and the current flow.

Now,

\(\mathrm{A}=90^{\circ}\) as the south-westward direction which is perpendicula to the earth magnetic field.

\(\mathrm{L}=1\)

Thus the required force,

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{B} \times \mathrm{I}=0.001 \times 10=10^{-3} \mathrm{~N}\)

A particle of mass \(\mathrm{m}\) and charge \(\mathrm{q}\) moves with a constant velocity \(\mathrm{v}\) along the positive \(\mathrm{x}\) - direction. It enters a region containing a uniform magnetic field \(\mathrm{B}\) directed along the negative \(z\) - direction, extending from \(x=\) a to \(x=b\). The minimum value of \(\mathrm{v}\) required so that the particle can just enter the region \(x>b\) is:

Radius of curvature has to be greater than the width of magnetic field for the particle to enter the region \(x>B\).

\(\therefore \frac{\mathrm{mv}}{\mathrm{qB}}>(\mathrm{b}-\mathrm{a})\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}>\frac{\mathrm{qB}(\mathrm{b}-\mathrm{a})}{\mathrm{m}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{v}_{\min }=\frac{\mathrm{qB}(\mathrm{b}-\mathrm{a})}{\mathrm{m}}\)

A circular coil carrying a current I has radius \(\mathrm{R}\) and number of turns \(\mathrm{N}\). If all the three, i.e., the current I, radius \(\mathrm{R}\) and number of turns \(\mathrm{N}\) are doubled, then magnetic field at its centre becomes.

Magnetic field at the center of coil is given by \(B=\frac{\mu \mathrm{NI}}{2 \mathrm{R}}\)

New current \(I^{\prime}=2 I\)

New radius \(R^{\prime}=2 R\)

New number of turns \(\mathrm{N}^{\prime}=2 \mathrm{~N}\)

Thus, magnetic field \(\mathrm{B}^{\prime}=\frac{\mu_{0} \mathrm{~N}^{\prime} \mathrm{I}^{\prime}}{2 \mathrm{R}^{\prime}}=\frac{\mu_{0}(2 \mathrm{~N})(2 \mathrm{I})}{2(2 \mathrm{R})}\)

\(\Longrightarrow \quad B^{\prime}=2 \times \frac{\mu_{0} N I}{2 R}=2 B\)

Thus magnetic field gets doubled.

Two particles, each of mass \(m\) and charge q, are attached to the two ends of a light rigid rod of length \(2 \mathrm{R}\). The rod is rotated at constant angular speed about a perpendicular axis passing through its center. The ratio of the magnitudes of the magnetic moment of the system and its angular momentum about the center of the rod is:

Current, \(\mathrm{i}=(\) frequency) (charge \()\)

\(=\left(\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}\right)(2 q)=\frac{q \omega}{\pi}\)

Magnetic moment,

\(\mathrm{M}=(\mathrm{I})(\mathrm{A})=\left(\frac{\mathrm{q} \omega}{\pi}\right)\left(\pi \mathrm{R}^{2}\right)=\left(\mathrm{q} \omega \mathrm{R}^{2}\right)\)

Angular momentum, \(\mathrm{L}=2 \mathrm{I} \omega=21\left(\mathrm{mR}^{2}\right) \omega\)

\(\frac{M}{L}=\frac{q \omega R^{2}}{2\left(m^{2}\right) \omega}=\frac{q}{2 m}\)
A charged particle is released from rest in a region of steady and uniform electric and magnetic fields, which are parallel to each other. The particle will move in a:

When the particle is released from rest, it starts to move along the fields due to application of electric field.

The magnetic force acting on a moving charged particle is given by

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}=q(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{v}} \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{B}})\)

Since velocity and magnetic fields are parallel, no magnetic force acts on the particle, hence it continues to move in a straight line along with constant acceleration.
A particle of charge q and mass m moves in a circular orbit of radius r with an angular speed . The ratio of the magnitude of its magnetic moment to that of its angular momentum depends on:

The angular momentum \(\mathrm{L}\) of the particle is given by

\(\mathrm{L}=\mathrm{mr}^{2} \mathrm{w}\) where \(\mathrm{w}=2 \pi \mathrm{n}\)

\(\therefore\) Frequency \(n=\frac{\mathrm{W}}{2 \pi}\)

Further \(\mathrm{i}=\mathrm{q} \times \mathrm{n}=\frac{\mathrm{wq}}{2 \pi}\)

Magnetic Moment, \(\mathrm{M}=\mathrm{iA}=\frac{\mathrm{wq}}{2 \pi} \times \pi^{2}\);

\(\therefore \mathrm{M}=\frac{\mathrm{wq}^{2}}{2}\)

So, \(\frac{\mathrm{M}}{\mathrm{L}}=\frac{\mathrm{wqr}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{mr}^{2} \mathrm{~W}}=\frac{\mathrm{q}}{2 \mathrm{~m}}\)

Thus the required ratio depends upon both \(q\) and \(m\).
If an electron revolves around a nucleus in a circular orbit of radius \(\mathrm{R}\) with frequency \(\mathrm{n}\), then the magnetic field produced at the centre of the nucleus will be:

Given: Radius of the orbit=R

            Frequency of revolution=n

Solution: As we know, the magnetic field at the center of the circular loop is given by,

\(B=\frac{\mu_{0} n i}{2 R}\) .......(1)

As in 1 second the electron revolves n rounds,

\(I=\frac{g}{t}\)

As, \(q=e\) and \(t=1 s\)

therefore, \(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{e} A\)

Putting the values of current the equation (1) we get,

\(\mathrm{B}=\frac{\mu_{0} \mathrm{ne}}{2 \mathrm{R}}\)
A wire of length \(\mathrm{L}\) metre carrying a current I ampere is bent in the form of a circle. It's magnitude of magnetic moment will be:

If \(r\) is the radius of the circle,

then \(\mathrm{L}=2 \pi \mathrm{r}\) or, \(\mathrm{r}=\frac{\mathrm{L}}{2 \pi}\)

Area \(=\mathrm{A}=\pi \mathrm{r}^{2}=\frac{\pi \mathrm{L}^{2}}{4 \pi^{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{L}^{2}}{4 \pi}\)

Magnetic Moment \(=\mathrm{IA}=\frac{\mathrm{IL}^{2}}{4 \pi}\)

A straight horizontal conducting rod of length \(0.5 \mathrm{~m}\) and mass \(50 \mathrm{~g}\) is suspended by two vertical wires at its ends. A current of \(5.0 \mathrm{~A}\) is set up in the rod through the wires. Then the magnetic field set up normal to the conductor in order that the tension in the wires is zero is (ignore the mass of the wire and take \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) ) :

Magnetic force in the wire \(=\mathrm{Bil}\)

\(\therefore\) tension in the wire is zero

So,

\(\mathrm{Bil}=\mathrm{mg}\)

\(\mathrm{B} \times 5 \times 0.5=50 \times 10^{-3} \times 10\)

\(\mathrm{~B}=0.2 \mathrm{~T}\)

A conducting circular loop of radius \(r\) carries a constant current i. It is placed in a uniform magnetic field \(\vec{B}_{0}\) perpendicular to the plane of the loop. The magnetic force acting on the loop is:

The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the paper. Let us consider two diametrically opposite elements as shown in the figure.Since the direction of current is opposite, forces will cancel each other due to \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{FF}}=\mathrm{i}(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d} l} \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{B}})\) Similarly, all forces acting on the diametrically opposite elements will cancel out in pair. The net force on the loop will be zero.
In the region around a magnet in which magnetic forces act exists:

An asteroid of mass \(\mathrm{m}\) is approaching earth, initially at a distance of \(10 R_{e}\), with speed \(v_{i}\). It hits the earth with a speed \(v_{f}\) ( \(R_{e}\) and \(M_{e}\) are radius and mass of earth), then:

Applying law of conservation of energy for asteroid at a distance 10Re and at earth's surface,

\(K_{i}+U_{i}=K_{f}+U_{f} \ldots(i)\)

Now, \(K_{i}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{i}^{2}\) and \(U_{i}=\frac{G M_{e} m}{10 R_{e}}\)

\(K_{f}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{f}^{2}\) and \(U_{f}=\frac{G M_{e} m}{R_{e}}\)

Substituting these values in eq. (i), we get

\(\frac{1}{2} m v_{i}^{2}-\frac{G M_{e} m}{10 R_{e}}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{f}^{2}-\frac{G M_{e} m}{R_{e}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v_{f}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{i}^{2}+\frac{G M_{e} m}{R_{e}}-\frac{G M_{e} m}{10 R_{e}} \)

\(\Rightarrow v_{f}^{2}=v_{i}^{2}+\frac{2 G M_{e}}{R_{e}}-\frac{2 G M_{e}}{10 R_{e}} \)

\(\therefore v_{f}^{2}=v_{i}^{2}+\frac{2 G M_{e}}{R_{e}}\left(1-\frac{1}{10}\right)\)

A satellite of mass \(m\) is in a circular orbit of radius \(2 R_{E}\) about the earth. The energy required to transfer it to a circular orbit of radius \(4 R_{E}\) is (where \(M_{E}\) and \(R_{E}\) is the mass and radius of the earth respectively)

Initial total energy of the satellite is:

\(E_{i}-\frac{G M_{E} m}{4 R_{E}}\)

Final total energy of the satellite is:

\(E_{f}=-\frac{G M_{E} m}{8 R_{E}}\)

The change in the total energy is:

\(\Delta E=E_{f}-E_{i}\)

\(\Delta E=-\frac{G M_{E} m}{8 R_{E}}-\left(-\frac{G M_{E} m}{4 R_{E}}\right)\)

\(=-\frac{G M_{E} m}{8 R_{E}}+\frac{G M_{E} m}{4 R_{E}}=\frac{G M_{E} m}{8 R_{E}}\)

Thus, the energy required to transfer the satellite to the desired orbit \(=\frac{G M_{E} m}{8 R_{E}}\)

Cavendish's apparatus for experimentally determining the value of G involved a light, rigid rod about 2-feet long. Two small lead spheres were attached to the ends of the rod and the rod was suspended by a thin wire. When the rod becomes twisted, the torsion of the wire begins to exert a torsional force that is proportional to the angle of rotation of the rod. The more twist of the wire, the more the system pushes backwards to restore itself towards the original position.
The value of the gravitational constant G is:

The value of G was experimentally determined by Lord Henry Cavendish using a torsion balance. Cavendish brought two large lead spheres near the smaller spheres attached to the rod. Since all masses attract, the large spheres exerted a gravitational force upon the smaller spheres and twisted the rod a measurable amount. Once the torsional force balanced the gravitational force, the rod and spheres came to rest and Cavendish was able to determine the gravitational force of attraction between the masses. Cavendish expressed his result in terms of the density of the Earth.

\(\mathrm{G}=\mathrm{g} \frac{\mathrm{R}_{\text {earth }}^{2}}{\mathrm{M}_{\text {earth }}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{g}}{4 \pi \mathrm{R}_{\text {earth }} \rho_{\text {earth }}}\)

\(\mathrm{G}=\mathrm{g}\frac{R_{\text {earth }}^{2}}{M_{\text {earth }}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{g}}{4 \pi R_{\text {earth }} \rho_{\text {earth }}}\)

After converting to SI units, Cavendish's value for the Earth's density, \(5.448 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}\), gives

\(G=6.74 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{~m}^{3} \mathrm{~kg}^{-1} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\)

Today, the currently accepted value is \(6.67259 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\).
The acceleration due to gravity at a height h in terms of mass of earth ME and radius of the earth RE and gravitational constant G is:

We know by Newton's law of gravitation, the force on the body of mass m, situated at height h to the surface of the earth of mass ME is given by:

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{G} \frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{m}}{(\mathrm{r}+\mathrm{h})^{2}} \)     ....(i)

we also know F = mass × acceleration( here acceleration is acceleration due to gravity)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=\mathrm{mg}\)     ....(ii)

Equating (i) & (ii), we get

\(g=G \frac{M_{e}}{(r+h)^{2}}\)
The acceleration due to gravity at a depth d in terms of g the acceleration due to gravity at radius of the earth RE is:

Acceleration due to gravity at the surface of the earth of radius \(R_{E}\)

\(g=G \frac{M}{R_{E}^{2}}=\frac{4}{3} \pi \rho G R_{E} \text {    .....(1) }\)

Acceleration due to gravity at depth \(d\) from the surface of the earth

\(g(d)=\frac{4}{3} \pi \rho G(R-d) \quad .....(2)\)

From (1) & (2), we get

\(g(d)=g\left(1-\frac{d}{R_{E}}\right)\)

Kepler law of areas describes the speed of a planet travelling in an elliptical orbit around the sun. A planet’s orbital speed changes, depending on how far it is from the Sun. The farther it is from the Sun, the weaker the Sun’s gravitational pull, and the slower it moves in its orbit. So, statement of Kepler's law of area is "The line joining the sun to the planet sweeps out equal areas in equal interval of time". i.e. areal velocity is constant.

The direction of the universal gravitational force between particles of masses m1 and m2 is:
towards m2 on m1 and towards m1 on m2

Since gravitational force is attractive in nature, so if there are two particles of m1 & m2.

So, One Force will be on \(\mathrm{m}_{1}\) which will be directed towards \(\mathrm{m}_{2}\). i.e \( \overrightarrow{F_{12}}=G \frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{r_{21}{ }^{2}}\)

And other force wiil be on \(\mathrm{m}_{2}\) which will be directed towards \(\mathrm{m}_{1}\) i.e \(\overrightarrow{F_{21}}=-\mathrm{G} \frac{\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{~m}_{2}}{\mathrm{r}_{12}{ }^{2}}\)

Clearly, It can be seen that \(\overrightarrow{F_{12}}=-\overrightarrow{F_{21}}\) Because these forces are attracted to each other, and the direction of each force is opposite to another one.
To find the resultant gravitational force acting on the particle m due to a number of masses we need to use:

According to properties of gravitational force, gravitational force between the particles is independent of the presence or absence of other particles; so the principle of superposition is valid i.e. force on a particle due to number of particles is the resultant of forces due to individual particles i.e. \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{1}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{2}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}_{3}}+\ldots \ldots \ldots\)

When a system is taken from state '\(x\)' to state '\(y\)' then \(30 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of heat flows into the system and the system does \(10 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of work. When the system is returned from state '\(\mathrm{y}\)' to state '\(\mathrm{x}\)' along another path, then work done on the system is \(8 \mathrm{~kJ}\). What is the amount of heat liberated?

We know that:

First law of thermodynamics for a process is given by

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W\)

When the system is taken from state \({x}\) to state \({y}\) then:

\(\mathrm{Q}_{x-y}=+30 \mathrm{k} J, W_{x-y}=+10 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{J}\)

Then from first law of thermodynamics,

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W \)

\(+30 k J=d u_{x-y}+10 \mathrm{~kJ} \)

\( d u_{x-y}=30-10 \)

\( d u_{x-y}=20 \mathrm{k} J\)

Now,

When the system is taken from state \({y}\) to state \({x}\) then:

\(W_{y-x}=-8 \mathrm{~kJ} \text { and }\)

\(\mathrm{d} U_{y-\mathrm{x}}=-20 \mathrm{~kJ} [\because\left(U_{y}-U_{x}\right)=-\left(U_{x}-U_{y}\right)]\)

Then from first law of thermodynamics

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W \)

\(Q_{y-x}=-20-8 \)

\(\therefore Q_{y \cdot x}=-28 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Here negative sign indicates that heat is being liberated.

A reversible Carnot engine works between the temperature of \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\) and \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). Heat supplied to the engine by \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\) reservoir is \(250 \mathrm{~kJ}\). Now the work obtained by this engine is supplied to the refrigerator which works between the temperature limits of \(270 \mathrm{~K}\) and \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). The COP of the refrigerator is \(50 \%\) of the COP of the reversible refrigerator then find out the heat rejected by the refrigerator (in \(\mathrm{kJ}\) ) at the reservoir which is at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\).

Given:

For engine

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=300 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=1000 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{s}}=250 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Now, The efficiency of the Carnot engine is given by:

\(\eta=1-\frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}}\)

Where \(\boldsymbol{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=\) temperature of the low-temperature reservoir and \(\boldsymbol{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=\) temperature of the high-temperature reservoir.

\(=1-\frac{300}{1000}=0.7\)

Again, The efficiency of an engine is given by:

\(\eta=\frac{W_{n e t}}{Q_{\text {supplied }}} \)

Where \(\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\) Net work done by the engine and \(\mathrm{Q}_{\text {supplied }}=\) Heat supplied to the engine.

\(\therefore \mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\eta \times \mathrm{Q}_{\text {supplied }}\)

\(=0.7 \times 250 \)

\(\therefore \mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=176 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{J}\)

Now this work is supplied to the refrigerator,

For refrigerator,

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=270 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=300 \mathrm{~K}\)

COP of a reversible refrigerator is given by:

\(C O P=\frac{T_{L}}{T_{L}-T_{H}}\)

Where, \(T_{L}=\) Temperature of the evaporator and \(T_{H}=\) Temperature at which heat is rejected.

\(\therefore C O P=\frac{270}{300-270}=9\)

Now,

The actual COP is \(60 \%\) of the ideal COP

\(\therefore \text { COP }_{\text {actual }}=9 \times 0.5=4.5\)

Again,

\(C O P=\frac{\text { Desired Effect }}{\text { Work Input }} \)

\(\Rightarrow 4.5=\frac{\text { Desired } E f \text { fect }}{175 \mathrm{~kJ}} \)

\( \text { Desired effect }=4.5 \times 175 \)

\(=787.6 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

\(\) The heat rejected to the \(300 \mathrm{~K}\) reservoir by the refrigerator \(=787.6+176=962.6 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

In an adiabatic chamber, two blocks of the same mass and heat capacity comes in contact with each other. One is at a temperature of \(500 \mathrm{~K}\) and the other one is at \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\). Find the value of entropy change if the system attains thermodynamic equilibrium. Take (mass \(\left.=2 \mathrm{~kg}, \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}=1 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K}\right)\)

Given:

\(T_1=500k,~T_2=1000k,~T_f=750k\)

\(m=2,~C_p=1\)

According to the question:

Heat lost by block \(1=\) Heat gained by block 2

\(\therefore m C_{p}\left(T_{1}-T_{f}\right)=m C_{p}\left(T_{f}-T_{2}\right) \)

\(\therefore T_{f}=\frac{T_{1}+T_{2}}{2}=750 K\)

Now,

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=(\Delta s)_{\text {block } 1}+(\Delta s)_{\text {block } 2} \)

\(=m C_{p} \ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}\right)+m C_{p} \ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{2}}\right) \)

\(=m C_{p}\left(\ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}\right)+\ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{2}}\right)\right) \)

Put all given values in above equation:

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=2 \times 1 \times\left[\ln \left(\frac{750^{2}}{500 \times 1000}\right)\right] \)

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=0.2355 ~{k J}/{K}\)

A gas is compressed at constant pressure from \(0.3 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) and \(0.1 \mathrm{MPa}\) to \(0.15 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\). There is a transfer of heat of \(35 \mathrm{~kJ}\) from gas during the process. Find the change in internal energy during the process.

Given:

\(\mathrm{P}=0.1 \mathrm{MPa}=0.1 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~Pa}\)

\(\mathrm{~V}_{1}=0.3 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\)

\(\mathrm{~V}_{2}=0.15 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\)

\(\mathrm{dQ}=-35 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Work done in constant pressure process is given by:

\(\mathrm{dW}=\mathrm{P}\left(\mathrm{V}_{2}-\mathrm{V}_{1}\right)\) [where \(P\) is pressure, \(V_{2}\) is final volume and \(V_{1}\) is initial volume]

Put given values in above formula:

\(\mathrm{dW}=0.1 \times 10^{6}(0.15-0.3) \)

\(=-0.015 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~J}\)

\(=-15 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Now, According to first law of thermodynamics:

\(\mathrm{dQ}=\mathrm{dU}+\mathrm{dW} \)

\(-35=\mathrm{d} \mathrm{U}-15\)

\(\mathrm{d} \mathrm{U}=-20kJ\)
Figure shows the \(P-V\) diagram of an ideal gas. The work done by the gas in the process ABCDA is:

Given:

Work done = Area of Parallelogram ABCDA

Area of parallelogram \(=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times(\) Sum of parallel sides \() \times\) height

Work done \(=\) Area of Parallelogram \(A B C D A=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times(A B+C D) \times B C\)

\(\frac{ 1 }{ 2} \times(V+2 V) \times P\)

\(=1.5 P V\)
Two blocks that are at different temperatures are brought into contact with each other and allowed to reach a final state of thermal equilibrium. The final temperature attained is specified by:

Two blocks that are at different temperatures are brought into contact with each other and allowed to reach a final state of thermal equilibrium. The final temperature attained is specified by 'Zeroth law of thermodynamics'.

There are 4 laws to thermodynamics:

1. Zeroth law of thermodynamics:

2. First law of thermodynamics

3. Second law of thermodynamics

4. Third law of Thermodynamics

Zeroth law of thermodynamics:

If two thermodynamic systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.
Since no heat interaction takes place in a adiabatic process, hence temperature of a ideal gas will going to be:

Since no heat interaction takes place in a adiabatic process, hence temperature of a ideal gas will going to be 'Can increase or decrease'.

Adiabatic process:

  • When a thermodynamic system undergoes a change in such a way that no exchange of heat takes place between Systems and surroundings, the process is known as an adiabatic process.
  • In adiabatic process system goes to a change is state by work interaction only.

From first law of thermodynamics,

\(\delta{ Q}=\Delta U+\delta W\)

For an adiabatic process \(\delta Q=0\)

i.e., \(0=\Delta U+\delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Rightarrow \delta W=-\Delta U \)

\(\Delta U=m C_{\mathrm{v}}(\Delta T) \)

\(\Rightarrow \delta{ W}=-m C_{v}(\Delta T)\)

So if work is added to the system i.e., \({\delta} \mathrm{W}=-\mathrm{ve}\), then \((\Delta \mathrm{T})=+\) ve, temperature of the gas will increase.

and work is done by the system i.e. \(\delta W=-\)ve then \((\Delta T)=-\) ve, temperature of the gas will decrease.
A reversible heat engine operates using three thermal reservoirs with temperatures as shown in following figure. If \(Q_{1}=Q_{2}\), the efficiency of engine is:
For a heat engine operating on a Carnot cycle, the work output is \(\frac{1}{ 4}{\text {th }}\) of the heat rejected to the sink. The thermal efficiency of the engine would be:

Given:

\(\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\frac{Q_{2}}{4}\)

The fraction of heat input \(\left(Q_{1}\right)\) that is converted to net-work output \(\left(W_{n e t}\right)\) is a measure of performance of a heat engine and is called thermal efficiency.

\(\mathrm{Q}_{1}\) is the heat taken from the source \(\left(T_{H}\right)\) and \(Q_{2}\) is the heat transferred to the sink \(\left(T_{L}\right)\) ). Net-work done by the engine, \(\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\mathrm{Q}_{1}-\mathrm{Q}_{2}\).

\(\frac{Q_{2}}{4}=Q_{1}-Q_{2}\)

\(\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=\frac{4}{5}\)

\(\eta_{\text {thermal }}=\frac{\text { Work output }}{\text { Heat input }}=\frac{W}{Q_{1}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}\)

\(\eta_{\text {thermal }}=1-\frac{4}{5}\)

\(\Rightarrow 20 \%\)

Change in entropy (in \(\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} . \mathrm{K})\) in a reversible adiabatic process is 0.

Adiabatic process:

When a thermodynamic system undergoes a change in such a way that no exchange of heat takes place between the system and surrounding, the process is known as an adiabatic process.

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=0\)

The change in entropy is,

\(\Delta S=\frac{\Delta Q}{T}\)

\(d S=\frac{d Q}{T}=0\)

\(50 \mathrm{cc}\) of water at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is mixed with \(150 \mathrm{cc}\) of water at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

The direction of a natural process is dictated by the __________ law of thermodynamics.

The direction of a natural process is dictated by the second law of thermodynamics.

Second law of thermodynamics - The entropy of an isolated system not in equilibrium will tend to increase over time, approaching a maximum value at equilibrium.

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q} }{ \mathrm{T}} \)

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {Total }}=\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {system }}+\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {surrounding }}\)

The second law of thermodynamics introduces the concept of entropy. The second law of thermodynamics deals with the direction taken by natural or spontaneous processes.
If hot water and cold water are mixed, then the entropy of the system will:
May increase/Decrease depending on initial temperature of hot water and cold water

If hot water and cold water are mixed, then the entropy of the system will Increase.

Entropy

It can be defined as a measure of the degree of molecular disorder/randomness existing in the system.

We know that,

\(\rho=\frac{P}{R T}\)

Density and Temperature are inversely related at constant Pressure.

Initially, hot water has a lower density and cold water has a higher density. Due to the density differences, hot water floats above cold water. Due to temperature differences heat transfer takes place within the mixture from hot water to cold water. Molecules of hot water start moving downwards and molecules of cold water start moving upwards as they lose and gain heat respectively. Thus, the mixture comes in motion as a result of buoyancy force originated from variation in fluid density.
