It is impossible to construct a device which, operating in a cycle will produce no effect other than the transfer of heat from a cooler to hotter body

Kelvin-Plank statement: It is impossible for a heat engine to produce net work in a complete cycle if it exchanges heat only with bodies at a single fixed temperature.


For heat engine to operate, the working fluid has to exchange heat with a heat sink as well with the heat source.

If \(\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{L}}=0\), then \(\eta=1-\frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}}=1\)

Therefore, the second law claims that no heat engine can be \(100 \%\) efficient. So, \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{Q}\) (is impossible)

There will be always some heat loss to the surrounding. \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{H}}-\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{L}}\) (is possible)

As \(\left(Q_{H}-Q_{L}\right) \geq 0\) so \(W_{\text {cycle }} \geq 0\)
The weight of the diesel engine, compared to similar petrol engine is

The weight of the diesel engine is 2 to 3 times greater compared to similar petrol engine.

  • Diesel engines or (C.I.Engines) are heavier than petrol engines (S.I.Engines) because of the large compression ratio in the case of diesel engines. The reason for the large compression ratio being compression ignition i.e. in diesel engines, ignition takes place by the high temperature developed by the compression since there is no spark plug like in petrol or S.I.Engine.
  • Also, the flashpoint at which fuel gets ignited is more in the case of diesel engines so the compression ratio needs to be sufficient enough to produce that self-ignition temperature of the fuel for the combustion to take place.
  • Compression ratio (r): It is defined as the ratio of volume before compression to the volume after compression.

\(r=\frac{\left(V_{c}+V_{s}\right)}{V_{c}}\)

where \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{C}}\) and \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{S}}\) are clearance and swept volume respectively.

  • The value of the compression ratio for diesel engines lies between \(16: 1\) to \(22: 1\) whereas for the petrol engine it lies between \(6: 1\) to \(12: 1\).
A system is in thermal equilibrium with its environment if:
The temperatures of the system and environment are equal
The pressures in the system and environment are equal
The chemical potentials of the system and environment are equal

A system is in thermal equilibrium with its environment if the temperatures of the system and environment are equal.

Thermal equilibrium: It is a condition/state in which all parts of a system are at the same temperature. Two objects are in thermal equilibrium if they are in close contact and there is no net flow of thermal energy between them. 

For this condition to happen, the two closely contact objects must be at the same temperature. From the definition of thermal equilibrium, a system is in thermal equilibrium with its environment if the temperatures of the system and environment are equal.
If __________ between the system and the surroundings, the process is adiabatic.
heat flows but matter does not flow
matter flows but heat does not flow

If neither heat nor matter flows between the system and the surroundings, the process is adiabatic.

Adiabatic wall:

An adiabatic wall is an insulating wall that does not allow the flow of heat energy between the system and its surroundings or between two systems.

It is found that \(\left(N_{A}, V_{A}\right)\) will be in equilibrium with any other possible pair of values. \(\left(\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{B}}, \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{B}}\right)\)

Diathermic wall:

A diathermic wall is a conducting wall, which allows heat energy to flow between the system and its surroundings or between two systems.

From above it is clear that if neither heat nor matter flows between the system and the surroundings, then the process is adiabatic.

Thermocouple, thermometer is based on Seebeck effect.

Seebeck effect

  • If two different metal wires are joined to form a closed circuit and two junctions are kept at different temperatures, a small emf is set up in the circuit in a definite direction. This effect is called a thermoelectric effect or Seebeck effect.
  • The emf developed in the circuit is called thermal emf or Seeback emf and the current called thermoelectric current.
Two bodies in contact are said to be in thermal equilibrium when:
No work is done by the bodies
When one of the body has a higher temperature
No heat flow occurs between the two bodies

Two bodies in contact are said to be in thermal equilibrium when no heat flow occurs between the two bodies.

Thermal equilibrium: Thermal equilibrium is a condition when two surfaces in physical contact have no exchange of heat between them.

  • Heat flows from an object of higher temperature to an object of lower temperature.
  • So, temperature governs the direction of heat flow.
  • When no heat flow occurs, it is to be inferred that the surfaces are at the same temperature.
300 gm of water at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is added to \(100 \mathrm{gm}\) of ice at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). Final temperature of the mixture is:

Given:

\(m_1=300 ~gm\), \(T_0=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), \(m_2=100 \mathrm{gm}\)

We know that latent heat of fusion of ice is \(79.7 \mathrm{Cal}\) per gram.

Let final temperature be \(\mathrm{T}\).

Then

\(\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{~S} \Delta \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{~L} \)

Put the given values in above formula:

\(300 \times 1 \times(25-\mathrm{T})=100 \times 75 \)

\(\Rightarrow (25-\mathrm{T})=\frac{100 \times 75}{300} \)

\(\Rightarrow 25-\mathrm{T}=25 \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{~T}=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

After that total energy left \(=4.7 \times 100=470\)

Total mass of water \(=400 \mathrm{~g}\)

Amount of water again converted into ice

\(m=\frac{\text{ total energy left }}{\text{ latent heat of fusion of ice}}\)

\(\mathrm{m}=\frac{470}{79.7} \)

\(\mathrm{~m}=5.9 \mathrm{~g}\)

Thus whole mass is converted into water at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), and about \(5.9\) gwater is again converted into ice whose temperature is also \(0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

After achieving the temperature of \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), latent heat of fusion is required firstly for conversion of water into ice then further lowering of temperature is possible. So the final temperature will be \(0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).
Which of the following equation correctly represents work done by adiabatic expansion?

\(\frac{P_{1} V_{1}-P_{2} V_{2}}{\gamma-1}\) correctly represents work done by adiabatic expansion.

An adiabatic process is a thermodynamic process in which there is no exchange of heat between the system and surrounding, that is, the heat remains constant.

For an adiabatic process, We follow the Poisson's Law.

\(P V^{\gamma}=\) constant

\(T V^{\gamma-1}=\) constant

\(\frac{T^{\gamma}}{P^{\gamma-1}}=\) constant

For adiabatic process, \(\Delta Q=0\)

Now according to the first law of thermodynamics \(\Delta Q=\Delta W+\Delta U\), so if \(\Delta Q=0\).

This means that for adiabatic process the system performs Work \((\Delta \mathrm{W})\) based on the bases of internal energy since \(\Delta \mathrm{W}=-\Delta \mathrm{U}\) from the above equation

For the adiabatic process, the work done by the system is given as

\(W=\frac{P_{1} V_{1}-P_{2} V_{2}}{\gamma-1}=\frac{n R\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)}{\gamma-1}\)

Here \(\mathrm{R}\) is gas constant, \(\mathrm{n}\) is molar mass and \(\gamma=\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}}\), where \(\mathrm{Cp}\) and \(\mathrm{Cv}\) are specific heat at constant pressure and volume. (as we had discussed in topic Heat and temperature)

Here,

\(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}=\) initial and final pressure

\(\mathrm{V}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{V}_{2}=\) initial and final volume,

\(\gamma =\) adiabatic index

\(W=\) work done
During an adiabatic expansion of 2 mole of gas, the change in internal energy was, found \(-50 \mathrm{~J}\). The work done during the process:

Given:

\(\Delta \mathrm{U}=-50 \mathrm{~J}\) and \(\mathrm{Q}=0 \mathrm{~J}\) (Adiabatic process)

The first law of thermodynamics: This law states that the total heat given or taken out of the system will always be equal to the work done and change in the internal energy of the system.

\(\Rightarrow \Delta Q=\Delta W+\Delta U\)

The work done during the process

\(\Rightarrow 0=\Delta W-50 \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta W=50 J\)

Here work done is positive so we can conclude that the system is doing work on the surrounding.
A monoatomic gas is suddenly compressed to \(\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)^{t h}\) of its initial volume adiabatically. The ratio of its final pressure to the initial pressure is:

Given:

\(\gamma=\frac{5 }{ 3}\) and \(V_{2}=\frac{V_{1} }{ 8}\)

For an ideal gas undergoing an adiabatic process at room temperature,

\( P_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma}=P_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)^{\gamma} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\left(\frac{1V_{1}}{8V_{1}}\right)^{\frac{5}{3}}\)

\(=1:32\)
For a gas of non rigid diatomic molecules, the value of \(\gamma=\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}}\) is:

Given:

Diatomic molecule, so \(\mathrm{f}=5\)

Molecular specific heat at constant volume \(\mathbf{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\mathrm{f} \frac{R}{ 2}\)

Molecular specific heat at constant volume \(C_{p}=C_{v}+R=(2+f) \frac{R }{ 2}\)

where \(\mathrm{f}\) is the degree of freedom.

For monoatomic molecule \(\mathrm{f}=3\)

For diatomic molecule \(f=5\)

\(\gamma=\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}}=\frac{7}{5}\)
A Carnot heat pump works between \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(327^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). What will be its COP?

Given:

\(T_{1}=327^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=600 \mathrm{~K}, \mathrm{~T}_{2}=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=300 \)

COP of Carnot Heat pump \(=\frac{T_{1}}{T_{1}-T_{2}}\)

\( C O P=\frac{600}{600-300}=\frac{600}{300}=2\)

COP of Carnot heat pump \(=2\)
In a vapor compression refrigeration system, the sub-cooling of refrigerant in the condenser results in:
Decrease in the size of the condenser
Increase in the size of the evaporator
Increase in the size of the compressor

• In a vapor compression refrigeration system, the sub-cooling of refrigerant in the condenser results in increase in the size of the evaporator.
  • Sub cooling is the process of cooling the liquid refrigerant below the condensing temperature for a given pressure.
  • The difference between the saturation temperature and the temperature of sub cooled liquid at that pressure is called Degree of sub cooling.
  • Subcooling is beneficial as it increases the refrigeration effect by reducing the, throttling loss at no additional specific work input.
  • Also, subcooling ensures that only liquid enters the throttling device leading to its efficient operation.
Domestic refrigerator working on vapour compression cycle uses the following type of expansion device.

Domestic refrigerator working on vapour compression cycle uses the 'Capillary tube' of the expansion device.

  • The capillary tube is one of the most commonly used throttling devices in domestic refrigerators, deep freezers, water coolers, and air conditioners. Capillary tubes have very small internal diameters and very long lengths and they are coiled to several turns so that they would occupy less space (compact). They are easy to manufacture, cheap and compact.
  • When the refrigerant leaves the condenser and enters the capillary tube, its high pressure drops down suddenly due to the very small diameter of the capillary tube and the long length gives more friction head and drops pressure further.
  • The decrease in pressure leads to the cooling of the refrigerant and the low-temperature refrigerant can take the heat from the room.
Which is the desirable physical property of refrigerant?

'Low boiling point' is the desirable physical property of refrigerant.

The characteristics of a good refrigerant should have the following properties.

1. Low boiling point

2. High latent heat value

3. Low freezing point

4. Non-flammable and non-toxic

5. High di-electric strength

6. Not affected by moisture

7. Non-corrosive to metals

8. Mixes well with compressor oil
In a refrigeration system, why are expansion devices located closer to the evaporator?
To avoid the flow of the refrigerant
To ease the flow of the refrigerant

In a refrigeration system, 'To minimise the heat gain', expansion devices are located closer to the evaporator.

Refrigeration system:

  • A refrigeration system contains a minimum of four key components i.e., compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator.
  • The purpose of the expansion device is to rapidly reduce the pressure of the refrigerant in the refrigeration cycle.
  • This allows the refrigerant to rapidly cool before entering the evaporator.
  • An expansion device is located closer to the evaporator in order to minimize heat gain.
  • The most common devices are capillary tubes, thermal expansion valves, electronic expansion valves.
If the volume of most air with \(50 \% \mathrm{RH}\) is isothermally reduced to half its original volume then relative humidity of moist air becomes:

Given:

\(\phi_{1}=50 \%\)

Relative humidity is given by

\(\phi=\frac{P_{v}}{P_{v s}}\)

where \(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{v}}\) is pressure of water vapour and \(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{vs}}\) is pressure of water vapour at saturation point.

So,

\(\frac{\phi_{2}}{\phi_{1}}=\frac{P_{v_{2}}}{P_{v 1}} \)

Since volume is reduced to half so the pressure has become twice.

\(P_{v _2}=2 P_{v _1} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\phi_{2}}{\phi_{1}}=2 \)

\(\Rightarrow \phi_{2}=2 \phi_{1} \)

Put the value of \(\phi_{1}\) in above equation:

\(\phi_{2}=2 \times 50\%\)

\(= 100 \%\)
An ideal gas is heated at constant pressure so as to triple its volume. Find the increased temperature of the gas if initial temperature of gas is \(27^{\circ}\) C.

Given: Pressure is constant \(P _{2}= P _{1}\)

Volume is doubled \(V _{2}=3 V _{1}\)

\(T _{1}=27^{\circ}\) C \(=273+27=300 K\), \(T _{2}=?\)

Ideal gas equation,

\(PV = nRT\), \(n =\frac{P V}{R T}\)

During the whole process, no. of moles will not change.

So, \(n_{1}=n_{2}\)

\(\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{R T_{1}}=\frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{R T_{2}}\)

\(\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{300 R}=\frac{\left(P_{1}\right)\left(3 V_{1}\right)}{R T_{2}}\)

\(\frac{1}{300}=\frac{3}{T_{2}}\)

\(T_{2}=900\) K
A vessel contains two non-reacting gases Helium and Neon. The ratio of their partial pressure is 5 : 2. Find the ratio of the number of molecules of helium and Neon.

The volume and temperature are the same for the two gases.

Given the ratio of partial pressure \(\frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}=\frac{5}{2}\)

We know that:

\(P _{1} V = n _{1} R T \text { and } P _{2} V = n _{2} RT\)

Where, \(P\) is pressure, \(V\) is volume, \(T\) is temperature, \(n\) is no. of mole and \(R\) is the universal gas constant

\(\frac{P_{1}}{ P _{2}}=\frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}=\frac{5}{2}=2.5\)

If \(N _{1}\) and \(N _{2}\) are the numbers of molecules of and \(N\) is the Avogadro's number, then:

\(\frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}=\frac{\frac{N_{1}}{N}}{\frac{N_{2}}{N}}=\frac{5}{2}=2.5\)

Thus, the ratio of the number of molecules of helium and Neon is \(2.5\).
Some gases like Hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen behaves as an ideal gas at:

Some gases like Hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen behaves as an ideal gas at low Pressure and High Temperature.

An ideal gas is a gas that obeys the law of the Ideal Gas Equation.

\(PV = nRT\)

While deriving the ideal gas equation, the following assumptions should be considered:

  • The size of the ideal gas molecules is negligibly small.
  • There must be no force of attraction among the molecules of the gases.
  • Ideal gas work at Low Pressure and High Temperature.
Which of the following is the unit of universal gas constant?

From the ideal gas law, the universal gas constant \(R=\frac{P V}{n T}\)

Unit of Pressure \((P)=\) \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\)

Unit of Temperature \((T)=\)  \(\mathrm{K}\) 

Unit of Volume \(({V})=\)  \(\mathrm{m}^3\)

Unit of Number of moles \(({n})=\)  \(\mathrm{mol}\)

Substituting the units in (1),

\( R=\frac{\left(\mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\right)\left(\mathrm{m}^3\right)}{(\mathrm{mol})(\mathrm{K})}=\mathrm{Nm} \mathrm{mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}\)

So, \(\mathrm{NmK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\) is the unit of \({R}\).

\(\mathrm{Nm}\) is also the unit of energy and can be denoted by joules \((J)\). Thus, \(\mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\) is also a unit of \({R}\).

An erg is a unit of energy equal to \(10^{-7}\) joules. So, \(\mathrm{{erg} K^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}}\) is a unit of \({R}\). Thus, all the given options are correct.
The pressure of an ideal gas undergoing isothermal change is increased by \(10 \%\). The volume of the gas must decrease by about:

Here isothermal process is given,

Temperature \(( T )=\) constant

\(PV = n R T =\) constant

\(P _{1} V _{1}= P _{2} V _{2} \quad \ldots\) (1)

Where, \(P _{1}\) is initial pressure, \(P _{2}\) is final pressure, \(V _{1}\) is initial volume and \(V _{2}\) is final pressure.

Since, pressure is increased by \(10 \%\)

Final pressure \(\left(P_{2}\right)=P+P \times 10 \%=1.1 P\)

Use equation (1);

\(P _{1} V _{1}= P _{2} V _{2}\)

\(P \times V _{1}=1.1 P \times V _{2}\)

\(V _{2}= \frac{V _{1}}{1.1}=\frac{10 V_{1} }{11}\)

Decrease in volume \((\Delta V )= V _{1}- V _{2}= V_{1} -\frac{10 V_{1}}{11}= \frac{V_{1}}{11}\)

\(\%\) Decrease in volume \(=\frac{\Delta V}{V_{1}} \times 100=\frac{V_{1}}{11 V_{1}} \times 100=9.09 \approx 9 \%\)

A stainless steel chamber contains Ar gas at a temperature \(T\) and pressures \(P\). The total number of Ar atoms in the chamber is \(n\). Now Ar gas in the chamber is replaced by \(CO _{2}\) gas and the total number of \(CO _{2}\) molecules in the chamber is \(\frac{n}{2}\) at the same temperature \(T\). The pressure in the chamber now is \(P ^{\prime}\). Which one of the following relations holds true? (Both the gases behave as ideal gases.)

Both Ar and \(CO _{2}\) are ideal gases. So, we will apply the ideal gas equation.

For Ar: The temperature is \(T\), pressure is \(P\), and the number of molecules is \(n\), and volume \(( V )\) is the same for both the gases.

Use ideal gas equation:

\(PV = nRT \quad \ldots\) (1)

For \(CO _{2}\): The temperature is T, Pressure is \(P ^{\prime}\), number of molecules are \(\frac{n}{2}\) and Volume \(( V )\)

Apply Ideal gas equation:

\(P ^{\prime} V=\left(\frac{n}{2}\right) RT\quad \ldots\) (2)

Equation (2) divided by (1):

\(\frac{P ^{\prime}}{P} = \frac{n}{2}\)

\(P^{\prime}=\frac{P}{2}\)
Real gases behave like an ideal gas at:

Real gases behave like an ideal gas at low pressure and high temperature.

The properties of an ideal gas are:

  • They are having negligible volume, point size molecules.
  • There is no attractive or repulsive force between the particles of gas
  • The collision between the gases and the walls of the container should be perfectly elastic (there is no loss of energy).
  • It follows the gas law P V = nRT [P = pressure of the gas, V = volume of the gas, n = moles of the gas, R = 8.314 J/mol-K (Universal gas constant), T = temperature of the gas].

Real Gas: It will obey the gas rule only at high temperature and low pressure.

Its properties are:

  • The molecules are not having negligible volume.
  • They can be repulsive and attractive between the molecules.
  • It obeys Van der waals equation: (P + an2/V2) × (V – nb) = nRT

From the above, it is clear that a real gas behaves like an ideal gas at high temperature and low pressure.
At \(27^{\circ}\) C a gas is compressed suddenly such that its pressure becomes \(\frac{1}{8}\) of original pressure. Final temperature will be \(\left( \gamma =\frac{5}{3}\right)\):

Given: 

\(T _{1}=27+273=300\) K, \(\gamma =\frac{5}{3}, P _{2}=\frac{1}{8} P _{1}\)

Since gas is compressed suddenly, gas is undergone an adiabatic process.

In the adiabatic process,

\(P V^{\gamma}=\) constant

We also know that:

\(T ^{ V } P ^{1- \gamma}=\) Constant

\(T _{1} v P _{1}{ }^{1- \gamma }= T _{2} vP _{2} ^{1- \gamma}\)

Where, \(T_{1}\) is the initial temperature, \(T_{2}\) is the final temperature \(P_{1}\) is the initial pressure, \(P_{2}\) is the final pressure and \(\gamma\) is the adiabatic constant.

\(\frac{P_{1}^{1-\gamma}}{P_{2}^{1-\gamma}}=\frac{T_{2}^{\gamma}}{T_{1}^{\gamma}}\)

\(\left(\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}\right)^{1-\gamma}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{\gamma}\)

\(\left(\frac{P_{1} \times 8}{P_{1}}\right)^{1-\left(\frac{5}{3}\right)}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{300}\right)^{\frac{5}{3}}\)

\(T _{2}=130.58 K\)

\(T _{2}=130.58-273=-142.42^{\circ} C\)

Thus, The final temperature will be \(-142^{\circ} C\).
An ideal gas has pressure \(P\) and the kinetic energy of the unit volume of the gas is \(E\). \(P\) and \(E\) are related as:

The given gas is ideal and therefore obeys the ideal gas equation: \(PV = n R T \quad \ldots\) (1)

Where, \(P\) is the pressure of the gas, \(V\) is the volume of the gas, \(n\) is the number of moles, \(T\) is the temperature and \(R\) is the universal gas constant.

The kinetic energy per unit volume of this gas, \(E =\frac{3}{2} n R T \quad \ldots\) (2)

From (1), the pressure per unit volume \(( V =1\) unit), \(P = nRT\quad \ldots\) (3)

Substituting (3) in (2) we get,

\(E =\frac{3}{2} P\)

\(\Rightarrow P =\frac{2}{3} E\)
The mean free path of gas molecules is proportional to \(n ^{\text {th }}\) power of diameter of molecules. Here \(n\) is:

We know that:

The distance travelled by a gas molecule between two successive collisions is known as a free path. It is given as:

\(\lambda=\frac{\text { Total distance travelled by a gas molecule between successive collisions }}{\text { Total number of collisions }}\)

During two successive collisions, a molecule of gas moves in a straight line with constant velocity, and the mean free path of a gas molecule is given by:

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi n d^{2}} \quad \dots\) (1)

Where, \(n=\) number of molecules per unit volume and \(d=\) diameter of a molecule

From equation (1) we get,

\( \lambda \propto d^{-2}\)

So, \(n ^{\text {th }}\) power of diameter of molecules \(= -2\)
In Maxwell Boltzmann distribution, the fraction of gas molecules having energy between \(E\) and \(E + dE\) is proportional to:

Maxwell Boltzmann distribution for velocity is given by:

\(n(E) d E=\frac{2 \pi N}{V(\pi k T)^{\frac{3}{2}}} E^{\frac{1}{2}} e^{-\frac{E}{k T}} dE\)

Where, \(n=\) number of molecules, \(T=\) temperature, \(k=\) Boltzmann constant, and \(E=\) energy

From the above equation, it is clear that the fraction of gas molecules having an energy between \(E\) and \(E + d E\) is proportional to \(E^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left(-\frac{E}{k T}\right)\).
If temperature of the gas is increased to three times, then its root mean square velocity become:

The rms speed of any homogeneous gas sample is given by:

\(V_{rms}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\) \(\quad \cdots (1)\)

Where, \(R =\) universal gas constant, \(T =\) temperature and \(M =\) Molecular mass

Here, \(M\) and \(R\) is constant,

On increasing the value of T by 3 in equation (1) we get,

\(V _{ rms } \propto \sqrt{3 T }\)

If the temperature is increased to \(3\) times, then \(V _{ rms }\) is increased by \(\sqrt{3}\) times.
The total internal energy of a mole of a rigid diatomic gas is?

The molar specific heat capacity of a gas at constant volume is defined as the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 mol of the gas by \(1^{\circ} C\) at the constant volume.

\(C_{v}=\left(\frac{\Delta Q}{n \Delta T}\right)_{\text {constant volume }}\)

The molar specific heat of a gas at constant pressure is defined as the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of \(1 mol\) of the gas by 1 \({ }^{\circ} C\) at the constant pressure.

\(C_{p}=\left(\frac{\Delta Q}{n \Delta T}\right)_{\text {constant pressure }}\)

The ratio of the two principal specific heat is represented by \(\gamma\).

\(\therefore \gamma=\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}\)

The value of \(\gamma\) depends on the atomicity of the gas.

The total internal energy of a mole of a rigid diatomic gas is,

\(U=\frac{5}{2} R T\)

A piece of glass of mass 100 g heated at \(350^{\circ}\) C is placed in 1 kg of water at \(23.6^{\circ}\) C. What is the final recorded temperature of the system? (The specific heat capacity of the glass = 0.8 J/g\(^{\circ}\) C and specific heat capacity of water = 4.0 J/g\(^{\circ}\) C).

Given: mass of glass \(m_{1}=100\) g, initial temperature \(t_{1}=350^{\circ}\) C, specific heat capacity of the glass \(c _{1}=0.8\) J/g\(^{\circ}\) C and mass of water \(m _{2}=1\) kg \(=1000\) g, final temperature \(t _{2}=23.6^{\circ}\) C, specific heat capacity of water \(C _{2}=4.0\) J/g\(^{\circ}\) C

Let the final temperature of the system will be \(x ^{\circ}\) C.

Heat lost by glass = Heat gained by water

\(m_{1} c_{1}\left(t_{1}-x\right)=m_{2} c_{2}\left(x-t_{2}\right)\)

\(100 \times 0.8 \times(350-x)=1000 \times 4.0(x-23.6)\)

\(350-x=50(x-23.6)\)

\(51 x=1530\)

\(\Rightarrow x=30^{\circ}\) C
The ratio of \(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}\) for a rigid diatomic gas is? (\(C_{p}\) and \(C_{v}\) are molar specific heats at constant pressure and constant volume respectively)

We know that:

The relation between the ratio of \(C_{p}\) and \(C_{V}\) with a degree of freedom is given by,

\(\gamma=\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=1+\frac{2}{f}\)

Where, \(C_{v}=\) molar specific heat capacity of a gas at constant volume, \(C_{p}=\) molar specific heat of a gas at constant pressure, \(f=\) degree of freedom, \(\gamma\) is the adiabatic constant

Diatomic gas has 5 degrees of freedom,

\(\gamma=1+\frac{2}{5}\)

\(=\frac{5+2}{5}\)

\(=\frac{7}{5}\)
Pressure of a gas increases due to increase of its temperature because at higher temperature:
Potential energy of the gas molecules is higher
Kinetic energy of the gas molecules are higher

Pressure of a gas increases due to increase of its temperature because at higher temperature kinetic energy of the gas molecules are higher.

Root mean square speed of gas molecules:

\(\left(V_{r m s}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma R T}{M}}\)

According to the above-given formula for the speed of molecules, when the temperature of the gases increases then the speed of gaseous molecules increases.

The kinetic energy of the molecules increases by an increase in speed.

Due to an increase in the speed of molecules, it moves faster and the collisions between them increase.

Due to an increase in collisions between the molecules, the gaseous pressure increases. So, due to increasing temperature the kinetic energy of molecules increases and finally the pressure increases.
In gases of monoatomic molecules, find the ratio of the two specific heat of gases \(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}\).

For monoatomic:

Degree of freedom \(=3\)

For monoatomic molecules,

\(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=1+\frac{2}{f}\)

Where, \(C_{p}\) is the specific heat at constant pressure, \(C_{v}\) is the specific heat at constant volume and \(f\) is the degree of freedom.

\(=1+\frac{2}{3}\)

\(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=\frac{5}{3} \approx 1.66\)
The ratio of the root mean square speed, average speed and maximum possible speed for a gas will be:

Root mean square velocity of Gaseous particles: Root mean square velocity (RMS value) is the square root of the mean of squares of the velocity of individual gas molecules. It is given by,

\(V_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

Average velocity: It is the arithmetic mean of the velocities of different molecules of a gas at a given temperature. It is given by,

\(V_{a v}=\sqrt{\frac{8 R T}{\pi M}}\)

Most probable velocity: It is the velocity possessed by maximum fraction of molecules at the same temperature. It is given by,

\(V_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{2 R T}{M}}\)

The required ratio between these parameters are,

\(\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}: \sqrt{\frac{8 R T}{\pi M}}: \sqrt{\frac{2 R T}{M}}\)

By Canceling all constant terms from the above expression we have,

\(\sqrt{3}: \sqrt{\frac{8}{\pi}} : \sqrt{2}\)

Or

1.732:1.596:1.414
If one mole of Carbon contains \(x\) atoms, then the number of atoms in \(12\) g of Magnesium is:

1 mole of \(C=x\) atoms \(=N_{A}\) atoms.

We know that \(N _{ A }\) = the number of atoms present in 12 grams of Carbon-12

So, \(x = N _{ A }\)

The atomic mass of \(Mg\) is \(24\) g/mol i.e., 1 mole of Mg \(=24\) g \(= x\) atoms

The number of moles in \(12\) g of Mg \(=\frac{12}{24}=0.5\) moles

1 mole of \(Mg \rightarrow x\) atoms

\(0.5\) mole of \(Mg \rightarrow 0.5 x\) atoms

Therefore, \(12 g\) of Magnesium has \(0.5 x\) atoms.

Which of the following statements about kinetic theory of gases is wrong?
The molecules of a gas are in continuous random motion.
The molecules do not interact with each other except during collisions.
The collisions amongst the molecules are of short duration.

The kinetic theory of gases is based on the assumptions that:

  1. The gas is composed of a large number of identical molecules moving in random directions, separated by distances that are large compared with their size.
  2. The molecules undergo perfectly elastic collisions (no energy loss) with each other and with the walls of the container, but otherwise do not interact.
  3. The transfer of kinetic energy between molecules takes place in the form of heat.

From the above, it is clear that the molecules of the gases undergo perfectly elastic collisions.
A mono atomic molecule free to move in space has how many translational degrees of freedom?

A monoatomic molecule free to move in space has 3 translational degrees of freedom.

For a monoatomic gas,

The number of particle in the system (A) = 1

The number of relations among the particles (R) = 0

The number of degrees of freedom,

N = 3A - R = 3

More amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature
Less amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature
More amount of energy is needed to change its state
Less amount of energy is needed to change its state

If a material have less specific heat then it means that less amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature.

The specific heat capacity (S) of a substance is defined as the amount of heat (\(\Delta Q\)) per unit mass of the substance that is required to raise the temperature

\((\Delta T)\) by \(1^{\circ}\) C

i.e., \(S=\frac{\Delta Q}{m \Delta T}\)

And the unit of Specific heat is J/g\(^{\circ}\) C and Cal/g\(^{\circ}\) C

Here,

\(S =\) specific heat of material

\(\Delta Q=\) heat exchange

\(\Delta T =\) change in temperature

\(m =\) unit mass of material

Thus, if specific heat of a material is less it means that the less amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature.

Initial temperature \(\left(T_{1}\right)=0^{\circ}\) C

Final temperature \(\left(T_{2}\right)=100^{\circ}\) C

Heat absorbed (Q) =?

specific heat capacity (C) \(=140\) J/(kg K)

We know that: Heat absorbed is given by,

\(Q=m C \Delta T\)

\(Q=0.01 \times 140 \times(100-0)=140\) J

If the gas particles are of diameter '\(d\)', average speed '\(v\)', number of particles per unit volume '\(n\)', then the average distance between two successive collisions, called the mean free path is ______.

The distance travelled by a gas molecule between two successive collisions is known as a free path.

\(\lambda=\frac{\text { Total distance travelled by a gas molecule between successive collisions }}{\text { Total number of collisions }}\)

During two successive collisions, a molecule of gas moves in a straight line with constant velocity, and the mean free path of a gas molecule is given by,

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi n d^{2}}\)

Where, \(n=\) number of molecules per unit volume and \(d=\) diameter of a molecule

From the above, it is clear that the average distance between two successive collisions called the mean free path is \(\lambda=\frac{1}{\pi n d^{2}}\).
The mean free path of electrons in a metal is \(4 \times 10^{-8}\) m. The electric field which can be given on an average 2 eV energy to an electron in the metal will be in units of V/m:

Given: The mean free path of electron \(r =4 \times 10^{-8}\) m

Energy \(=2\) eV

Let Potential difference between two collisions \(=V_{0}\)

The energy required to bring an electron between these points \(= eV _{0}\), on equating energy and Potential difference between two collisions,

\(eV _{0}=2\) eV

\(\Rightarrow V _{0}=2\) V

We know that, electric field is the ratio of potential difference by the distance between two points.

E \(=\frac{V}{r}\)

\( E=\frac{2}{4 \times 10^{-8}}\)

\(\Rightarrow E =0.5 \times 10^{8}\) V/m \(=5 \times 10^{7}\) V/m
According to Kinetic molecular theory of gases, which of the following postulate is true:
There exists force of attraction between the particles of a gas at ordinary temperature and pressure
At any particular time, different particles in the gas have same speeds
Particles of gas move in straight line

According to Kinetic molecular theory of gases particles of gas move in straight line.

According to Kinetic molecular theory of gases:

  • There is no force of attraction between the particles of a gas at ordinary temperature and pressure.
  • Collisions of gas molecules are perfectly elastic.
  • At any particular time, different particles in the gas have different speeds and hence different kinetic energies.
  • Particles of gas move in straight line.
Which one of the following is not an assumption in the kinetic theory of gases?
The volume which is occupied by the gas molecules is almost negligible
The force of attraction between the molecules is negligible

Kinetic theory assumes that molecules are very small in size relative to the distance between molecules. The collision between molecules is an elastic collision, that means there is no net loss of kinetic energy. The force of attraction between the molecules is also very less almost negligible. Gas particles are rapid, continuous and random motion.

Two liquids \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) are at temperatures \(75^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), respectively. Their masses are in the ratio \(2: 3\) and specific heats are in the ratio \(3: 4\). The resultant temperature of the mixture, when the above liquids are mixed (neglect the water equivalent of container ) is:

Heat lost by one liquid = Heat gained by another liquid

\(\mathrm{m}_{1} \cdot \mathrm{C}_{1} \cdot \Delta \mathrm{T}_{1}=\mathrm{m}_{2} \cdot \mathrm{C}_{2} \cdot \Delta \mathrm{T}_{2}\)

\(m_{1} \cdot C_{1}(T-75)=m_{2} \cdot C_{2}(150-T)\)

\(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{2}} \cdot \frac{c_{1}}{c_{2}}=\frac{150-T}{T-75}\)

\(\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{3}{4}=\frac{150-\mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{T}-75}\)

\(\frac{1}{2}=\frac{150-T}{T-75}\)

\(T-75=300-2 T\)

\(3 \mathrm{~T}=375\)

\(\mathrm{T}=125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

Find the amount of work done to increase the temperature of one mole of an ideal gas by \(30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), if it is expanding under the condition \(\mathrm{V} \propto \mathrm{T}^{23} .(\mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mole} / \mathrm{K})\):

Given \(\mathrm{V} \alpha \mathrm{T}^{23} \ldots .(1)\)

Substituting \(\mathrm{T}=\frac{\mathrm{PV}}{\mathrm{R}}\) in eqn(1) we get

\(\mathrm{V}=\operatorname{constant}\left(\frac{\mathrm{PV}}{\mathrm{R}}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{P}^{\frac{2}{3}} \mathrm{~V}^{\frac{-1}{3}}=\) constant

\(\therefore \mathrm{PV}^{\frac{-1}{2}}=\) constant

\(\therefore\) polytropic exponent \(\eta\) is \(\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)\)

Work done in a polytropic process : \(\mathrm{W}=\frac{-\mathrm{R} \Delta \mathrm{T}}{\eta-1} \ldots .(2)\)

Substituting the values in (2)

\(\mathrm{W}=\frac{-8.31 \times 30}{\frac{-1}{2}-1}=166.2\)

Suppose \(4.00 \mathrm{~mol}\) of an ideal gas undergo a reversible isothermal expansion from volume \(V_{1}\) to volume \(V_{2}=2.00 V_{1}\) at temperature \(T=400 \mathrm{~K}\). Find the entropy change of the gas. If the expansion is reversible and adiabatic instead of isothermal,what is the entropy change of the gas?

\(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{nRT} \ln \frac{\mathrm{V}_{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_{1}}=4 \times 8.31 \times 400 \times \ln \frac{2.0 \mathrm{~V}_{1}}{\mathrm{~V}_{1}}=9216 \mathrm{~J}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=\int_{\mathrm{i}}^{\mathrm{f}} \frac{\mathrm{dQ}}{\mathrm{T}}\)

If \(\propto\) is the coefficient of performance of a refrigerator and ' \(Q_{1}^{\prime}\) is heat released to the hot reservoir, then the heat extracted from the cold reservoir' \(\mathrm{Q}_{2}^{\prime}\) is:

We have,

Coefficient Of Performance (COP) of a refrigerator, \(\alpha=\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{2}}{\mathrm{Q}_{1}-\mathrm{Q}_{2}}\)

where,

\(\alpha\) is coefficient of performance

\(Q_{1}\) is heat released to the hot reservoir

\(Q_{2}\) is the heat extracted from the cold reservoir

Then,

\(\frac{1}{\alpha}=\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{1}-\mathrm{Q}_{2}}{\mathrm{Q}_{2}}\)

\(\frac{1}{\alpha}=\frac{Q_{1}}{Q_{2}}-1\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}{\mathrm{Q}_{2}}=1+\frac{1}{\alpha}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}{\mathrm{Q}_{2}}=\frac{\alpha+1}{\alpha}\)

\(\mathrm{Q}_{2}=\frac{\alpha \mathrm{Q}_{1}}{1+\alpha}\)

So the heat extracted from the cold reservoir \(\mathrm{Q}_{2}=\frac{\alpha \mathrm{Q}_{1}}{1+\alpha}\).

The molar heat capacity of solid gold is given by the relation

\(C_{\mathrm{p}, \mathrm{m}}=25.69-7.32 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~T}+4.56 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~T}^{2}\) in units of \(\mathrm{Jmol}^{1} \mathrm{~K}^{1}\). Calculate the entropy change for heating \(2.50\) moles of gold from \(22.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) at constant pressure.

The entropy change for heating at constant pressure is

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=\int_{\mathrm{T}_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}_{2}} \frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}}{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{dT}\)

or since \(C_{P}=n_{P, m}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=\int_{\mathrm{T}_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}_{2}} \frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}, \mathrm{m}}}{\mathrm{T}} \mathrm{dT}\)

Substituting the heat capacity for gold and integrating yields

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=\int_{\mathrm{T}_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}_{2}} \frac{1}{\mathrm{~T}}\left(25.69-7.32 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~T}+4.58 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^{2}\right) \mathrm{dT}\)

\(=25.69 \mathrm{n} \int_{\mathrm{T}_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}_{2}} \frac{1}{\mathrm{~T}} \mathrm{dT}-7.32 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{n} \int_{\mathrm{T}_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}_{2}} \mathrm{dT}+4.58 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{n} \int_{\mathrm{T}_{1}}^{\mathrm{T}_{2}} \mathrm{~T} \mathrm{dT}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=25.69 \mathrm{n} \ln \left(\frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}}\right)-7.32 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{n}\left(\mathrm{T}_{2}-\mathrm{T}_{1}\right)+4.58 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{n}\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\mathrm{T}_{1}^{2}}{2}\right)\)

For \(2.5\) moles of gold being heated from \(295 \mathrm{~K}\) to \(1273 \mathrm{~K}\), the entropy change is

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=25.69(2.5 \mathrm{~mol}) \ln \left(\frac{1273}{295}\right)-7.32 \times 10^{-4}(2.5 \mathrm{~mol})(1273-295)+4.58 \times\) \(10^{-2}(2.5 \mathrm{~mol})\left(\frac{(1273)^{2}}{2}-\frac{(295)^{2}}{2}\right)\)

\(=93.91-1.79+8.78=100.9 \mathrm{JK}^{-1}\)

An ideal gas enclosed in a vertical cylindrical container supports a freely moving piston of mass \(\mathrm{M}\). The piston and cylinder have equal cross sectional area \(\mathrm{A}\). When the piston is in equilibrium, the volume of the gas is \(V_{0}\) and its pressure is \(P_{0}\). The piston is slightly displaced from the equilibrium position and released. Assuming that the system is completely isolated from its surrounding, the piston executes a simple harmonic motion with frequency:

Let the piston be displaced by small amount X and the increase in pressure be △p. 

Initial pressure \(\mathrm{P}_{1}=\mathrm{P}_{0}+\frac{\mathrm{Mg}}{\mathrm{A}}\)

Volume \(\mathrm{V}_{1}=\mathrm{V}_{0}\)

Final pressure \(P_{2}=P_{1}+\Delta \mathrm{p}\)

Volume \(\mathrm{V}_{2}=\mathrm{V}_{0}-\Delta \mathrm{V}, \Delta \mathrm{V}=\mathrm{Ax}\)

Applying Poisson's equation

\(\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{~V}_{1}^{\gamma}=\mathrm{P}_{2} \mathrm{~V}_{2}^{\gamma}\)

\(\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{~V}_{1}^{\gamma}=\left(\mathrm{P}_{1}+\Delta \mathrm{p}\right)\left(\mathrm{V}_{0}-\Delta \mathrm{V}\right)^{\gamma}\)

\(=\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{~V}_{0}^{\gamma}\left(1+\frac{\Delta \mathrm{P}}{\mathrm{P}_{1}}\right)\left(1-\frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}_{0}}\right)^{\gamma}\)

\(1=\left(1+\frac{\Delta \mathrm{P}}{\mathrm{P}_{1}}\right)\left(1-\gamma \frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}_{0}}\right)\)

\(=1-\gamma \frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}_{0}}+\frac{\Delta \mathrm{P}}{\mathrm{P}_{1}}-\gamma \frac{\Delta \mathrm{P} \cdot \Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{~V}_{0}}\)

Neglecting second order terms we have

\(\Delta \mathrm{p}=\frac{\gamma \mathrm{P}_{1} \Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}_{0}}\)

Restoring force on piston

\(\mathrm{F}=-\mathrm{A} \Delta \mathrm{P}\)

\(=-\frac{\gamma \mathrm{AP}_{1}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}} \cdot(\mathrm{Ax})\)

\(=-\frac{\gamma \mathrm{A}^{2} \mathrm{P}_{1}}{\mathrm{~V}_{0}} \mathrm{x}\)

Acceleration of piston

\(a=\frac{F}{M}=-\left(\frac{\gamma A^{2} P_{1}}{M V_{0}}\right) \mathrm{x}\)

Acceleration is proportional to the displacement, therefore motion is simple harmonic angular frequency of oscillation

\(\omega=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma \mathrm{A}^{2} \mathrm{P}_{1}}{M V_{0}}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{f}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{\gamma \mathrm{A}^{2}}{\mathrm{MV}_{0}}\left(\mathrm{P}_{0}+\frac{\mathrm{Mg}}{\mathrm{A}}\right)}\)

One mole of ideal monoatomic gas \((\mathrm{v}=\frac{5}{3})\) is mixed with one mole of diatomic gas \((\gamma=\frac{7}{5})\). What is \(\gamma\) for the mixture? ( \(\gamma\) denotes the ratio of specific heat at constant pressure, to that at constant volume.)

For a monoatomic gas:

\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{R}}{2}\)

For a diatomic gas:

\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{5 \mathrm{R}}{2}\)

Thereofore \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}_{\text {vvg }}}=\frac{\frac{3 \mathrm{R}}{2}+\frac{5 \mathrm{R}}{2}}{2}=2 \mathrm{R}\)

\(\mathrm{Also} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}=\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}+\mathrm{R}\)

\(\Rightarrow C_{\text {pugg }}=3 R\)

\(\Rightarrow \gamma=\frac{C_{p_{\text {avg }}}}{C_{V_{\mathrm{vVI}}}}=\frac{3}{2}\)

Two cylinders A and B fitted with pistons contain equal number of moles of an ideal monoatomic gas at \(400 \mathrm{~K}\). The piston of \(A\) is free to move while that of \(B\) is held fixed Same amount of heat energy is given to the gas in each cylinder. If the rise in temperature of the gas in \(\mathrm{A}\) is \(42 \mathrm{~K}\), the rise in temperature of the gas in \(\mathrm{B}\) is: \(\left(\gamma=\frac{5}{3}\right)\):

Piston of A is free to move, implies heat is added at constant pressure.

\(\mathrm{dQ}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{p}} \mathrm{dT} \mathrm{T}_{1}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \mathrm{dT_{1 }}+\mathrm{nRdT_{1 }}\)

Piston B, the heat is added at constant volume

\(\mathrm{dQ}=\mathrm{dU}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \mathrm{dT}_{2}\)

Given that same amount of heat is supplied

\(\therefore \mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \mathrm{dT}_{1}+\mathrm{nRdT}_{1}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \mathrm{dT}_{2}\)

Given, \(\gamma=\frac{5}{3}, C_{p}=5 \frac{R}{2} C_{v}=\frac{3R}{2}\)

\(\frac{3 \mathrm{R}}{2} \mathrm{dT}_{1}+\mathrm{R} d \mathrm{~T}_{1}=\frac{3 \mathrm{R}}{2} \mathrm{dT}_{2}\)

\(\mathrm{dT}_{2}=\frac{5 \mathrm{dT}_{1}}{3}=\frac{5}{3}(42)=70 \mathrm{~K}\)

An ideal gas of mass \(m\) in a state A goes to another state \(B\) via three different processes as shown in the fig. If \(\mathrm{Q}_{1}, \mathrm{Q}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{Q}_{3}\) denote heats absorbed by the gas along three paths respectively then

From 1st law of thermodynamics

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

where, ΔQ is the heat supplied to the system, ΔU is the change in internal energy, ΔW is the work done by the  system

In the P-V diagram work done is area under the curve.

Process 3 lies above processes 1 and 2 and has maximum area. Process 1 has the least area.

Hence, \(\Delta \mathrm{W}_{3}>\Delta \mathrm{W}_{2}>\Delta \mathrm{W}_{1}\)

Since initial states for all three processes are same and final states for all three process are same,

\(\Delta \mathrm{U}_{1}=\Delta \mathrm{U}_{2}=\Delta \mathrm{U}_{3}\)

\(\therefore \Delta \mathrm{Q}_{3}>\Delta \mathrm{Q}_{2}>\Delta \mathrm{Q}_{1}\)
One mole of Ideal monatomic gas \(\left(\gamma=\frac{5}{3}\right)\) is mixed with one mole of diatomic gas \(\left(\gamma=\frac{7}{5}\right)\). What is \(\gamma\) for the mixture?

Total no of moles: \(\mu=\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}=1+1=2\)

\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{\gamma-1}\)

\(\left(C_{v}\right)_{\operatorname{mix}}=\frac{\frac{\mu_{1} R}{\gamma_{1}-1}+\frac{\mu_{2} R}{\gamma_{2}-1}}{\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}}\)

\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}=\frac{\mathrm{R} \gamma}{\gamma-1}\)

\(\left(C_{p}\right)_{\operatorname{mix}}=\frac{\frac{\mu_{1} R \gamma_{1}}{\gamma_{1}-1}+\frac{\mu_{2} R \gamma_{2}}{\gamma_{2}-1}}{\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}}\)

\(\gamma_{\operatorname{mix}}=\frac{2 \gamma_{1} \gamma_{2}-\gamma_{1}-\gamma_{2}}{\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2}-2}=\frac{2 \times \frac{5}{3} \times \frac{7}{5}-\frac{5}{3}-\frac{7}{5}}{\frac{5}{3}+\frac{7}{5}-2}=\frac{\frac{24}{15}}{\frac{16}{15}}=\frac{3}{2}\)

Two cylinders A and B fitted with pistons contain equal amounts of an ideal diatomic gas at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). The piston of \(\mathrm{A}\) is free to move, while that of \(\mathrm{B}\) is held fixed. The same amount of heat is given to the gas in each cylinder. If the rise in temperature of the gas in \(\mathrm{A}\) is \(30 \mathrm{~K}\), then the rise in temperature of the gas in \(\mathrm{B}\) is:

Given there are two cylinders A and B fitted with pistons. The piston A is free to move and B is fixed. Same amount of heat is passed to each of the cylinder. The rise in temperature of the gas in A is 30K. We should find the rise in temperature of the gas in B.

Here the process in cylinder A is constant pressure process and process in cylinder B is constant volume process since the piston in B is fixed.

\(Q={ }_{n} C_{P} \Delta T_{1}\)

\(Q={ }_{n} C_{V} \Delta T_{2}\)

Let us divide both the equations above we get

\(\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}}=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{T}_{2}}{\Delta \mathrm{T}_{1}}=\gamma\)

Change in Temperature:

We know for a diatomic gas \(\gamma=\frac{7}{5}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{T}_{2}=\frac{7}{5} \times 30\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{T}_{2}=42 \mathrm{~K}\)
Which of the following statements is incorrect?
A reversible cycle is more efficient than irreversible one
Carnot cycle is the most efficient among all cycles

All reversible cycle has same efficiency statements is incorrect.

We know that carnot cycle is reversible cycle, and reversible cycle has maximum efficiency of all other cycles
The coefficient of performance of a refrigerator is 5 . If the temperature inside freezer is \(-20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), the temperature of the surroundings to which it rejects heat is:

Coefficient of performance: \(\mathrm{COP}=\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}{\mathrm{~W}}=\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{1}}{\mathrm{Q}_{1}-\mathrm{Q}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}-\mathrm{T}_{2}}\) where where \(\mathrm{T}_{1}\) is temp of heat bath and \(T_{2}\) is temp of cold bath.

Temp of heat bath and \(\mathrm{T}_{2}\) is temp of cold bath.

\(\Rightarrow 5=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{2}}{\mathrm{~T}_{1}-(-20)}\)

\(\Rightarrow 6 \mathrm{~T}_{2}=5 \mathrm{~T}_{1}\)

\(\Rightarrow 6 \times(-20+273)=5 \mathrm{~T}_{1}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{1}=31^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

The specific heat capacity of a metal at low temperature \((\mathrm{T})\) is given as \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\left(\mathrm{kJk}^{-1}\right)=\) \(32\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}}{400}\right)^{2} \cdot \mathrm{A} 100\) gram vessel of this metal is to be cooled from \(20^{\circ} \mathrm{K}\) to \(4^{\circ} \mathrm{K}\) by a special refrigerator operating at room temperature \(\left(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\). The amount of work required to cool the vessel is:

It is given that \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}=32\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}}{400}\right)^{3}\)

Since, it is an isothermal process because here temperature is constant i.e., \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

\(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{U}+\mathrm{W}\)

\(\because \mathrm{U}=0\)

so, \(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{W} \ldots \ldots . .(1)\)

and \(d Q=m C_{p} d T\)

so, \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{Q}=\int \mathrm{mC}_{\mathrm{p}} \mathrm{dT}\)

\(=\int_{20}^{4} 0.1 \times 32 \times\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}}{400}\right)^{3} \mathrm{dT}\)

\(=\int_{20}^{4} \frac{3.2}{64 \times 10^{6}} \mathrm{~T}^{3} \mathrm{dT}\)

\(=5 \times 10^{-8} \int_{20}^{4} \mathrm{~T}^{3} \mathrm{dT}\)

\(=5 \times 10^{-8} \int_{20}^{4} \frac{\mathrm{T}^{4}}{4} \mathrm{dT}\)

\(=0.002 \mathrm{~kJ}\)
The work done in adiabatic change in a gas depends only on:
According to Work done in adiabatic change \(=\frac{\mu \mathrm{R}\left(\mathrm{T}_{1}-\mathrm{T}_{2}\right)}{\gamma-1}\), it only depends on change in temperature.
When an ideal monoatomic gas is heated at constant pressure, the fraction of the heat energy supplied which increases the internal energy of the gas is:

By first law of thermodynamics

\(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{U}+\mathrm{W}\)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{f}}{2} \mathrm{nRT}+\mathrm{P} \int \mathrm{dV}=\frac{\mathrm{f}}{2} \mathrm{nRT}+\mathrm{PV}\)

or \(Q=\frac{f}{2} n R T+n R T(\because P V=n R T)\)

\(=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{nRT}+\mathrm{nRT}=\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{nRT}\)

\(\therefore\) Fraction of heat energy supplied \(=\frac{U}{Q}\)

\(=\frac{(\frac{3}{2}) n R T}{(\frac{5}{2}) n R T}=\frac{3}{5}\)
110 Joules of heat are added to a gaseous system, whose internal energy is 40 J; then the amount of external work done is:

According to the first law of thermodynamics we have,

\(\Delta \mathrm{U}=\mathrm{Q}+\mathrm{W}\)

\(40=110+W\)

\(\mathrm{W}=70 \mathrm{~J}\)

A Carnot engine, having an efficiency of \(\eta=\frac{1}{10}\) as heat engine, is used as a refrigerator. If the work done on the system is \(10 \mathrm{~J}\), the amount of energy absorbed from the reservoir at lower temperature is:

Efficiency of carnot cycle is given as 

\(\eta=\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{H}}}\)

where \(W\) is work done and \(Q_{H}\) is amount of heat added to system.

\(\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{H}}=\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\eta}=100 \mathrm{~J}\)

\(\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{C}}=\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{H}}-\mathrm{W}=100-10=90 \mathrm{~J}\)
What makes molecules tend to drive back to their original positions when a deforming force is removed from an elastic material?
Deforming force gives a negative force to make molecules back to original position.
Charge on the molecules makes molecules to come back to its original positions.
Intermolecular forces that works between the molecules.
The real cause has not been determined yet.

Option (A): The deforming force does not give a negative force, it only deforms the body. So, deforming force is not the reason to drive molecules back to their original positions.

Option (B): There may be or may not be a charge on the molecules of the solid. So this can't be the reason to drive molecules back to their original positions.

Option (C): When the deforming force is removed, the interatomic force between the molecules tries to bring back the body into its original position.
Which among the following is a material that does not show elastic after effect?

Steel, copper, and rubber are known to regain their original shape and size after being deformed within the elastic limit.

Quartz is highly elastic in nature as it does not get deformed easily. As a result, quartz has practically no elastic after effect.
A 120 cm long rod is subjected to an axial pull of 18 kN. If the diameter of the rod is 3 cm, the stress acting on it is:

Given that:

Axial force, F = 18 kN = 18 × 103 N

Diameter of the rod, d = 3 cm = 30 mm

Cross-sectional area, A \(=\frac{\pi}{4}\) d\(^{2}=\frac{\pi}{4}(30)^{2}=706.85\) mm2

We know that, 

Stress, \(\sigma=\frac{F}{A}=\frac{18 \times 10^{3}}{706.85}=25.47\) N/mm2
If the length of a rod becomes half by cutting it, how much load it can bear before breaking as compared to before?

Breaking Stress: It is also called ultimate tensile stress. It is the maximum stress a material can stand before it breaks.

Tensile stress:  The force applied along a rod divided by the cross-sectional area of the rod perpendicular to the applied force is called tensile stress.

Tensile stress \(= \frac{\text{Force}}{\text{Cross section area}}\)

From the definition, it is clear that the breaking stress of a rod does not depend on its length.

So, If we half the length of the rod, the force required to break it will remain the same. So, it can bear the same load as before.
The length of a wire is 'L' and volume is V(fixed). If constant force F is applied on the wire, the extension produced in the wire will be proportional to _____

Given that length = L and volume = V and Force = F

Since, in the stress formula we have to use area A that is not given in the question.

So, Volume V = Area A × length L

A = \(\frac{V}{L}\)

From Hooke's law,

Stress = k × Strain

From Hooke's law,

\(\frac{F}{A}=k \times \frac{\Delta L}{L}\)

\(\frac{F}{\frac{V}{L}}=k \times \frac{\Delta L}{L}\)

\(\frac{F L}{V}=k \times \frac{\Delta L}{L}\)

\(\frac{F L^{2}}{k V}=\Delta L\)

So, extension \(\Delta L \propto L^{2}\)

The extension produced in this wire by a constant force \(F\) is proportional to \(L^{2}\).
If stress developed in a material is \(6 \times 10^{7}\) N/m and strain developed is \(2 \times 10^{2}\). What will be the proportionality constant according to Hook's law?

Given: 

Stress \(=6 \times 10^{7}\) N/m and strain \(=2 \times 10^{2}\)

We know that:

Stress \(= k \times\) Strain

Where, \(k\) is the proportionality constant.

So, from the formula of stress, we get, 

\(6 \times 10^{7}= k \times 2 \times 10^{2}\)

\(k =3 \times 10^{5}\) N/m
Which of the following is correct regarding the region B to D in a typical stress-strain curve as given below?
Point B to D, material follows Hook's Law.
Strain does not occur for given stress.
Strain increases very slowly even for a small change in the stress.
Strain increases rapidly even for a small change in the stress.

Option (D): From B to D, in the stress-strain curve, the curve is almost flat or increasing slowly.

This flatness tells that a very less increase in stress will give a high change in strain because the slope is very low.

Option (A): A material follows Hook's law in the region from O to point A only.

So, this is not the correct answer.

Option (B): Since in region B to D curve increasing in the x-axis i.e. strain axis, it means the material has a strain in this region.

So, this is not the correct answer.

Option (C): If the slope of the curve were high, the less change in strain would have been due to more change in the stress.

But the curve here B to D is less sloped or almost flat for some material.

So, this is not the correct answer.
Which of the following is correct for point A to B in the stress-strain curve?
If we remove the load the body will return to its original dimension
If we remove the load the body will not return to its original dimension

Option (A): Point B is the elastic point. Up to point B, when the load is removed, the body returns to its original dimension.

Option (B): Stress is proportional to strain up to point A from point O.

Hook's law is followed up to in the region of OA only. After it, there is no proportionality.

So, in the region A to B, the material does not follow proportionality law or Hook's law.

Therefore, both options (A) and (B) are the correct answer.
An increase of \(0.1 \%\) in the length of a wire of cross-section \(10^{-6}\) m\(^{2}\) causes tension of \(1 \times 100\) N in the wire. The Young's modulus of the material of the wire is:

Given: \(\% dl\) is percentage change in lenght \(=0.1 \%\), A is area \(=10^{-6}\) m\(^{2}\) and P is Tension in wire \(=100\) N

We know that,

\(\% d l=\frac{d l}{l} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \% d l=\frac{d l}{l} \times 100=0.1\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d l}{l}=10^{-3} \quad \cdots\) (1)

By Hooke's law,

\(\sigma=E \epsilon\)

Where, \(\sigma\) is stress, E is young's modulus, \(\epsilon\) is strain.

From the formula, we get,

\( E=\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{\frac{P}{A}}{\frac{d l}{l}}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{100}{10^{-6} \times 10^{-3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=10^{11}\) N/m\(^{2}\)

A steel wire of 1 m long and 1 mm\(^{2}\) cross-section area is hanged from the rigid end when the weight of 1 kg is hung from it then change in length will be (for wire Youngs coefficient Y \(=2 \times 10^{11}\) N/m\(^{2})\):

Given: Young modulus \(Y =2 \times 10^{11}\) N/m\(^{2}\), mass \(m =1\) Kg, \(L =1\) m, Area \(A =1\) mm\(^{2}=1 \times 10^{-6}\) m\(^{2}\), Change in length \(\Delta L =?\), and Force F \(=\) mg \(=1 \times 10=10\) N

The young modulus of the material is given by,

\(Y=\frac{F L}{A \Delta l}\)

The above equation can be rewritten for \(\Delta L\) as,

\(\Delta L=\frac{F L}{A Y}\)

Substituting the given value in the above equation,

\(\Delta L=\frac{10 \times 1}{1 \times 10^{-6} \times 2 \times 10^{11}}=5 \times 10^{-5}\) m

\(\Rightarrow \Delta L =0.05\) mm
Why water is more elastic than air?

It is known that liquids are incompressible and gases can be easily compressed.

Therefore, water has greater resistance to compression than water i.e., it has a greater value of bulk modulus of elasticity. Also, water is more elastic than air because bulk modulus of elasticity is reciprocal of compressibility and air is more compressible than water. Thus, water will be more elastic than air as air has greater compressibility.
In the elastic behaviour of solids, the intermolecular forces are in which equilibrium?
Intermolecular forces are not in the equilibrium

Each molecule of an elastic solid is acted upon by the forces because of neighboring molecules known as intermolecular force.

Due to an external force on an elastic body, the body gets displaced. Thus, molecules are displaced from their original position. But when the external force is removed, they come back to its original position. Thus, the force between the molecules (intermolecular forces) is in stable equilibrium.
A liquid placed inside a glass tube rises due to capillary action. If the angle of contact made by the liquid on the glass is \(\theta\), which of the following is true?

Consider a capillary tube of radius r dipped in a liquid of density \(\rho\). Let us assume that the liquid rises to a height of \(h\) in the tube due to the surface tension \(\sigma\) and g is acceleration due to gravity.


    \(\theta\) is the contact angle made by the liquid meniscus with the capillary tube's surface.

    On balancing the forces in the liquid column of height \(h\),

    Weight of the water in column = Upwards force due to surface tension

    Mass of water \(\times g =\sigma \cos \theta \times\) perimeter

    Density \(\times\) volume \(\times g=\sigma \cos \theta \times 2 \pi r\)

    \(\rho \times \pi r^{2} h \times g=\sigma \cos \theta \times 2 \pi r\)

    Capillary rise, \(h=\frac{2 \sigma \cos \theta}{\rho g r}\)

    Capillary rise is dependent on \(\theta\). Therefore capillary rise depends on the values of \(\cos \theta\).

    For a rise in the liquid column, the value of capillary rise 'h' must be positive. This is possible when \(\cos \theta\) is positive i.e., \(0^{\circ}<\theta<90^{\circ}\)
The Young's modulus of the material of a wire is \(2 \times 10^{10}\) N/m\(^{2}\). If the elongation strain is \(1 \%\), then the energy stored in the wire per unit volume in J/m\(^{3}\) is:

Given: Young modulus \(Y =2 \times 10^{10} N / m ^{2}\), elongation strain is \(1 \%, U =\) energy stored per unit volume.

We know that:

Young's modulus, Y \(=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}\)

Using this the energy stored per unit volume can be given as,

U \(=\frac{\text { strain energy }}{\text { volume }}=\frac{1}{2} \times Y \times \text {strain}^{2} \quad \dots\) (1)

Now, as we have all the values just put it in the equation number (1),

\(U =\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \times 2 \times 10^{10} \times \left(\frac{1}{100}\right)^{2}=10^{6}\) J/m\(^{3}\)

So, energy stored in the wire per unit volume in J/m\(^{3}\) is \(10^{6}\).

A student conducted an experiment on a wire and observed that there was no change in the volume of the wire due to a change in its length by stretching. The Poisson's ratio of the material of the wire is:

Let the length of the wire be I, r its radius, and A its cross-sectional area.

Poisson's ratio, \(\nu=-\frac{\epsilon_{t}}{\epsilon_{l}}=-\frac{\frac{d r}{r}}{\frac{d l}{l}} \quad \ldots\) (1)

Volume of wire, \(V=\) Length \(\times\) Cross-sectional area \(=l \times \pi r^{2}\)

\(d V =\pi r ^{2} \cdot d +2 mrl \cdot dr\)

Since, there is no change in volume, \(dV =0\)

\(0=\pi r^{2} \cdot d l+2 \pi r l dr\)

\(\Rightarrow \pi r^{2} \cdot d l=-2 \pi r l \cdot d r\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d r}{r}=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d l}{l}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\frac{d r}{r}}{\frac{d l}{l}}=-\frac{1}{2}\quad \ldots\) (2)

Substituting (2) in (1),

Poisson's ratio, \(\nu=-\frac{\frac{d r}{r}}{\frac{d l}{l}}=-\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=0.5\)
When a spring is stretched by 2 cm the energy stored is 100 J. If it is stretched further by 2 cm, its energy increases by ________.

Given:

Length of spring \({x}=2\) cm

\(\text {Energy stored }=\frac{1}{2} {kx}^{2}\)

\(100=0.5 \times {k} \times 2^{2}\)

\({k}\) =\(\frac{100}{2}=50\)

\(\text {Now, } {x}=4\) cm

\(\text {Energy stored }=\frac{1}{2}{kx}^{2}\)

\(=0.5 \times 50 \times 4^{2} \)

\(=400\) J

So, stored energy increases by \(= 400-100=300\)
Work done in blowing the soap bubble in the air of radius 2R is W. Find the work done in blowing the soap bubble of radius R.

We know that:

Work done to blow a bubble \(=\) Surface tension \(\times\) surface area

Since, the soap bubble is in the air so there will be two surfaces in contact with the air (inside and outside)

Work done to blow a bubble \(=\) Surface tension \(\times 2 \times\) surface area of the bubble

Work done to blow a bubble of radius 2R

\(W = T \times 2 \times A\)

Where, T is the surface tension and A  is area

\(W = T \times 2 \times\left(4 \pi(2 R )^{2}\right)\)

\(W =32 T \pi R ^{2} \quad \ldots\) (i)

Work done to blow a bubble of radius R

\(W ^{\prime}= T \times 2 \times A = T \times 2 \times\left(4 \pi R ^{2}\right)\)

\(W ^{\prime}=8 T \pi R ^{2}\quad \ldots\) (ii)

Eq (ii) / eq (i)

\(\frac{W^{\prime}}{W} =\frac{8 T \pi R^{2}}{32 T \pi R^{2}}\)

\(\frac{W^{\prime}}{W} =\frac{1}{4}\)

\(W^{\prime}=\frac{W}{4}\)
Calculate the work done in blowing the soap bubble when the difference in surface area is 1 cm\(^{-2}\) and surface tension of bubble is 3 dyne cm\(^{-1}\).

Given: The change in the Area of the soap bubble \((\Delta A)\)

\(\Delta A =1\) cm\(^{2}\)

\(W = S \times \Delta A\)

Where, W is the work done, S is the surface tension of bubble

\(W =3 \times 1 erg\)

\(W =3~erg\)

Since, \(1 \text { erg }=1 \times 10^{-7}\) J

\(W =3 \times 10^{-7}\) J

So, work done is \(3 \times 10^{-7}\) J
The specific gravity of an oil is 0.9 and the viscosity of the oil is 0.28 stokes at 38ºC. What will be the viscosity in Ns/m2?

Given:

ρ = 0.9 x 1000 kg/m3

ν = 0.28 stokes = 0.28 x 10-4 m2/s

We know that,

μ = ρ x ν

Where, ρ = density of oil = specific gravity of oil x density of water, μ is viscosity in Ns/m2  and ν is viscosity of oil

μ = (0.9 x 1000) x (0.28 x 10-4) Ns/m2

μ = 0.0252 Ns/m2

A square metal plate of 10 cm side moves parallel to another plate with a velocity of 10 cms-1, both plates immersed in water. If the viscous force is 200 dyne and the viscosity of water is 0.01 poise, what is their distance apart?

Given: \(A=100\) cm\(^{2}\), \(\eta=0.01\) poise, \(dv=10\) cms\(^{-1}\), \(dy=?\)

We know that:

Newton's formula for the viscous force between two parallel layers is given by:

\(F =\eta A \frac{ dv }{ dy }\)

Where, \(\eta \) is viscosity of water, A is area, dv is velocity and dy is distance

On putting the value of the above we get,

\(dy =\frac{\eta Adv }{ F }\)

Pressure inside two soap bubbles is 1.01 and 1.03 atmosphere. Ratio between their volumes is:

Given:

Atmospheric pressure \(=1\)

Pressure in bubble \(1=1.01\)

Pressure in bubble \(2=1.03\)

So, external pressure in bubble 1 is \(1.01-1=0.01\) atm

External pressure in bubble 2 is \(1.03-1=0.03\) atm

Let the radius of bubble 1 is \(R _{1}\)

Let the radius of bubble 2 is \(R _{2}\)

We know that the formula of pressure inside the soap bubble is given as:

\(\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\frac{\frac{4 T}{R_{1}}}{\frac{4 T}{R_{2}}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}=\frac{0.03}{0.01}=\frac{3}{1}\)

Now, the ratio of volume is:

\(\frac{\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R_{1}\right)^{3}}{\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R_{2}\right)^{3}}=\frac{\left(R_{1}\right)^{3}}{\left.R_{2}\right)^{3}}=\left(\frac{3}{1}\right)^{3}=\frac{27}{1}\)

So, the required ratio is 27 : 1.
Find the strain energy of the wire on applying a load of F, if the length of the wire is l, cross section area is A, and young modulus is Y.

The volume of material \(=\) Area \(\times V = Al\) \(E=\frac{1}{2} \times\) stress \(\times\) strain \(\times\) volume \(\quad \ldots\) (i)

We don't know strain here, so we will change strain into stress and \(Y\).

\(Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}\)

From the equation (1), we get, strain energy of the wire:

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \times\) stress \(\times \frac{\text { stress }}{Y} \times\) volume

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\text { stress }^{2}}{Y} \times\) volume

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\left(\frac{F}{A}\right)^{2}}{Y} \times A l\)

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \frac{F^{2}}{A Y} l\)
A water drop and a soap bubble have the same radii. If the surface tension of water is two times that of soap solution, the ratio of excess pressure inside the water drop and soap bubble is:

Let \(R_{1}, R_{2}\), and \(T_{1}, T_{2}\) be the radius and surface tension of water drop and soap bubble respectively.

Given that:

\(R _{1}= R _{2}\) and \(T _{1}=2 T _{2}\)

We know that:

Work done by excess pressure \(=\) force \(×\) displacement \(=\) pressure \(×\) surface area \(× dR = P × 4πR2 × dR \quad \ldots \) (1)

Energy (work done) \(= T \times\) area \(=2 T \times\) change in area \(=2 T \times\left(4 \pi\{ R + dR \}^{2}-4 \pi R ^{2}\right)=2 T (4 \pi(2 RdR ))\quad \ldots \) (2)

Equating (1) and (2),

\(P \times 4 \pi R ^{2} \times dR =2 T \times(4 \pi(2 RdR ))\)

Excess pressure, \(P=\frac{4 T}{R}\)

The ratio of excess pressure:

\(\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\frac{\frac{2 T_{1}}{R_{1}}}{\frac{4 T_{2}}{R_{2}}}=\frac{\frac{2\left(2 T_{2}\right)}{R}}{\frac{4 T_{2}}{R}}=\frac{1}{1}\)

When the temperature of black body increases, it is observed that the wavelength corresponding to maximum energy changes from \(0.26 \mu m\) to \(0.13 \mu m\). The ratio of the emissive powers of the body at the respective temperatures is:

From Wien's displacement law,

\(\lambda_{\max } \propto \frac{1}{ T }\)

Where, \(\lambda_{\max }=\) Maximum wavelength, \(T =\) Time

Let initial and final temperature \(T _{1}\) and \(T _{2}\), and corresponding powers \(P _{1}\) and \(P _{2}\) respectively.

From Stefan's law,

\(\frac{ P _{1}}{ P _{2}}=\left(\frac{ T _{1}}{ T _{2}}\right)^{4}\)

\(=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{4}=\frac{1}{16}\)

Consider two hot bodies \(A\) and \(B\) which have temperature \(120^{\circ} C\) and \(80^{\circ} C\) respectively at time \(t =0\) sec. The temperature of the surrounding is \(40^{\circ} C\). The ratio of the rate of cooling for the body \(A\) and the body \(B\) at \(t=0\) sec will be:

Given: \(t =0\) sec, \(T _{ tA }=120^{\circ}\) C, \(T _{ tB }=80^{\circ}\) C and \(T _{ s }=40^{\circ}\) C

Where, \(T _{ tA }\) is Temperature of body A , \(T _{ tB }\) is the temperature of body B and \(T _{ s }\) is the temperature of the surroundings.

According to Newton's law of cooling, the rate of cooling of a body is given as,

\(R \propto\left(T_{ t }- T _{ s }\right) \quad \ldots\) (1)

For body A: \(\left(T_{t A}=120^{\circ} C \right)\)

\(R _{ A } \propto\left(T_{ tA }- T _{ s }\right)\quad \ldots\) (2)

For body B: \(\left(T_{t B}= 80^{\circ} C \right)\)

\(R _{ B } \propto\left(T_{ tB }- T _{ s }\right)\quad \ldots\) (3)

By equation (2) and equation (3),

\(\frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{\left(T_{t A}-T_{s}\right)}{\left(T_{t B}-T_{s}\right)}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{\left(T_{t A}-T_{s}\right)}{\left(T_{t B}-T_{s}\right)}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{(120-40)}{(80-40)}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{2}{1}\)

A capacitor of capacitance \(2 \mu \mathrm{F}\) is charged to a potential difference of \(12 \mathrm{~V}\). It is then connected across an inductor of inductance \(0.6 \mathrm{mH}\). The current in the circuit when the potential difference across the capacitor is \(6 \mathrm{~V}\) is :

According to question,

Initial energy of capacitor \(\mathrm{E}_{1}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{CV}_{1}^{2}\)

Final energy of capacitor is \(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{f}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{CV}_{2}^{2}\)

Final energy of inductor \(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{L}}=\frac{1}{2 \mathrm{LI}^{2}}\)

The total energy in the given circuit remains conserved I.e.

\(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{CV}_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{CV}_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{LI}^{2}\)

\(\mathrm{C}\left(\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}-\mathrm{V}_{2}^{2}\right)=\mathrm{LI}^{2}\)

\(I=\sqrt{\frac{C\left(V_{1}^{2}-V_{2}^{2}\right)}{L}}\)

Given that,

\(\mathrm{C}=2 \mu \mathrm{F}=2 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~F}\)

\(\mathrm{~L}=0.6 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{H}\)

\(\mathrm{V}_{1}=12 \mathrm{~V}\)

\(\mathrm{~V}_{2}=6 \mathrm{~V}\)

Put all values in the expression of I

\(I=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 10^{-6}(144-36)}{0.6 \times 10^{-3}}}\)

\(I=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 10^{-3} \times 108}{0.6}}\)

\(\mathrm{I}=0.6 \mathrm{~A}\)

A conducting circular loop is placed in a uniform magnetic field, \(\mathrm{B}=0.025 \mathrm{~T}\) with its plane perpendicular to the loop. The radius of the loop is made to shrink at a constant rate of \(1 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{~s}{ }^{-1}\). The induced emf when the radius is \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\), is

Given: The magnetic field in the region is, \(B=0.025 \mathrm{~T}\).

Radius of the loop, \(\mathrm{r}=2 \mathrm{~cm}=2 \times 10^{-2}\)

Constant rate at which radius of the loop shrimks, \(\frac{\mathrm{dr}}{\mathrm{dt}}=1 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

To find: The induced emf in the loop when radius is \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\).

The magnetic flux linked with the loop is given by:

\(\phi=\mathrm{BA} \cos \theta\)

\(=\mathrm{B}\left(\pi r^{2}\right) \cos 0^{\circ}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{B} \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}\)

The magnitude of induced emf is given as:

\(|\epsilon|=\frac{d \phi}{d t}\)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{dt}}\left(\mathrm{B} \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}\right)\)

\(=\mathrm{B} \pi 2 \mathrm{r} \frac{\mathrm{dr}}{\mathrm{dt}}\)

Substitute the values.

\(|\epsilon|=0.025 \times \pi \times 2 \times 2 \times 10^{-2} \times 1 \times 10^{-3}\)

\(=\pi \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~V}\)

\(\Rightarrow \pi \mu \mathrm{V}\)

A conducting circular loop is placed in a uniform magnetic field of \(0.04 \mathrm{~T}\) with its plane perpendicular to the magnetic field. The radius of the loop starts shrinking at \(2 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{s}\). The induced emf in the loop when the radius is \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\) is:

Induced emf in the loop is given by

\(\mathrm{e}=-\mathrm{B} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{dA}}{\mathrm{dt}}\) where \(\mathrm{A}\) is the area of the loop.

\(e=-B \cdot \frac{d}{d t}\left(\pi r^{2}\right)=-B \pi 2 r \frac{d r}{d t}\)

\(r=2 \mathrm{~cm}=2 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\mathrm{dr}=2 \mathrm{~mm}=2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\mathrm{dt}=1 \mathrm{~s}\)

\(e=-0.04 \times 3.14 \times 2 \times 2 \times 10^{-2} \times \frac{2 \times 10^{-3}}{1} V\)

\(=0.32 \pi \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~V}\)

\(=3.2 \pi \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~V}\)

\(=3.2 \pi \mu \mathrm{V} .\)

A conducting square loop is placed in a magnetic field \(B\) with its plane perpendicular to the field. The sides of the loop start shrinking at a constant rate \(\alpha /\) The induced emf in the loop at an instant when its side is ' a' is:

At any time \(t\), the side of the square \(a=\left(a_{0}-\alpha t\right)\), where \(a_{0}=\) side at \(t=0\).

At this instant, flux through the square:

\(\phi=\mathrm{BA} \cos 0^{\circ}=\mathrm{B}\left(\mathrm{a}_{0}-\alpha \mathrm{t}\right)^{2}\)

\(\therefore\) emf induced \(\mathrm{E}=-\frac{\mathrm{d} \phi}{\mathrm{dt}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{E}=-\mathrm{B} \cdot 2\left(\mathrm{a}_{0}-\alpha \mathrm{t}\right)(0-\alpha)=+2 \alpha \mathrm{a} \beta\)

Efficiency of a transformer is defined as the ratio of output power to the input power. A transformer which decreases the AC voltage is called a step down transformer. Transformer is an essentially an AC device. It cannot work on DC. A transformer changes AC voltage/currents. Efficiency of transformer is given by

\(\eta=\frac{\text { output power }}{\text { input power }}=\frac{E_{s} I_{s}}{E_{p} I_{p}}\)

Here, \(P_{\text {output }}=8 \mathrm{~kW}, \eta=90 \%\)

\(\mathrm{P}_{\text {input }}=\frac{8 \times 100}{90}=\frac{80}{9} \mathrm{~kW}\)

\(=8.89 \mathrm{~kW}\)

\(\left[\mathrm{As} \mathrm{q}_{0}=\mathrm{CV}\right]\)

\(\mathrm{At} \mathrm{t}=\frac{\tau}{2}, \mathrm{q}=\mathrm{CV}\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-\tau / 2 \tau}=\mathrm{CV}\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{1 / 2}\right)\right.\)

To find: The maximum current in the inducting coil.

The charge stored in the capacitor is given by:

\(\mathrm{Q}_{0}=\mathrm{CV}\)

The maximum current flowing in the series LC circuit is:

\(\mathrm{I}_{\max }=\mathrm{Q}_{0} \mathrm{~W}\)

The frequency of a series LC circuit is given by:

\(\omega=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mathrm{LC}}}\)

Substitute the values in equation of maximum current.

\(\Rightarrow I_{\max }=(C V) \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mathrm{LC}}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{C}}{\mathrm{L}} \mathrm{V}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{I}_{\max }=\sqrt{\frac{1.5 \times 10^{-6}}{15 \times 10^{-3}}} \times 60=0.6 \mathrm{~A}\)
Which of the following is not a unit of Young's modulus?

Young's modulus \(\quad \mathrm{Y}=\frac{\text { Stress }}{\text { Strain }}\)

As we know, strain is a dimensionless quantity whereas stress is defined as force per unit area.

Stress has units as \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\) (SI unit), Dyne \(\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\) (cgs unit) or Pascal ( \(\mathrm{Pa}\)).

As Young's modulus has same unit as that of stress, thus \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\) is not a unit of Young's modulus.
Which of the following is the most elastic?

Steel is the most elastic material.

If the object is elastic, the body regains its original shape when the pressure is removed.

Steel having the steepest linear stress-strain curve among all.

A stiffer material will have a higher elastic modulus.

\(1=\frac{\mathrm{FL}}{\mathrm{AY}}=\frac{\mathrm{FL}^{2}}{(\mathrm{AL}) \mathrm{Y}}=\frac{\mathrm{FL}^{2}}{\mathrm{VY}}\)

\(\therefore 1 \alpha \mathrm{L}^{2}\) if volume of the wire remains constant

\(\frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}_{2}}{\mathrm{~L}_{1}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{8}{2}\right)^{2}=16\)

\(\therefore 1_{2}=16 \times 1_{1}=16 \times 2=32 \mathrm{~mm}=3.2 \mathrm{~cm}\)

If in a stationary lift, a man is standing with a bucket full of water, having a hole at its bottom. The rate of flow of water through this hole is \(R_{o}\). If the lift starts to move up and down with same acceleration and then that rates of flow of water are \(R_{u}\) and, \(R_{d}\), then:

Rate of flow will be more when elevator will move in upward direction with some acceleration because the net downward pull will be more and vice-versa. 

\(F_{\text {upward }}\left(R_{u}\right)=\mathrm{m}(g+\mathrm{a}) \)

\(F_{\text {downward }}\left(R_{d}\right)=\mathrm{m}(\mathrm{g}+\mathrm{a}) \Rightarrow F_{\text {at rest }}\left(R_{o}\right)=m g\)

Thus, relation between \(R_{u} . R_{o}\) and \(R_{d}\) is \(R_{u}>R_{o}>R_{d}\)
In streamline flow of a liquid, the total energy of the liquid is constant at:

Bernoulli's theorem : The total mechanical energy of the flowing fluid, comprising of the energy associated with fluid pressure, the gravitational potential energy and the kinetic energy for the fluid motion remains constant.  

Bernoulli’s theorem is the principle of energy conservation for ideal fluids in streamline flow.

Mathematical reference : 

\(P_{1}+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_{1}^{2}+\rho g h_{1}=P_{2}+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_{2}^{2}+\rho g h_{2}\)

\(\rho\)= density of the fluid

\(g\)= acceleration due to gravity

\(P_{1}\)= Pressure At height 1

\(v_{1}\)= velocity at elevation 1

\(h_{1}\)= height of elevation 1

\(P_{2}\)= Pressure at elevation 2

\(v_{2}\)= velocity at elevation 2

\(h_{2}\)= height of elevation 2
A spinner swings a cricket ball due to:

A spinner swings a cricket ball due to Magnus effect.

It is usually experienced by cricketers and tennis players, whenever a ball is thrown by spinning it moves in a curved path instead of moving in a straight line which is called a swing of the ball.

In this process, the velocity of air above the ball decreases and down the ball increases.

Therefore according to Bernoulli's theorem, pressure above the ball increases and down the ball decreases, due to this effect ball moves in a curved path instead of the straight line. This effect is called the Magnus effect.

The force, if T is surface tension (for per unit length) will be 8LT.

If a liquid does not wet glass, this means liquid-liquid interaction is more than liquid-solid interaction leading us to obtuse angle of contact.
