Let r be radius of common drop

\(\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}=2 \times \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\)

\(r=2^{1 / 3} R\)

surface tension of 2 drops \(2 \times 4 \pi R^{2} \mathrm{~T}\)

surface tension of common drop \(4 \pi \mathrm{r}^{2} \mathrm{~T}\)

ratio \(\frac{2 \times 4 \pi R^{2} T}{4 \pi r^{2} T}=\frac{2 R^{2}}{2^{2 / 3} R^{2}}=\frac{2^{1 / 3}}{1}\)
In which mode of transmission do heat waves travel along a straight line with the speed of light?

The energy emitted by a body, in the form of radiation on account of its temperature, is called thermal radiation. These radiations are heat radiations and travel along straight lines with the speed of light.
The thermal conductivity of a rod is 2. What is its thermal resistivity?

Direction: In the following question, a statement of assertion is given, followed by a corresponding statement of reason just below it. Mark the correct answer as:

Assertion: It is hotter over the top of fire than at the same distance on the sides.

Reason: Air surrounding the fire conducts more heat upwards.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion.
Assertion is correct but Reason is incorrect.

Heat is carried away from a fire sideways mainly by radiation. Above the fire, heat is carried by both radiations and also by the convection of air. The latter process carries much more heat. So the assertion is correct but the reason is incorrect.
The work done in which of the following processes is zero?

An isochoric process is one in which the volume is held constant, meaning that the work done by the system will be zero. It follows that, for the simple system of two dimensions, any heat energy transferred to the system externally will be absorbed as internal energy.

One end of a copper rod of length \(1 \mathrm{~m}\) and area of cross - section \(400 \times\left(10^{-4}\right) m^{2}\) is maintained at \(100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). At the other end of the rod ice is kept at \(0^{\circ} C\). Neglecting the loss of heat from the surrounding, find the mass of ice melted in \(1 \mathrm{~h}\). Given,

\(K_{C u}=401 W / m-K \text { and } L_{f}=3.35 \times\left(10^{5}\right) \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg} \).

Thermal resistance of the rod

\(R=\frac{l}{K A}=\frac{1.0}{(401)\left(4 \times\left(10^{-4}\right)\right)}=6.23 K / W\)

\(\therefore\) Heat current, \(H=\frac{\text { Temperature difference }}{\text { Thermal resistance }}\)

\(=\left(\frac{100-0}{6.23}\right)=16 W\)

Heat transferred in \(1 \mathrm{~h}\)

\(Q=H t\left\langle. H=\frac{Q}{t}\right)\)

\(=(16)(3600)=57600 J\)

Now, let m mass of ice melts in 1 h, then,

\(m=\frac{Q}{L}\)

\(=\frac{57600}{3.35 \times\left(10^{5}\right)}\)

\(=0.172\)

or \(=172 g\)
If the temperature difference on the two sides of a wall increases from \(100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), its thermal conductivity:

The coefficient of thermal conductivity of a material is the amount of heat flowing in \(1 s\) through a rod of that material of \(1 m\) length and \(1 m^{2}\) area of cross-section in the steady state; when the difference of temperatures between the two ends of the rod is \(1^{\circ} C\) and the flow of heat is normal to the end faces of the rod. Coefficient of thermal conductivity \(K\) is a constant, whose value depends upon the material of the rod. Hence, even if temperature increases or decreases, its thermal conductivity remains unchanged.
In an isochoric process, the increase in internal energy is:
Equal to the sum of the heat absorbed and work done

In an isochoric process, \(\Delta \mathrm{V}=0\), hence, work done \(\mathrm{P}\) \(\Delta V=W=0\). So, \(\Delta E=q+0\). Hence, the increase in internal energy will be equal to heat absorbed by the system.
A beaker is completely filled with water at \(4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) It will overflow if:

Volume of water is minimum at \(4 C\). It will overflow if both heated and cooled above and below \(4^{0} C\) respectively.

Water has maximum density at \(4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), so if the water is heated above \(4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) or cooled below \(4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) density decreases i.e., volume increases. In other words, it expands so it overflows in both the cases.

A wire of length L and area of cross-section A is stretched through a distance x metre by applying a force F along length, then the work done in this process is : (Y is Young's modulus of the material)

Work done \(=\frac{1}{2} \times\) stress \(\times\) strain \(\times\) volume

or \(W=\frac{1}{2} Y \frac{x}{L} \times \frac{x}{L} \times A L\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}(A L)\left(Y \frac{x}{L}\right)\left(\frac{x}{L}\right)\)
When a long spring is stretched by 2 cm, its potential energy is U. If the spring is stretched by 10 cm, its potential energy will be (in term of U):

The potential energy of a stretched spring is

\(\mathrm{U}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{kx}^{2}\)

Here, \(\mathrm{k}=\) spring constant,

\(\mathrm{x}=\) elongation in spring.

But given that, the elongation is \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\).

So, \(U=\frac{1}{2} k(2)^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{U}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k} \times 4\)

If elongation is \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\) then potential energy

\(U^{\prime} =\frac{1}{2} k(10)^{2} \)

\(U^{\prime} =\frac{1}{2} k \times 100 \quad \ldots \ldots \text { (ii) }\)

On dividing equation (ii) by equation (i), we have

\(\frac{U^{\prime}}{\mathrm{U}}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k} \times 100}{\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k} \times 4} \)

\(\text { or } \frac{\mathrm{U}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{U}}=25 \Rightarrow \mathrm{U}^{\prime}=25 \mathrm{U}\)

Heat is the motion of particles that creates a form of energy known as heat or thermal energy.

Heat is a type of energy transfer in which energy flows from a warmer substance or object to a colder one. It can be defined as the total amount of transferred energy excluding any macroscopic work that was done and any transfer of part of the object itself. Transfer of energy as heat can occur through direct contact, through a barrier that is impermeable to matter (as in conduction), by radiation between separated bodies, by way of an intermediate fluid (as in convective circulation), or by a combination of these. By contrast to work, heat involves the stochastic (random) motion of particles (such as atoms or molecules) that is equally distributed among all degrees of freedom, while work is confined to one or more specific degrees of freedom such as those of the center of mass.
Heat flows from one body to other when they have:

Heat flows from one body to other when they have Different temperature.

The heat will flow from the high-temperature region to the low-temperature region until the temperature distribution is the same throughout the body. Or, there may be a temperature gradient across an object. The heat will flow so as to equalize the temperature throughout the object.
State the temperature of ice point and steam point on the Fahrenheit scale :

Ice point:

The temperature at which ice and water are in equilibrium or the temperature at which water turns into ice. Temperature of ice point is \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

Now we have relation between Celsius scale and Fahrenheit scale,

\(\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{C}}-0}{100}=\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{F}}-32}{180} \text {, }\)

given \(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{C}}=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

hence, \(\frac{0-0}{100}=\frac{T_{F}-32}{180}\),

or \(\quad \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{F}}=32^{\circ} \mathrm{F}\)

Steam point:

The temperature at which maximum vapour pressure equals the one atmospheric pressure or the temperature at which water starts boiling . Temperature of steam point is \(100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\),

given \(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{C}}=100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\),

hence, \(\frac{100-0}{100}=\frac{T_{\mathrm{F}}-32}{180}\),

or \(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{F}}=212^{\circ} \mathrm{F}\)
Copper expands about _____ times more than glass for the same rise in the temperature.

Copper expands about five times more than glass for the same rise in the temperature.

In response to a change in temperature, by heat transfer, thermal expansion is the tendency of matter to change in volume. This property is determined by the coefficient of thermal linear expansion, defined as the fractional change in the length of a specific material for each degree of change in temperature.

Copper \(\left(\right.\) at \(\left.20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)-17 \times 10^{-6} / \mathrm{K}\)

Glass (at  \(\left.20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)-3.3 \times 10^{-6} / \mathrm{K}\)

Hence, the correct option is (C).
Show that volume expansion coefficient is three times the linear expansion coefficient for a solid.

Solution:

Let the initial dimensions of the cuboid be \(1_{1}, 1_{2}\) and \(1_{3}\).

Initial volume \(\mathrm{V}=1_{1} 1_{2} 1_{3}\)

Final dimensions are,

\(1_{1}^{\prime}=1_{1}(1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T}) \quad \mathrm{1}_{2}^{\prime}=1_{2}(1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T}) \quad 1_{3}^{\prime}=1_{3}(1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T})\)

Final volume \(\mathrm{V}^{\prime}=1_{1}^{\prime} 1_{2}^{\prime} 1_{3}^{\prime}\)

Or \(\mathrm{V}^{\prime}=1_{1}(1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T}) \mathrm{l}_{2}(1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T}) \mathrm{l}_{3}(1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T})\)

\(\mathrm{V}^{\prime}=\mathrm{V}(1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T})^{3}\)

Since \(\alpha\) is very small, so \((1+\alpha \Delta \mathrm{T})^{3} \approx 1+3 \alpha \Delta \mathrm{T}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}^{\prime}=\mathrm{V}(1+3 \alpha \Delta \mathrm{T})=\mathrm{V}(1+\gamma \Delta \mathrm{T}) \)

\(\Rightarrow \gamma=3 \alpha\)

When a force \(\mathrm{F}\) acts on a body of mass \(\mathrm{m}\),the acceleration produced in the body is a if three equal forces \(F_{1}=F_{2}=F_{3}=F\) act on the same body as shown in figure. The acceleration produced is:

\(\mathrm{F}_{12}\) is opposite to the direction ofF \(\mathrm{F}_{3}\)

Physical independence of force is consequence of:

It states that “Everybody continues its state of rest or state of uniform motion unless and until external unbalanced force acts on it.”

So when a body is at rest or is moving with uniform velocity net force acting on it is zero. When an unbalanced force acts on it, the body moves in the direction of force. Thus the effect of this unbalanced force is not influenced by the presence of other forces. This implies that forces act independently of each other and they have no influence on others.

 In order to calculate net effect we do vector addition of all forces because each force has its own direction.

A body \(\mathrm{X}\) of mass \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving with velocity \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) while another body \(\mathrm{Y}\) of mass \(20 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving with velocity \(5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). Compare the momentum of the two bodies.

For body X,

mass: \(m_{\mathrm{X}}=5 \mathrm{~kg}\)

velocity: \(v_{\mathrm{X}}=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\therefore\) momentum: \(\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{X}}=\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{X}} \times \mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{X}}=5 \times 20=100 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

For body Y,

mass: \(m_{\mathrm{Y}}=20 \mathrm{~kg}\)

velocity: \(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{Y}}=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\therefore\) momentum: \(\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{Y}}=\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{Y}} \times \mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{Y}}=20 \times 5=100 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

So, \(\mathrm{pX}_{\mathrm{X}}: \mathrm{py}_{\mathrm{Y}}=1: 1\)

A lift is moving downwards with an acceleration equal to the acceleration due to gravity. A body of mass M kept on the floor of the lift is pulled horizontally. If the coefficient of friction is μ, then the friction resistance offered by the body is:

Frictional force is directly proportional to the normal contact force between the bodies under consideration in the given question. A cyclist starts from the centre O of a circular park of radius 1 km, reaches the edge P of the park, then cycles along the circumference and returns to the centre along QO as shown in the figure. If the round trip takes ten minutes, the net displacement and average speed of the cyclist (in metre and kilometre per hour) is

\(=\frac{\mathrm{OP}+\mathrm{PQ}+\mathrm{QO}}{10} \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~min}-1\)

\(=\frac{\pi+4}{20} \times 60 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}=21.4 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}\)

So, \(\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{12} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(=\frac{\pi}{21600} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}\)

The Centripetal Force Formula is given as the product of mass (in kg) and tangential velocity (in meters per second) squared, divided by the radius (in meters) that implies that on doubling the tangential velocity, the centripetal force will be quadrupled. Mathematically it is written as:

\(F=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}\)

Where, \(F\) is the Centripetal force, \(m\) is the mass of the object, \(v\) is the speed or velocity of the object and \(r\) is the radius.
A particle revolves round a circular path with a uniform speed. The centripetal acceleration of the particle is:

The acceleration due to the particle moves in a circular path is of two types-tangential acceleration and centripetal acceleration. In the case of tangential acceleration, the velocity of a particle changes, and for uniform velocity, the value for tangential acceleration becomes zero.
For a body moving with constant speed in a horizontal circle, which of the following remains constant?

When a body moves at a constant speed in a horizontal circle, its Kinetic energy remains constant.

When the body rotates in a horizontal circle then, only the direction of velocity, acceleration & force changes continuously at every instant but not in terms of their magnitude. its kinetic energy remains constant as mass and speed remain constant.
When a bus starts suddenly, the passengers are pushed back. This is an example of which of the following?

When a bus suddenly starts moving, the passengers fall backward due to the law of inertia of rest or 1st law of Newton.

Because the body was in the state of rest and when the bus suddenly starts moving the lower body tends to be in motion, but the upper body still remains in a state of rest due to which it feels a jerk and falls backward. Hence option 1 is correct.
A ball balanced on a vertical rod is an example of:

A ball balanced on a vertical rod is an example of unstable equilibrium. A system is in unstable equilibrium if, when displaced from equilibrium, it experiences a net force or torque in the same direction as the displacement from equilibrium.

If a ball is placed on vertical rod, it is in unstable equilibrium because once it is displaced from its place, it will experience the net force in the direction of displacement and never come back to its original position. The potential energy of the ball is maximum at this point.

Due to an acceleration of \(2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\), the velocity of a body increases from \(20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) to 30 \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\) in a certain period. Find the displacement (in \(\mathrm{m}\) ) of the body in that period.

Given \(-\) Acceleration \((a)=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\), Final velocity \((\mathrm{v})=30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and Initial velocity \((\mathrm{u})=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Displacement \(=\mathrm{s}\)

We know,

\(\Rightarrow v^{2}-u^{2}=2 a s\) (Equation of Motion)

\(\Rightarrow s=(\frac{v^{2}-u^{2}}{2 \times a})\)

\(\Rightarrow s=(\frac{30^{2}-20^{2}}{(2 \times 2)})\)

\(\Rightarrow s=\frac{500}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow s=125 \mathrm{~m}\)

The force required to accelerate a body of mass " \(\mathrm{m}\) " with acceleration "a" is given by:

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=\mathrm{ma}\)

\(\Rightarrow 90=\mathrm{m} \times 2.6\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}=\frac{90}{2.6}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}=34.6 \mathrm{~kg}\)

According to Newton’s first law of motion, an object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.

The heavier the object is harder to move it or the greater the amount of force required to move it hence higher the inertia.

Since higher mass has higher inertia. In all the above 4 options, a cricket ball has maximum mass so it will have maximum inertia.

Given \(-\mathrm{u}=18 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \mathrm{v}=36 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and \(\mathrm{t}=5 \mathrm{~s}\)

- As acceleration is written as

- \(\Rightarrow a=\frac{v_{2}-v_{1}}{t_{2}-t_{1}}\)

- \(\Rightarrow a=\frac{10-5}{5}=1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)
Newton’s first law is also known as _______.

Newton’s first law is also known as the law of inertia. It states that ‘an object will continue to stay at rest and an object in motion will remain in motion in the same direction and speed unless an unbalanced force acts upon it’.

Newton’s second law of motion states that ‘for a constant mass, force is equal to the product of mass and acceleration. Force is also equal to the change in momentum per change in time.

Newton’s third law of motion states that ‘for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

Work done upon a body is only a scalar quantity. scalar quantities are the measurements that strictly refer to the magnitude of the medium. there are absolutely no directional components in a scalar quantity only the magnitude of the medium. For example, length, speed, work, mass, density, etc.

The formula for the velocity of electromagnetic waves in vacuum is given by:

Maxwell deduced that the speed of propagation of an electromagnetic wave through a vacuum is entirely determined by the constants \(\mu_{0}\) and \(\epsilon_{0}\) as the following:

\(c=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} E_{0}}}\)

We know that \(\mu_{0}=4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~s}^{2} \mathrm{C}^{-2}\) and \(\epsilon_{0}=8.854 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{C}^{2} \mathrm{~N}^{-1} \mathrm{~m}^{-2}\) which gives:

\(\mathrm{c}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi \times 10^{-7} 8.854 \times 10^{-12}}}=2.998 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).

In electromagnetism, displacement current is a quantity appearing in Maxwell's equations that is defined in terms of the rate of change of electric displacement field. It is mathematically represented as \(I_{d}=\epsilon_{0} \frac{d \phi_{E}}{d t}\).
If \(\mathrm{c}\) is the speed of electromagnetic waves in vacuum, its speed in a medium of dielectric constant \(k\) and relative permeability \(\mu_{\mathrm{r}}\) is:

Speed of light of vacuum \(c=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}} \ldots . .(1)\)

And in another medium \(\mathrm{v}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu \mathrm{v}}} \ldots(2)\)

\(\mu \mathrm{r}=\frac{\mu}{\mu_{0}}, \epsilon_{\mathrm{r}}=\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_{0}}=\mathrm{k}\)

Dividing by equation (1)&(2)

\(\frac{\mathrm{c}}{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{\sqrt{\mu \epsilon}}{\sqrt{\epsilon_{0} \mu_{0}}}\)

\(=\sqrt{\left(\frac{\mu}{\mu_{0}}\right) \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_{0}}}=\sqrt{\mu_{\mathrm{r}} \mathrm{k}}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{c}}{\mathrm{v}}=\sqrt{\mu_{\mathrm{r}} \mathrm{k}}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{c}}{\sqrt{\mu_{\mathrm{r}} \mathrm{k}}}\)

Average energy density of magnetic field, \(u_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{\mathrm{B}_{0}^{2}}{2 \mu_{0}}, \mathrm{~B}_{0}\) is maximum value of magnetic field.

Average energy density of electric field,

\(\mathrm{u}_{\mathrm{E}}=\frac{\varepsilon_{0} \epsilon_{0}^{2}}{2}\)

now, \(\epsilon_{0}=C_{0}, C^{2}=\frac{1}{\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0}}\)

time-varying magnetic field vanishes in electric field
only time-varying magnetic field acts as a source of electric field
time-varying magnetic field acts as a source of electric field and time-varying electric field acts as a source of magnetic field
time-varying magnetic field produce as a static electric field

A time varying magnetic field is a source of changing electric field. And a time varying electric field is a source of changing magnetic field. Maxwell’s displacement current is a response to

Maxwell showed that Ampere's circuital law is logically inconsistent. He considered a parallel plate capacitor being charged be a battery. He showed inconsistency of the law in the regions outside the plates of capacitor and just between the plates. To resolve this inconsistency displacement current was introduced by Maxwell.

Which of these mechanisms can be used to produce electromagnetic waves?
point charge travelling in a straight line with constant velocity
point charge oscillating in simple harmonic motion

This charge produces an oscillating electric field in its neighbourhood. This field in turn, produces an oscillating magnetic field in its neighbourhood. The process continues as both the fields acts as source of each other. Hence an em wave originates from the oscillating charge.
Note: The frequency of em wave is equal to frequency of oscillating charge.
Since both electric and magnetic fields oscillates perpendicular to direction of propagation of em-wave, it is transverse in nature.

Kilo-watt hour is a unit of energy used to denote the energy consumption of large machinery and the electricity consumption in homes and industries. It is also a common unit representation in electrical power engineering.

\(1 \mathrm{KWh}=(1000 W) \times(3600 s)=3.6 \times 10^{6}\) Joules

So, one \(1 \mathrm{KWh}\) contains \(3.6 \times 10^{6}\) Joules.
Which of the following is the smallest unit of distance?

1 millimeter \(=10^{-3}\) meter

1 angstrom \(=10^{-10}\) meter

Also, the nucleus has the diameter of \(10^{-13}\) centi - meter. This unit is mostly used by Atomic physicists.

The unit Fermi was derived by Enrico Fermi and it is used to deal with subatomic particles. Particles that are even smaller than the nucleus like protons and neutrons also (known as nucleons) have this unit. This unit is mostly used by Particle physicists.

What is the SI unit of pressure?

Pressure is defined as the force applied per unit area on an object. The force applied is perpendicular to the surface area of the object. The symbol for it is \(p\).

Mathematically, the formula for pressure can be written as

\(p=\frac{F}{A}\)

Where \(p\) is the pressure, \(F\) is the perpendicular force exerted on the surface area \(A\) of an object.

The SI unit of pressure is Pascal which is usually represented as \(P a\) or Newton per square metre \(N / m^{2}\) where \(N\) the SI unit of force and \(m^{2}\) is the SI unit of area.

The density of a cube is found by measuring its mass and the length of its side. If the maximum errors in the measurement of mass and length are \(0.3 \%\) and \(0.2 \%\) respectively, the maximum error in the measurement of density is:

Given that,

Mass error \(\mathrm{m} \%=0.3 \%\)

Length error \(1 \%=0.2 \%\)

We know that,

Density \(=\) \(\frac{mass}{volume}\)

\(\rho=\frac{M}{V}\)

\(\rho=\frac{M}{1^{3}}\)

Now, the percentage error is

\(\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho} \times 100=\left[\frac{\Delta \mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{m}} \times 100\right]+3\left[\frac{\Delta \mathrm{l}}{\mathrm{l}} \times 100\right]\)

\(\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho} \times 100=0.3 \%+(3 \times 0.2) \%\)

\(\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho} \times 100=0.3 \%+0.6 \%\)

\(\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho} \times 100=0.9 \%\)

Hence, the maximum error in the measurement of density is \(0.9 \%\)

If the error in the measurement of radius of a sphere is 1%, what will be the error in the measurement of its volume?

Volume \(=\frac{4 \pi \mathrm{R}^{3}}{3}\)

\(\frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}} \times 100=3 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{R}}{\mathrm{R}} \times 100\)

\(=3 \times \frac{1}{100} \times 100\)

= 3

In a vernier calliper, one main scale division is \(\mathrm{x} \mathrm{cm}\) and \(\mathrm{n}\) divisions of the vernier scale coincide with \((\mathrm{n}-1)\) division of the main scale. The least count (in \(\mathrm{cm}\) ) of the callipers is:

\(\mathrm{IMSD}=\mathrm{x} \mathrm{cm}\)

\((n) V \cdot s \cdot D=(n-1) M S D\)

\(1 \mathrm{VSD}=\frac{\mathrm{n}-1}{\mathrm{n}}MSD\)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{n}-1}{\mathrm{n}} \mathrm{x} \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{L} \cdot \mathrm{C}=1 \mathrm{MSD}-1 \mathrm{VSD}\)

\(=\mathrm{x}-\left(\frac{\mathrm{n}-1}{\mathrm{n}}\right) \mathrm{x}\)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{nx}-(\mathrm{n}-1) \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{n}}\)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{n}} \mathrm{cm}\)

The femtometre symbol derived from the Danish and Norwegian word femten 'fifteen', is an SI unit of length equal to 10−15 metres, which means a quadrillionth of one metre. This distance is sometimes called a fermi and was so named in honour of Italian-American physicist Enrico Fermi, as it is a typical length-scale of nuclear physics.
If energy (E), velocity (v) and force (F) are taken as fundamental quantities, what are the dimensions of mass?

\({[\mathrm{E}]=\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2} }\)

\({[\mathrm{v}]=\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-1} }\)

\({[\mathrm{~F}]=\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2} }\)

Let dimension of mass in \(\mathrm{E}\) is \(=\mathrm{x}\)

Let dimension of mass in \(\mathrm{V}\) is \(=\mathrm{y}\)

Let dimension of mass in \(\mathrm{F}\) is \(=\mathrm{z}\)

Then, \(M=\mathrm{E}^{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{V}^{\mathrm{y} \mathrm{F}^{\mathrm{z}}}\)

\(\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}=\left[\mathrm{ML}^{2} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{x}}\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]^{\mathrm{y}}\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{z}}\)

\(\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}=\mathrm{M}^{\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{z}} \mathrm{L}^{2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}+\mathrm{z}} \mathrm{T}^{-2 \mathrm{x}-\mathrm{y}-2 \mathrm{z}}\)

\(x+z=1 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots(\) i)

\(2 x+y+z=0 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots(\) ii \()\)

\(2 x+y+2 z=0 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots(\) iii)

By equation (i), (ii) & (iii)

\(x=1\)

\(y=-2\)

\(z=0\)

So, \([\mathrm{M}]=\mathrm{E}^{1} \mathrm{~V}^{-2}\)

If the screw on a screw-guage is given six rotations, it moves by 3mm on the main scale. If there are 50 divisions on the circular scale the least count of the screw gauge is?

If the zero \({ }^{\text {th }}\) division of head scale is above the index line of pitch scale, then error is said to be:

First, take the screw gauge and move it in decreasing order along the index line until it gets tight. At that point, if there is an error in the Screw gauge, we can find there because if there is any error the zero on the head (rotating ) scale does not coincide with the index line when the head scale edge is sharply at the zero of the pitch scale. If the zero of the head scale is above the index line then the error is negative, if the zero is below the index line then the error is positive.
Which of the following time measuring devices is most precise?

Option (B) is correct because a clock can measure time correctly up to one second. A stopwatch can measure time correctly up to a fraction of a second. A digital watch can measure time up to a fraction of second whereas an atomic clock is the most accurate timekeeper and is based on characteristic frequencies of radiation emitted by certain atoms having a precision of about 1 second in 300,000 years. So an atomic clock can measure time most precisely as the precision of this clock is about \(1 \mathrm{~s}\) in \(10^{13} \mathrm{~s}\).

The length, breadth and thickness of a block are given by \(1=12 \mathrm{~cm}, \mathrm{~b}=6 \mathrm{~cm}\) and \(\mathrm{t}=\) \(2.45 \mathrm{~cm}\). The volume of the block according to the idea of significant figures should be:

Step1: Volume calculation

Volume of the block, 

\(\mathrm{V}=1 \times \mathrm{b} \times \mathrm{t}\)

\(=12 \times 6 \times 2.45 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

\(=1.764 \times 10^{2} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

Step2: Rounding off the volume according to significant figures

For multiplication, the least number of significant figures in any number of the problem determines the number of significant figures in the answer.

Since the minimum number of the significant figures is 1 in width (6cm), therefore the volume will also contain only 1 significant figure. 

Therefore, rounding off the volume \(\left(1.764 \times 10^{2} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\right)\) to 1 significant figure, we get

\(\mathrm{V}=2 \times 10^{2} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

If voltage is ' \(\mathrm{V} '=(100 \pm 5)\) volts and current is 'I' \(=(10 \pm 0.2)\) amperes, then the percentage error in measuring the resistance ' \(R\) ' is:

Resistance is the ratio of voltage used and the current flowing through the circuit

\(R = \frac{V}{I}\)

By error calculation (division formula)

\((\frac{\Delta R}{R})=[(\frac{\Delta V)}{V}] \times 100+[(\frac{\Delta l)}{I}] \times 100\)

\(=(\frac{5}{100}) \times 100+(\frac{0.2}{10}) \times 100\)

= 5 + 2

= 7%
A rectangular plate has length \(=(5 \pm 0.1) \mathrm{cm}\) and breadth \(=(2 \pm 0.01) \mathrm{cm}\). The area of the plate is:

The area is given as 

A = l × b

Given length l = 5, error Δ l = 0.1

Breadth b = 2,  error Δ b = 0.01

Area on the measured value 

The error expression of this relation is given as:

\(\frac{\Delta A}{A}=\frac{\Delta l}{l}+\frac{\Delta b}{b}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta A}{10}=\frac{0.1}{5}+\frac{0.01}{2}=0.025\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta A=0.25\)

So, the error in measurement of the area is 0.25

A physical quantity A is related to four observable \(a, b, c\) and \(d\) as follows, \(A=\frac{a^{2} b^{3}}{c \sqrt{d}}\), the percentage errors of measurement in a, b, c and \(d\) are \(1 \%, 3 \%, 2 \%\) and \(2 \%\) respectively. What is the percentage error in the quantity A?

The given physical quantity \(\mathrm{A}=\frac{\mathrm{a}^{2} \mathrm{~b}^{3}}{\mathrm{c} \sqrt{\mathrm{d}}}\)

Given : \(\frac{\Delta \mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{a}} \times 100=1 \%, \frac{\Delta \mathrm{b}}{\mathrm{b}} \times 100=3 \%, \frac{\Delta \mathrm{c}}{\mathrm{c}} \times 100=2 \%\) and \(\frac{\Delta \mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}} \times 100=2 \%\)

Percentage error in \(\mathrm{A}, \frac{\Delta \mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{A}} \times 100=2 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{a}} \times 100+3 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{b}}{\mathrm{b}} \times 100+\frac{\Delta \mathrm{c}}{\mathrm{c}} \times 100+\frac{1}{2} \times\) \(\frac{\Delta d}{d} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta \mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{A}} \times 100=2 \times 1+3 \times 3+2+\frac{1}{2} \times 2=14 \%\)

The combined form of first and second laws of thermodynamics is given by ( \(P=\)

Pressure, \({V}=\) Volume, \({T}=\) Temperature, \({U}=\) Internal energy, \({S}=\) Entropy, \({Q}={Quantity}\) of heat):

According to first law of thermodynamics:

\(\mathrm{dQ}=\mathrm{dU}+\mathrm{pdV} \ldots(1)\)

According to second law of thermodynamics

\(d S=\frac{d Q}{T} \quad \ldots(2)\)

Combined form of \((1)\) and (2)

\(T d S=d U+p d V\)
\(3000 \mathrm{~J}\) of heat is added to a system and \(2500 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done by the system. What is the change in internal energy of the system?

Given:

\(3000 \mathrm{~J}\) of heat is added to a system and \(2500 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done by the system.

Applying 1 st Law of Thermodynamics:

\(\Delta Q=\Delta U+W\)

Since heat was added to system, it sign will be positive.

Also, since work was done by system, its sign will be positive.

\( 3000=\Delta U+2500 \)

\( \Delta U=3000-2500 \)

\( \Delta U=500 \text { joule }\)

An ideal gas heat engine operates in Carnot's cycle between \(227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) It absorbs \(6 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~J}\) at high temperature. The amount of heat converted into work is:

Given:

\(\mathrm{T}_{1}=227+273=500 \mathrm{~K}, \mathrm{~T}_{2}=127+273=400 \mathrm{~K}\),

Heat absorbed by the engine is \(\mathrm{Q}_{1}=6 \times\) \(10^{4} J\)

The efficiency of the heat engine is given by:

\(\Rightarrow \eta=\frac{W}{Q_{1}}=1-\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^{4}}=1-\frac{400}{500} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^{4}}=1-\frac{4}{5} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^{4}}=\frac{1}{5} \)

\(\Rightarrow W=\frac{6 \times 10^{4}}{5}\)

\(=1.2 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~J}\)

An ideal gas is expanded isothermally from a volume \(V_{1}\) to volume \(V_{2}\) and then, compressed adiabatically to original volume \(V_{1}\). The initial pressure is \(P_{1}\) and the final pressure is \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\). If the net work done is \(\mathrm{W}\), then:

Let the thermodynamic coordinates of various states be:

Initial state \(\left(\mathrm{P}_{1}, \mathrm{~V}_{1}, \mathrm{~T}_{1}\right)\)

State after first process \(\left(\mathrm{P}_{2}, \mathrm{~V}_{2}, \mathrm{~T}_{2}\right)\)

Final state \(\left(\mathrm{P}_{3}, \mathrm{~V}_{3}, \mathrm{~T}_{3}\right)\)

First process being isothermal, \(\mathrm{P}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{~V}_{1}}{\mathrm{~V}_{2}}\)

\(T_{2}=T_{1}\)

Next one being adiabatic, \(\mathrm{P}_{2} \mathrm{~V}_{2}^{\gamma}=\mathrm{P}_{3} \mathrm{~V}_{3}^{\gamma}\)

Here \(\mathrm{V}_{3}=\mathrm{V}_{1}\)

So \(P_{3}=\frac{P_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma}}{V_{1}^{\gamma}}\)

Replacing \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) from above, \(\mathrm{P}_{3}=\mathrm{P}_{1} \frac{\mathrm{V}_{2}^{\gamma-1}}{\mathrm{~V}_{1}^{\gamma-1}}\)

We know that \(\gamma>1 \Rightarrow \gamma-1>0\)

given \(\mathrm{V}_{2}>\mathrm{V}_{1} \Rightarrow\left(\frac{\mathrm{V}_{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_{1}}\right)^{\gamma-1}>1\)

Hence \(\mathrm{P}_{3}>\mathrm{P}_{1}\)

Work done in first process \(=P_{1} V_{1} \ln \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}=\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{\gamma-1} \ln \left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)^{\gamma-1}<P_{1} V_{1} \frac{\left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)^{\gamma-1}-1}{\gamma-1}\)

and in second process work \(=\frac{\mathrm{P}_{2} \mathrm{~V}_{2}-\mathrm{P}_{3} \mathrm{~V}_{1}}{\gamma-1}=\mathrm{P}_{1} \mathrm{~V}_{1} \frac{1-\left(\frac{\mathrm{V}_{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_{1}}\right)^{\gamma-1}}{\gamma-1}\)

So, net work \(=\mathrm{W}<0\)

Thus we get

\(\mathrm{nC} \Delta \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{n}\left(\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{R}\right) \mathrm{T}_{1}+\mathrm{n}\left(\frac{7}{2} \mathrm{R}\right) 2 \mathrm{~T}_{1}\)

\(\mathrm{C}\) \(=\frac{19}{6} \mathrm{R}\)

The state of a thermodynamic system is represented by:

The state of a thermodynamic system is represented by pressure, volume and temperature.

The state of a system is defined by ascribing values to a sufficient number of variables. In mechanics, the state of a body is specified by means of a few measurable quantities, such as the position of centre of mass, its velocity and acceleration etc. In thermodynamics, however we disregard these mechanical coordinates and instead consider the interior of the system, find out directly or indirectly by experiments same measurable quantities upon which the internal state of the system for all thermodynamic purposes, the state of a system can be represented by specifying its pressure p, volume V and the temperature T provided the system is in equilibrium.

An ideal gas is taken through the cycle \(\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}\) as shown in the figure below. If the net heat supplied to the gas in the cycle is \(5 \mathrm{~J}\), the work done by the gas in the process \(\mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}\) is:

In the cyclic process : \(\Delta=0\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{W} \)

\(\Delta \mathrm{W}=\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B}}+\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}}+\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}} \)

\(\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}}=0 \text { (volume remains constant) } \)

\(\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B}}=\mathrm{P}\left(\mathrm{V}_{2}-\mathrm{V}_{1}\right)=10(2-1)=10 \mathrm{~J} \text { (pressure remains constant) } \)

\(\text { Therefore, } 5=10+\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}}=-5 \mathrm{~J}\)
A thermodynamical system is changed from state \(\left(P_{1}, V_{1}\right)\) to \(\left(P_{2}, V_{2}\right)\) by two different processes. The quantity which will remain the same is:

For all processes, change in internal energy \(\Delta U=(\Delta Q-\Delta W)\) does not change. It depends only on initial and final states.

Which of the following is a necessary condition for a process to be reversible?
The substance undergoing a reversible change must at all instances be in thermodynamic equilibrium with its surroundings
There should not be any loss of energy due to conduction, convection or radiation during the cycle
There should not be any loss of energy due to conduction, convection or radiation during the cycle of operation

Conditions for Reversibility :

1. The substance undergoing a reversible change must at all instances be in thermodynamic equilibrium with its surroundings. It means the pressure and temperatures of the working substance must never differ appreciably from its surroundings at any stage of the cycle of operation.

2. All the processes taking place in the cycle of operation must be infinitely slow.

3. There should be a complete absence of frictional forces.

4. There should not be any loss of energy due to conduction, convection or radiation during the cycle of operation.

where \(v\) is the velocity of sound in air or vacuum.

\(\Rightarrow 400=f_{0}\left[\frac{340+50}{340-50}\right]\)

\(=300\) cycles \(/ \mathrm{s}\)

A ball of mass \(2 K g\) moving with velocity \(3 m s^{-1}\), collides with spring of natural length \(2 m\) and force constant \(144 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\). What will be the length of the compressed spring?

Given,

Mass of a ball \(m=2 K g\)

Velocity of a ball \(v=3 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

Natural length of a spring \(=2 m\)

Force constant of a spring, \(k=144 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)

Let the displacement of spring be \(=X\) meter

Calculating the length of compresses spring

Here, when ball collides with the spring, the kinetic energy of a ball will get converted into the potential energy of spring, that is

\(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{1}{2} k X^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow m v^{2}=k X^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \times 3^{2}=144 \times X^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 18=144 \times X^{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow X=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}} m\)

Now the length of compressed spring is given by:

Compressed length \(=\) natural length \(-X\)

\(=2-\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}} \)

\(=\frac{4 \sqrt{2}-1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\)

\(=1.5 m\)

A particle in SHM is described by the displacement equation \(x(t)=A\) \(\cos (\omega t+\theta)\). If the initial \((t=0)\) position of the particle is \(1 \mathrm{~cm}\) and its initial velocity is \(\pi \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{s}\), then what is its amplitude? (The angular frequency of the particle is \(\pi s^{-1}\).)

Given,

Diplacement function of the particle is,

\(x(t)=A \cos (\omega t+\phi)\)

\(x(0)=1 \mathrm{~cm} \text { and } v(0)=\pi \frac{c m}{s e c} \)

\(\text { differentiating w.r. to t, }\)

\(v(t)=-A(\omega) \sin (\omega t+\varphi) \ldots \ldots(1)\)

\(\text { At } t=0, \)

\(x(0)=A \omega \sin (\phi) \ldots \ldots(2) \)

\(v(0)=-A \omega \sin (\phi) \ldots . .(3)\)

Dividing (3) by (2),

\(\frac{v(0)}{x(0)}=-\omega \tan \phi \)

\(\Rightarrow \pi=-\omega \tan \phi \)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \phi=-1\)

i.e \(\phi=\frac{3 \pi}{4}\) or \(\frac{7 \pi}{4}\)

since, at \(t=0\)

\(x(0)=A \cos (\phi)=1\)

\(\Rightarrow \cos \phi\) is positive.

Therefore, \(\phi=\frac{7 \pi}{4}\)

\(\therefore A \cos \left(\frac{7 \pi}{4}\right)=1 \)

\(\Rightarrow A=\sqrt{2} c m\)

The time period of a particle in simple harmonic motion is \(8\) seconds. At \(t=0\), it is at the mean position. The ratio of the distances travelled by it in the \(1^{\text {st }}\) second and the \(2^{\text {nd }}\) second is:

\(x = A \sin \omega t\)

\(x(t=1 s)=A \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi}{T} t\right)\)

\(=A \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi}{8}\right)\)

\(=A \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)

\(=\frac{A}{\sqrt{2}} \)

\(x(t=2 s)=A \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi}{T} t\right)\)

\(=A \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\)

\(=A\)

\(=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}-1}\)

let two perpendicular SHM be

\(\frac{x^{2}}{A^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{B^{2}}=\sin ^{2} \omega t+\cos ^{2} \omega t \)

\(\frac{x^{2}}{A^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{B^{2}}=1\)

This is an equation of simple ellipse.

A point mass \(m\) is suspended at the end of a massless wire of length \(L\) and cross section \(A\). If \(Y\) is Young's modulus for the wire, what will be the frequency of oscillation for the SHM along the vertical line?

In this case, stress \(=\frac{m g}{A}\)

strain \(=\frac{l}{L} \quad\) (where I is extension)

Now, Young's modulus \(Y\) is given by

\(Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}=\frac{\frac{m g}{A}}{\frac{l}{L}} \)

\(m g=\frac{Y A l}{L} \)

\(\text { So, } k l=\frac{Y A l}{L} \quad(\because m g=k l)(\mathrm{k} \text { is force constant })\)

\(\therefore k=\frac{Y A}{L}\)

Now, frequency is given by

\(n=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \)

\(=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\left(\frac{Y A}{m L}\right)}\)
The factor determining the pitch of a tuning fork is:

Pitch is the characteristic of musical sound and depends upon its frequency. The tones of higher frequency are interpreted as shrill and that of low frequency are interpreted as grave.

Pitch is related to frequency. Changing the number of vibrations per second changes the pitch. The pitch that a particular tuning fork generates depends on the length of its prongs. Each fork is stamped with the note it produces (e.g. A) and its frequency in Hertz (e.g. 440 Hz). Shorter prongs produce higher pitch (frequency) sounds than longer prongs. Long prongs will bend more readily and therefore tend to vibrate at a lower frequency when struck.
When both the listener and the source are moving towards each other, then which of the following is true regarding the frequency and wavelength of the wave observed by the observer?

When the distance between the source and listener is decreasing, the apparent frequency increases. According to Doppler's effect, whenever there is a relative motion between a source of sound and listener, the apparent frequency of sound heard by the listener is different from the actual frequency of sound emitted by the source. Let \(S\) be source of sound and \(L\) the listener of sound. Let \(v\) be the actual frequency of sound emitted by the source and \(\lambda\) be the actual wavelength of the sound emitted. If \(v\) is velocity of sound in still air, then \(\lambda=\frac{v}{v}\)

If velocity of listener is \(v_{L}\) and velocity of source is \(v_{S}\), then apparent frequency of sound waves heard by the listener is

\(v^{\prime}=\frac{v-v_{L}}{v-v_{S}} \times v\)

Here, both source and listener are approaching each other.


Then \(v_{S}\) is positive and \(v_{L}\) is negative.

\(\therefore v^{\prime}=\frac{v-\left(-v_{L}\right)}{v-v_{S}} v \)

\(=\left(\frac{v+v_{L}}{v-v_{S}}\right) v\)

ie, \(v^{\prime}>v\)

Also, \(\lambda^{\prime}<\lambda\)

So, listener, listens more frequency and observes less wavelength.
The first overtone of a stretched wire of given length is 320 Hz. The first harmonic is

If a wire, vibrates in \(\mathrm{p}\) segments, then its frequency is given by

\(n=\frac{p}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{T}{m}}\)

The frequency of first harmonic is,

\(n=\frac{1}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{T}{m}} \ldots \text { (i) }\)

The frequency of second harmonic or first overtone is,

\(n^{\prime}=\frac{2}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{T}{m}} \ldots \text { (ii) } \)

\(n^{\prime}=2 n \)

\(n=\frac{n^{\prime}}{2} \)

\(=\frac{320}{2}\)

\(=160 H z\)
The pendulum of a wall clock executes;

The pendulum of a wall clock executes an oscillatory motion.

The bob of a pendulum moves in such a way that it repeats its positions several time but alternately the time gap between these positions is always equal which proves that the motion of a pendulum is oscillatory.

It executes simple harmonic motion because in this motion restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement towards the mean position at any time.
Oscillatory motion is best described by ____________________.
a zig zag motion about a straight line
combination of translational motion and rotational motion

In oscillatory motion object moves to and fro about mean position periodically or after a particular interval of time.All oscillatory motions are periodic in nature.

There are two types of oscillatory motions, namely, Linear Oscillatory Motion and Circular Oscillatory Motion.

In linear motion, the object moves left and right or up and down. Some examples of this type of linear motion are as below:

  1. The vibration of strings of the musical instruments,
  2. Movement of the fluid in a U-tube column and
  3. Floating of ships or big vessels in the sea.

In the circular motion, though the object moves left to right but in circular form. Some examples of this type of motion are as below:

  1. The motion of the solid sphere in a half hollow sphere
  2. The motion of the pendulum in watch
  3. A stringed object suspended on a nail
  4. Motion of swing
  5. The motion of a wheel
How can you describe a periodic motion?
Motion in which object comes to mean position at random intervals of time
Motion that does not repeat itself at regular intervals of time
Motion that repeats itself at regular intervals of time
Motion that repeats itself at irregular intervals of time

A repetitive motion which repeats itself after a regular interval of time is called the Periodic motion. A motion of a body that repeats itself at regular intervals of time on the same path like rotation of earth around sun in 365.25 days.

Usually, a period is measured in seconds. If it is in other units, they should be converted to seconds. The graph below shows a sine wave as an example of periodic motion.
Period of a periodic motion is the ________ interval of time after which the motion is __________.

Period of a periodic motion is the smallest interval of time after which the motion is repeated.

Time period of an oscillatory motion is the smallest interval of time for one complete oscillation. As when we apply the force on the bob, bob moves from mean position to extreme position then form extreme position to mean position and then again from mean to extreme in opposite direction and at last come to mean position. The time taken by bob in this whole process is called period of oscillation.
The reciprocal of the period of oscillation

Frequency of the periodic motion is the reciprocal of the period of oscillation.

Frequency is another quantity that can be used to quantitatively describe the motion of an object is periodic motion. The frequency is defined as the number of complete cycles occurring per period of time. Since the standard metric unit of time is the second, frequency has units of cycles/second.

Frequency is also called 'linear frequency'. Angular frequency is defined as \(2 \pi\) time the linear frequency. It is denoted by \(\omega\) (unit : \(\left.S^{-1}\right)\)

\(\omega=2 \pi v\)

Circular motion is an example of motion in two dimensions.

Motion in a plane is described as two dimensional motion. Example: An ant moving on the top surface of a desk is example of two dimensional motion. Projectile and circular motion are examples of two dimensional motion.

The position vector of a particle \(\vec{R}\) as a function of time is given by:

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{R}}=4 \sin (2 \pi t) \hat{i}+4 \cos (2 \pi t) \hat{j} \text {, }\)

Where \(\mathrm{R}\) is in meters, \(\mathrm{t}\) is in seconds and \(\hat{i}\) and \(\hat{j}\) denote unit vectors along \(\mathrm{x}\)-and \(\mathrm{y}\) - directions, respectively. Which one of the following statements is wrong for the motion of particle?
Path of the particle is a circle of radius \(4 \mathrm{~m}\)
Magnitude of acceleration vector is \(\frac{v^{2}}{R}\), where \(v\) is the velocity of particle.
Magnitude of the velocity of particle is \(8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Step 1: Velocity and acceleration calculation:

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{R}}=4 \sin (2 \pi \mathrm{t}) \hat{1}+4(\cos 2 \pi \mathrm{t}) \hat{\mathrm{j}}\)

Velocity is given by

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}}=\frac{\mathrm{d} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{R}}}{\mathrm{dt}}=8 \pi \cos (2 \pi t) \hat{1}-8 \pi \sin (2 \pi t) \hat{j}\)

Acceleration is given by

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{d \overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}}}{\mathrm{dt}}=-16 \pi^{2} \sin (2 \pi t) \hat{i}-16 \pi^{2} \cos (2 \pi t) \hat{\mathrm{j}}\)

From equation (1) and (3)

\(\vec{a}=-(2 \pi)^{2} \vec{R}\)

\(\therefore\) Acceleration is along \(-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{R}}\)

Step 2: Equation solving

Magnitude of velocity

\(|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}}| =\sqrt{[8 \pi \cos (2 \pi \mathrm{t})]^{2}+[-8 \pi \sin (2 \pi \mathrm{t})]^{2}}\)

\(=8 \pi \sqrt{[\cos (2 \pi \mathrm{t})]^{2}+[\sin (2 \pi \mathrm{t})]^{2}}=8 \pi\)

Magnitude of acceleration

\(|\vec{a}|=\left|-(2 \pi)^{2} \vec{R}\right|=4 \pi^{2}|\vec{R}|\)

From (1) \(|\vec{R}|=\sqrt{4^{2}} \sqrt{\sin ^{2}(2 \pi t)+\cos ^{2} 2 \pi t}=4\) (Radius of circle)

\(\Rightarrow|\vec{a}|=16 \pi^{2}=\frac{|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}}|^{2}}{|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{R}}|}\)

Hence option (A) and (C) are also correct.

The magnitude of velocity is coming \(8 \pi\)

A particle is moving eastwards with a velocity of \(5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). In \(10 \mathrm{~s}\), the velocity changes to \(5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) northwards. The average acceleration in this time is.

The initial velocity of the particle, \(\mathrm{v}=5 \hat{\mathrm{i}}\)

After some time velocity changes to \(5 \hat{\jmath}\)

Change in velocity \(d v=5 \hat{j}-5 \hat{i}\)

Time taken \(t=10 \mathrm{sec} .\)

Average acceleration \(=\left|\frac{d v}{t}\right|=\left|\frac{1}{2}(\hat{j}-\hat{1})\right|=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

The direction is north-west making 135 degrees with east as evident from its components.
